questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with a history of vaginal discharge without itching. On examination, the discharge was milky, nonviscous, and adherent to the vaginal wall. Microscopy of the discharge shows the presence of clue cells. What is the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The above case scenario is Bacterial Vaginosis. It is termed vaginosis rather than vaginitis because it is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora rather than due to any specific infection. It is not sexually transmitted and has a variable incubation period. About 50% of women are asymptomatic carriers of infection.

The presence of clue cells is one of the 4 criteria described in Amsel’s criteria.

Amsel’s criteria are used in the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

At least three of the four criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis.

On microscopy, there is no abundance of polymorphs in the case of bacterial vaginosis as it is just an alteration of flora and not an inflammation.

  • The diagnosis is based on wet smear and culture.
  • The smear reveals clean background with few inflammatory cells and other organ­isms, but scanty lactobacilli. Many epithelial cells present a granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, the so-called clue cells. Gram stain is 90% sensitive.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis comes to the hospital. She complains of blurring of vision in one of the eyes soon after she comes home after her zumba classes. What is the name of this sign?
questions.solution:
The blurring of vision after a physical exercise in multiple sclerosis is Uhthoff's Phenomenon. 

Uhthoff ’s phenomenon refers to the unilateral visual blurring that may occur during a hot shower or with physical exercise. It is an exacerbation of the symptoms of multiple sclerosis due to heat.

Other options:

Option A: Lhermitte's sign is an electric shock-like sensation radiating down the back into the legs. It is induced typically by flexion or other movements of the neck. Lhermitte’s sign can also occur simultaneously with other disorders of the cervical spinal cord like cervical spondylosis.

Option C: Facial myokymia is a persistent, rapid flickering contraction of the facial musculature or a contraction that slowly spreads across the face. It results from lesions of the corticobulbar tracts or in the course of the facial nerve in the brainstem.

Option D: Tic douloureux is the other name for trigeminal neuralgia. It can occur when the demyelinating lesion involves the root entry (or exit) of the fifth cranial nerve.

questions.text: Gallium scan finding shown below is seen in _________
questions.solution:
The given Gallium scan shows the Panda sign which is seen in sarcoidosis.

It is a gallium-67 citrate scan finding. It is due to the bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.

Other signs seen in Sarcoidosis are:

The lambda sign is seen on gallium-67 scans in the setting of thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).

Garland triad, also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign, is a lymph node enlargement pattern which has been described in sarcoidosis:

  • Right paratracheal nodes
  • Right hilar nodes
  • Left hilar nodes

Galaxy sign, initially described as the sarcoid galaxy, represents a coalescent granuloma seen in a minority of patients with pulmonary sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with chronic hepatitis B has high levels of serum HBeAg. Which of the following viral genes is involved in coding the same?
questions.solution:
HBeAg is coded by the C gene. The presence of high levels of HBeAg (and HBV DNA) suggests high infectivity. 

HBV Genome has four overlapping genes. They code for: 

  • S gene-It codes for surface antigen. 
  • C gene-
    • When the C region alone is translated: HBcAg is formed.
    • When translation begins from Pre C region, HBeAg is formed.
  • P gene- Codes for DNA polymerase.
  • X gene- Codes for a non-particulate protein HBxAg.

questions.text: A previously unvaccinated patient presented with a dirty, lacerated wound received an injection of Human anti-tetanus immunoglobulin.  Which of the following type of immunity is offered by this method?
questions.solution:
Human anti-tetanus immunoglobulin provides artificial passive immunity to the recipient.

Artificial passive immunity is the resistance passively transferred to the recipient by the administration of antibodies.

Examples of other types of immunity: 

  • Natural active immunity: Clinical or subclinical infection. 
  • Artificial active immunity: Vaccination.
  • Natural passive immunity: Transplacental transfer of antibody, colustrum.
  • Artificial passive immunity: Anti-tetanus serum, anti-diphtherial serum. 
  • Combined immunization: Antisera and vaccine are given at the same time.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with photosensitivity and pellagra like symptoms despite taking adequate niacin and tryptophan in his food. His mental development is normal but has neurologic symptoms like ataxia, headaches, and hypotonia. Among the following, which could be a probable cause of the impaired absorption which is leading to pellagra like symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hartnup's disease, which is due to impaired renal and intestinal absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids.

It is characterized by a varied clinical presentation including ataxia (lack of muscle control), diarrhea and dermatitis (pellagra-like symptoms as tryptophan is a precursor of niacin). Mental development can be normal or delayed.

Diagnosis is based on aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detected by Obermeyer test.

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Condition/Disease

Reason for niacin deficiency

Hartnup disease

Intestinal & renal malabsorption of tryptophan

Carcinoid syndrome

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Defective kynureninase pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Jowar diet (Sorghum)

Increase leucine content inhibit QPRTase enzyme

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with a recent history of travel to South America was brought to the hospital with fever, enlarged lymph nodes and multiple skin lesions on his face. Tissue sample from the lesion shows the following findings under microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the characteristic pilot's wheel appearance on culture(image) is suggestive of paracoccidioidomycosis caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. It is also called Lutz mycosis/ South American blastomycosis.

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus that causes a chronic granulomatous disease affecting the lungs, skin, mucosa, lymph nodes. On culture, yeast form is seen at 37° C and the mycelial form at 25° C.

Microscopy of tissue sample reveals thick walled, round, yeast cells with numerous buds attached to each other circumferentially giving the classic mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance. Most infections are asymptomatic and few individuals with acute disease present with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy and skin lesions.

The below image shows skin lesions in a child with paracoccidioidomycosis.

Treatment:

  • Mild/moderate disease: Itraconazole
  • Severe disease: Amphotericin B for 2-3weeks followed by Itraconazole. 

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A test is done by taking the fluid from the part labelled as B. Which of the following is false about the test?

choices.text: Classically the test is done between 15-20 weeks
Gives earlier result than chorionic villus sampling
Increased chances of miscarriage if done before 15 weeks
Detects genetic and chromosomal abnormalities in the baby

questions.solution:
Chorionic Villous sampling gives results earlier because it is done early in gestation.

The marked structure B is Amnion and contains amniotic fluid.

Amniocentesis is a test done during pregnancy to check if your baby has a genetic or chromosomal condition, such as Down's syndrome, Edwards' syndrome, or Patau's syndrome.

Amniocentesis is performed using an aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle.

The needle is directed into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord. Sonography is used to observe the uterine puncture site for bleeding and fetal cardiac motion is documented at the end of the procedure.

Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping and chromosomal microarray analysis.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked "A" in the CT scan of the thorax shown below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "A" in the CT Thorax is the ascending aorta.

In a CT study, X-rays are applied in a circular motion and body tissue slices are recreated mathematically. Different tissues are seen with different intensities, depending on the proportion of attenuation of the X-rays that pass through them.

  • Air and water are displayed as low-intensity (dark appearance) areas because they produce only little attenuation.
  • Bone is displayed as a high-intensity structure (bright appearance) because of its significant attenuation.
  • High density is seen in the presence of hyperemia, freshly clotted blood, and contrast agents.
  • Edema and necrosis are seen as low-intensity areas.

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with seizures, mental retardation, and port-wine stain. The CT scan of the brain shows characteristic tram track shaped cortical calcifications. Which is the most common ocular manifestation seen in this type of patient?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Sturge-Weber syndrome and glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation seen in these patients.

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a rare congenital vascular disorder characterized by facial capillary malformation (port-wine stain) and associated capillary-venous malformations affecting the brain and eye.

Ocular manifestations:

  • Glaucoma — The predominant ocular abnormality of SWS is glaucoma (increased intraocular pressure), which occurs in 30 to 70 percent of affected patients.
  • Visual field defects — Many patients have visual field defects, typically homonymous hemianopia. This is due to the presence of a leptomeningeal capillary-venous malformation affecting one or both occipital lobes or optic tracts.
  • Capillary — Venous malformation of the choroid.
  • Heterochromia of the iris
  • Episcleral and conjunctival lesions.

questions.text:
Which of the following increase or decrease appetite:
A- Leptin
B- Orexin
C- Ghrelin
questions.solution:
Leptin decreases the appetite whereas Ghrelin and Orexin increases the appetite.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with pain in the right hypochondrium and fever. He is also having mild jaundice. ERCP showed linear smooth filling defects. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and linear smooth filling defects on ERCP is suggestive of worm in the biliary tree.

The worm may also be seen as parallel filling defects - railway track sign. Worms in the gall-bladder appear as the long tubular coiled echogenic structure which may be rapidly mobile and is easier to diagnose than biliary ductal ascariasis.

Ultrasonography is also highly sensitive and specific to detect worms in biliary tree. USG is not useful to detect worms in duodenum or ampullary orifice.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child with the complaints that he hasn't begun walking or talking. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, and blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU).

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes.

Its symptoms are albinism with vision problems, which include:

  • Strabismus
  • Photophobia
  • Nystagmus
  • Impaired vision or blindness
  • Astigmatism

Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with pain and swelling in the knee joint. The physician advised for the examination of synovial fluid from the knee joint on polarized light microscopy, which showed needle-shaped crystals. What is the composition and birefringence pattern shown by these crystals?

choices.text: Monosodium urate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium pyrophosphate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium oxalate crystals with positive birefringence

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid point towards the diagnosis of gouty arthritis. It is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (MSU), which are needle-shaped and show negative birefringence on polarized light microscopy.

The below image shows negative birefringent needle-shaped crystals seen in gout.

Other options:

Option A- Calcium apatite crystals can occur in areas of tissue damage (dystrophic calcification) and in hypercalcemic or hyperparathyroid states (metastatic calcification). Clumps of these crystals may appear as intra- or extracellular nonbirefringent globules or aggregates that stain purplish with Wright’s stain and bright red with alizarin red S.

Option C- Calcium pyrophosphate crystals (rhomboid-shaped) deposition is seen in pseudogout. These crystals are rod-shaped or rhomboid-shaped and are weakly positive or nonbirefringent crystals.

Option D- Calcium oxalate crystals (CaOx) are seen in chronic renal failure. These crystals can be deposited in visceral organs, blood vessels, bones, and joints. The synovial fluid analysis will show the presence of variable-shaped crystals (commonly bipyramidal crystals are seen) with variable birefringence to polarized light.

NOTE:

Though pseudogout is the condition in which the knee joint is most commonly involved, gout can also involve the knee joint.

Below image shows the crystals seen in pseudogout.

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding

Gout

Pseudogout

Crystal composition

Monosodium urate

Calcium pyrophosphate

Shape

Needle like

Rhomboid

Birefringence pattern

Negative

Weak positive

Most commonly affected joint

1st MTP

Knee

X-ray findings

Periarticular erosions with overhanging margins

Chondrocalcinosis

questions.text: In Breslau's first life test, the organ tested is :
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s first life test (also known as Hydrostatic test/ Floatation test / Raygat’s test) the organ tested is the lung. In Breslau's second life test, stomach and intestine are tested.

Breslau's second life test: It is based on the air entering stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born foetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water.

Interpretation:

  • A positive test proves live birth even in the absence of a positive hydrostatic lung test. This may happen if there had been some obstruction in the respiratory passages.
  • A negative test does not mean stillbirth since air does not necessarily enter the stomach in adequate amounts during the breathing act.
  • Putrefaction invalidates the result.

Other tests for live birth:

  • Wreden’s test – Based on changes in the middle ear after birth.
  • Fodere’s test – Based on the increase in the weight of lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of unrespired lung is 30 – 40g whereas the weight of respired lung is 60 – 66g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs - weight of lungs : weight of the body = 1:70
    • Respired lungs - weight of lungs : weight of the body = 1:35

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The contrast radiograph given above is that of barium follow-through.

It is useful in visualising small bowel pathology. It is performed following a barium meal examination of the oesophagus, stomach, and duodenum. It is inferior to enteroclysis where contrast is administered through NG tube. It is also used to evaluate the function of the small bowel.

Barium meal examines the lower half of the esophagus, stomach, and entire duodenum.

Preparations and uses of Barium sulfate as a contrast in GI imaging:

  • Ba swallow uses barium paste (for esophagus).
  • Ba meal - 95% BaSO4 (for stomach and duodenum).
  • Ba meal follow through - 50% BaSO4 (for small bowel).
  • Ba enema -25% BaSO4 (for large bowel).
  • For Single contrast films, barium alone is used. Double-contrast films require air and barium which is better for a small mucosal lesion.

Contraindications to use of Barium:

  • Tracheoesophageal fistula: Dianosil-water soluble non-ionic agent is used.
  • Perforation peritonitis and esophageal perforation: Iohexol is used.

The above radiograph shows barium meal. 

Barium enema: contrast is administered through a rectal tube and series of radiographs are obtained. It still remains the investigation of choice to visualize fine mucosal detail and also a very good technique for demonstration of general colonic configuration and caliber. The above radiograph is double-contrast barium enema with normal large bowel structure.

This is a recent NEET pattern question and a must know topic.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: Salivary gland tumor with a propensity for perineural invasion:
questions.solution:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma has a propensity for perineural invasion and indolent growth pattern.

  • It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland.
  • The histological types are tubular, cribriform, and solid.
  • The tubular type has the best prognosis and solid has the worst.
  • Treatment is the removal of the gross tumor with radiation therapy for microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 60-year-old male comes to you in hospital. He complains of cough, difficult breathing, loss of appetite and, weight loss. He is a laborer by profession and has been a heavy smoker for the last 35 years. What subtype of lung cancer will be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
In heavy smokers, the most common types are small-cell lung cancers and squamous cell carcinomas.

The most common lung cancer in lifetime non-smokers, light smokers (<10 pack-year history), women, and younger adults (<60 years) is adenocarcinoma. 

WHO classification of lung carcinomas:

The WHO classification system divides epithelial lung cancers into four major cell types:

  • Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Non-small-cell lung carcinomas (NSCLCs)
    • Adenocarcinoma
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Large-cell carcinoma

SCLC may be distinguished from NSCLC by the presence of neuroendocrine markers including CD56, neural cell adhesion molecule (NCAM), synaptophysin, and chromogranin.

questions.text:
You counsel a patient with leprosy about lepra reactions before starting her on multidrug therapy. Which among these is correct regarding these reactions?
  1. Type 1 reactions are unrelated to drug therapy, whereas as type 2 may occur within a year of starting treatment.
  2. Type 1 reaction is seen in the borderline spectrum and type 2 is seen in lepromatous leprosy.
  3. New lesions appear in type 1 and they are tender and erythematous 
  4. Fever, keratitis, iritis, and nephritis can occur with a type 2 reaction.
  5. Steroids are the drug of choice for severe type 1 reactions.
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 4, and 5 regarding lepra reactions are correct. 

Type 2 lepra reactions are unrelated to drug therapy, whereas type 1 reactions may occur within a year of starting treatment.

New lesions typically appear in type 2 lepra reactions. They are tender and erythematous subcutaneous and dermal nodules. Existing lesions show no changes. 

Related Pearl: Lepra Reactions

Lepra Reactions:

Type 1 Reaction

(Reversal/Upgrading)

Type 2 Reaction

(Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

Mainly seen in the Borderline spectrum (BT, BB, BL)

Most severe in Borderline Lepromatous(BL) leprosy

 Mainly seen in LL(50%)>BL(15%)

Usually seen within 12 months of initiation of Multidrug Therapy

 Unrelated to Multidrug therapy. May occur before, during or after treatment

Type 4 Hypersensitivity

Due to enhanced cell-mediated response increased destruction of bacilli following treatment in reversal

Type 3 Hypersensitivity

Primarily Humoral

(Immune complex Deposition in tissues and vessels)

Cytokine involved - TNF-α

Inflammation of existing skin lesions (red, painful edematous skin lesions) that may ulcerate

New lesions may occur (rare)

Neuritis and Nerve abscesses (red, painful inflamed nerves)

New, erythematous and tender, subcutaneous and dermal nodules that are widely distributed over extremities and face

Existing lesions do not change
No systemic involvement Systemic symptoms present - fever, myalgias, arthralgias, anorexia, keratitis, iritis, nephritis, synovitis, orchitis, lymphadenopathy

Treatment:

Supportive therapy for mild reactions with NSAIDs

In case of severe reactions with neuritis and eye lesions- Oral corticosteroids

(Drug of Choice)

Nerve Abscess - Additional surgical drainage

Other drugs: Clofazimine, Cyclosporine

Treatment:

Oral Corticosteroids - First-line drug

Clofazimine (Steroid dependent ENL)

Thalidomide -most effective but not used first due to various side effects

questions.text:
Match the following buffer systems and their predominant locations:
A-Extracellular Buffer		
B-Intracellular Buffer
1-HCO3
2-Hemoglobin
3-Plasma protein
questions.solution:
Buffers are located in the extracellular fluid, intracellular fluid, and bone.

Extracellular Buffers:

The most important buffer in the ECF and the body is HCO3- (bicarbonate) which combines with excess H+ ions to form carbonic acid. The CO2/HCO3- buffer system is considered very effective because of the vast quantity of bicarbonate in the body and the ability to excrete the CO2 formed via ventilation. Other less important buffers in the ECF are plasma proteins and inorganic phosphates. 

Intracellular Buffers:

The primary intracellular buffers are proteins, organic and inorganic phosphates, and in the RBC, hemoglobin.

Bone Buffers:

It has been estimated that at least 40% of the buffering of an acute acid load takes place in the bone. Chronic acidosis can have very adverse effects on bone mineralization due to this process and can result in bone diseases such as rickets, osteomalacia, and osteopenia.

 

The most effective extracellular buffer system at physiological pH is the bicarbonate buffer system.

A molecule with a pKa close to the physiological pH (7.4) is considered an effective buffer.

Although the pKa of HCO3- is relatively low (6.1), it makes up 92% of the plasma buffering. This is often attributed to the enormous quantity of CO2 and HCO3- present in the body and the ability of this system to accept protons and convert bicarbonate to readily excretable CO2. This system is therefore considered as the most efficient extracellular buffering system in the body.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following is false about panel discussion?

choices.text: It usually consists of four to eight experts
Members of the audience are invited to take part at the end

questions.solution:
A moderator is required to regulate the panel discussion.

In a panel discussion, 4 to 8 experts have a discussion on a topic in front of an audience. No speeches or order is set beforehand. The audience is invited to take part after the panelists speak and ask questions.

questions.text:
You observe a six-year-old child in the ward and notice the following. Which of the following are true regarding this sign?
  1. It is due to distal muscle weakness
  2. It is pathognomonic of Duchenne muscular dystrophy
  3. It can be seen in Dermatomyositis
  4. It is seen only in children older than 5 years 
  5. It can be seen in Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy
questions.solution:
The image shows the Gowers sign. Patients use their hands to “climb up” their legs when asked to rise from a prone position to compensate for proximal lower-extremity weakness. An early Gowers sign is often evident by age of 3 years and is fully expressed by age of 5 or 6 years.

This maneuver can be seen in patients with:

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy
  • Becker's muscular dystrophy
  • Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy
  • Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy
  • Polymyositis
  • Dermatomyositis

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, significant lymphadenopathy is seen. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Which of the following is not usually involved in the immunohistochemistry of this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and bone marrow findings are suggestive of Acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Cytokeratin is an epithelial cell marker for Thymoma, whereas Tdt, CD1a, and CD3 are markers seen in ALL.

The given image points show lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm which are characteristics of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

ALL is more common in childhood with peak incidence around 3-5 years of age. The child had symptoms related to depression of marrow function including anemia, and fever secondary to infections. These infections are due to neutropenia and generalized lymphadenopathy, indicating the effect of neoplastic infiltration. Hepatosplenomegaly points towards extra-medullary hematopoiesis.

 

Related Pearl: Origin of leukemia / lymphoma and their immunophenotypes

questions.text: Parents of a child with the following finding are concerned. The child is found to have 21 hydroxylase deficiency. Both parents do not have the disease. They would like to know the chances of their next child being a carrier for the same disorder. The chances are _______
questions.solution:
The given finding is ambiguous genitalia, and having 21 hydroxylase deficiency is seen in Congenital adrenal hyperplasia(CAH). CAH is an autosomal recessive disorder, therefore there is a 50% chance of their next child being a carrier for the same.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders caused by the deficiency of enzymes involved in the synthesis of steroid hormones in the adrenal cortex.

Depending on the enzyme that is deficient, patients will have the signs, symptoms, and laboratory findings of:

  • Mineralocorticoid deficiency or excess
  • Incomplete virilization or precocious puberty in males
  • Virilization or sexual infantilism in females

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A newborn on routine head-to-toe examination was found to have ambiguous genitalia. Following a battery of lab-investigations, it was found to be 21-hydroxylase deficient. What is clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 21-hydroxylase deficiency causes congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which is a disorder of ambiguous genitalia.

The investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) in the newborn is by the measurement of 17-hydroxyprogesterone.

The diagnosis of 21-hydroxylase deficiency is most reliably established by measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone before and 30 or 60 min after an intravenous bolus of 0.125-0.25mg of cosyntropin (ACTH).

However, prenatal diagnosis of 21-hydroxylase is possible late in the 1st trimester by analysis of DNA obtained by chorionic villus sampling or during the 2nd trimester by amniocentesis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. The stool demonstrates occult blood. The small bowel is found to have a small infarcted area which is surgically removed. Histopathologic examination on the resected bowel reveals fibrinoid necrosis of an artery with a mixed inflammatory infiltrate containing neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells. In this patient, such fibrinoid necrosis can be seen in all of the following except _______
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). It characteristically spares the pulmonary circulation.

PAN is a systemic vasculitis of small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically involves the renal (most commonly involved) and visceral vessels. It has no association with ANCA, but about 30% of patients have chronic hepatitis-B.

The patient may present with rapidly accelerating hypertension due to renal artery involvement or abdominal pain and bloody stools caused by gastrointestinal vessels' involvement.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came to the casualty with a history of intake of antipsychotics for 4 days. He presents with grimacing, abnormal posturing, and increased tone in the muscles with a flexed neck. Which of the following is the best drug in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The patient has developed acute muscular dystonia. Benztropine can be used for the management of acute dystonia.

Acute dystonia is an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics that occurs within 1-5 days of intake. It is characterized by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck, and back.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, back

questions.text: A gynaecologist suspects tuberculous salpingitis in a young woman and suggests some investigations to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is true about these investigations?

choices.text: A differential WBC count shows lymphocytosis in advanced disease.
The ESR is frequently raised and is non-specific in early disease.
The Mantoux test is positive and indicative of current exposure to tubercle bacilli.
The Quantiferon test is positive and indicates latent tuberculosis.

questions.solution:
The Quantiferon test will be positive in patients having genital TB. It is an indicator of latent tuberculosis. The Quantiferon test measures the release of interferon-gamma by  T cells following stimulation by antigens unique to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

A differential WBC count shows lymphocytosis at all stages of genital tuberculosis. The ESR is frequently raised and is a non-specific investigation at any stage of the disease. None of these tests can be used for confirmation as these markers are raised in many infections.

The Mantoux test is positive in 90% of cases of genital TB. It is indicative of past exposure to the tubercle bacilli. It is not a confirmatory investigation but a negative result indicates tuberculosis to be unlikely.

questions.text: A diabetic patient reports that his index finger initially remains bent, but with further effort, it suddenly straightens with a snap. On examination, a tender nodule can be felt in front of the metacarpophalangeal joint. The suspected deformity is called _______.
questions.solution:
The given findings are suggestive of the trigger finger, and it is caused by the involvement of the flexor tendon.

Trigger finger is caused by stenosing tenosynovitis of the flexor sheath. There is nodular or fusiform swelling on the flexor tendon. When the finger is flexed or extended, the nodular swelling passes through the A1 pulley with a snap, leading to a triggering effect.

The nodule can be trapped behind the A1 pulley, leading to a locking of the finger in flexion. Surgical treatment involves the release of the A1 pulley, which is thickened and fibrosed.

Other options: 

Option A: Mallet finger/baseball finger is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the distal interphalangeal joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g. a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.

Option C: Bouchard nodes are the osteophytes or bony lumps present in the proximal interphalangeal joints. These are seen in patients with osteoarthritis. 

Option D: Dupuytren's contracture is proliferating fibroplasia involving palmar aponeurosis. It causes flexion deformity of one or more fingers as a result of abnormal thickening and shortening of the palmar aponeurosis. It is more common in males, and the incidence is higher in patients with cirrhosis of the liver, diabetes, smoking, and AIDS.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old lady who recently went in for an IUCD contraception has increasing pelvic discomfort and pain just a few days before her menses begin. The pain is relieved once the menses starts. What is the clinical diagnosis in this case?

IUCD: Intrauterine contraceptive device
questions.solution:
Pelvic discomfort and pain just a few days before menses are suggestive of congestive dysmenorrhea.

Dysmenorrhea is defined as cramping pain that occurs during menstruation.

It can be classified as:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhea is a type of dysmenorrhoea that is not associated with any pelvic pathology. It affects women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles.
  • Secondary (Acquired) dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and endometriosis. 

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the most common and is characterized by cramping pain on the first and second days of menstruation. 
  • Congestive dysmenorrhea presents as worsening pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain, a few days before the onset of menses followed by relief of the symptoms. This is seen in PID, IUCD users, varicosities of pelvic veins, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids. 
  • Membranous dysmenorrhea is rare and is characterized by crampy pain that occurs with the passage of the endometrium as a cast at the time of menstruation.

Primary dysmenorrhea can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), combined oral contraceptive pills, and progestin-only pills. GnRH agonists and androgens are also useful. Surgical management includes hysterectomy and is indicated if not responding to medical management. In secondary dysmenorrhea, treating the cause is needed.

Fibromyalgia is a disorder with diffuse musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It is associated with irritable bowel syndrome, anxiety, and depression. There is no cure for fibromyalgia as of now, although the symptoms can be controlled by medications. Researchers believe that fibromyalgia amplifies painful sensations by affecting the way your brain processes pain signals.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with an unsteady gait, forgetfulness, and labile moods.  Physical examination is remarkable for the ocular Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring and examination findings as shown below. Which of the following options correctly indicate the gene most likely mutated in this condition and its location?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Wilson's disease. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder is caused by a mutation in the ATP7B gene located on chromosome 13.

The ATP7B gene encodes a transmembrane copper-transporting ATPase, expressed on the hepatocyte canalicular membrane. In Wilson disease, there is a deficiency in the ATP7B protein. This causes a decrease in copper excretion into the bile, impairs its incorporation into ceruloplasmin, and inhibits ceruloplasmin secretion into the blood, leading to the accumulation of toxic levels of copper in the liver, brain, and eye.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor(shown in the gif in question)- It is a low‐frequency, high‐amplitude, tremor, elicited by sustained abduction of the arms, with flexed elbows and palms facing downwards.
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring - It is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea

The image below shows the ocular KF ring.

 

Diagnosis:

    • Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and zinc are the first choice of drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Note: 

Menkes disease is an X-linked metabolic disturbance of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the copper-transporting ATP7A gene.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Which of the following shows True Koebner’s phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Lichen Planus shows True Koebner’s phenomenon.

Koebner’s phenomenon/ isomorphic response is the development of lesions in previously normal skin that has been subjected to trauma. If the same response is seen from the spread of an infective agent ( like molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), it's called pseudo-koebner’s phenomenon.

Any of the following can elicit an isomorphic response:

  1. Physical trauma, including friction
  2. Incision and laceration
  3. Skin grafting
  4. Bites
  5. Vaccination skin tests
  6. Burns, freezing, and ultraviolet (UV), and ionizing radiation.

It is seen commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo. Other associated disorders include Darrier’s disease, pityriasis rubra pilaris, lichen nidatus, DLE, necrobiosis lipoidica, and Grzybowski syndrome.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: A male infant presented with distension of abdomen shortly after birth with a history of not passing meconium. Subsequently, a barium enema was done and its findings are shown below. This disease is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a barium enema showing a dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon characteristic of Hirschsprung's disease. Hirschsprung disease is associated with Down syndrome. 10% of all cases of Hirschsprung disease occur in children with Down syndrome.

Hirschsprung disease is also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon. The premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum produces aganglionosis of the distal intestinal segment. This causes functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation. Diagnosis requires documenting the absence of ganglion cells within the affected segment.

Heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase RET account for the majority of familial and sporadic Hirschsprung disease cases. There is an association between Downs syndrome and Hirschsprung disease as well. The disease is more common in males, but, when present in females, the affected aganglionic segment tends to be longer.

Diagnosis : 

Histologic confirmation that ganglion cells are absent within the affected segment through hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections or immunohistochemical stains for acetylcholinesterase.

Based on the segments affected, they are classified into -

  • Short-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease having proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

The rectum is always affected, but the length of the additional involved segments varies widely. In most cases, the abnormality extends to the sigmoid colon, but in severe cases, the entire colon may be involved.

The aganglionic region may have a grossly normal or contracted appearance. The normally innervated proximal colon undergoes progressive dilation and may become massively distended (congenital megacolon) as a result of the distal obstruction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is admitted to the ICU. Which of the following finding is most likely to be associated with pleural rub sound?
questions.solution:
In a patient with an infection, pleural rub sounds are most likely to be heard over the affected lobe of the lung. 

A pleural friction rub is an adventitious breath sound that is heard on auscultation of the lung. it results from the movement of inflamed and roughened pleural surfaces against one another during movement of the chest wall. Disease-associated with infection and inflammation like pleural effusion, pleuritis, or serositis can result in a pleural friction rub.

Vesicular breath sounds are normal breath sounds.

Bronchial breath sounds are associated with consolidation.

In added sounds: 

  • Wheezes are heard in asthma, COPD, infection, and cardiac failure.
  • Crackles are heard in pulmonary fibrosis, cardiac failure, and COPD.
  • The pleural rub is associated with infection.

questions.text: When do the gonads of the baby acquire the morphological characteristics of a male or female?
questions.solution:
Gonads acquire male or female characteristics only after the 7th week of development. 

Initially, the gonads appear as a longitudinal ridge called genital or gonadal ridge. The germ cells do not appear in these longitudinal ridges until the 6th week of development.

Although the chromosomal and genetic sex of an embryo is determined at fertilization by the kind of sperm that fertilizes the ovum, male and female morphological characteristics of sex do not begin to develop until the 7th week.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant neurotransmitter in the pars reticulata of the substantia nigra?
questions.solution: The predominant neurotransmitter in the pars reticulata of substantial nigra is Gamma Amino Butyric Acid (GABA). Dopamine is the predominant neurotransmitter in the pars compacta of substantia nigra.

questions.text: You are an intern who is posted in a TB screening camp in a village. In this camp, all the village people were screened for tuberculosis with the help of chest x-rays irrespective of risk factors. This type of screening is an example of _______
questions.solution:
Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using Chest X-rays for TB screening irrespective of the presence of any risk factors. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination with a large number of people at one time. Example: Annual health checkups.

High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups for example- MRI screening of breast done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in the first-degree relative.

questions.text: You are a resident doctor, posted in medicine IPD. A patient under treatment for pancreatic insufficiency develops a scaly rash as shown below. He is on lipid-free- total parenteral nutrition as he isn't tolerating enteral feeding. The consultant on rounds suspects essential fatty acid deficiency and adds IV lipid emulsion to treatment. Which of the following is not seen in essential fatty acid deficiency?

choices.text: Decrease in plasma concentrations of w3 fatty acids

questions.solution:
Deficiency of essential fatty acids causes loss of structural integrity of the skin and cell membranes leading to like scaly dermatitis, hair loss, and poor wound healing.

Essential fatty acid deficiency is a rarely seen clinical entity. But conditions like bowel resection, pancreatic insufficiency, cystic fibrosis, and fat-free TPN predispose to EFA deficiency. Plasma may show elevated levels of the triene-tetraene ratio. Including adequate IV lipid emulsion to supplement essential fatty acid is a possible treatment.

questions.text: A mother brings her 1-year-old  child concerned with his development. The child can stand without support, he walks but falls, speaks a few words but doesn't form sentences, he can hold things as shown below but cannot scribble yet. What would be your impression on developmental milestones according to his age?
questions.solution:
The child has attained all the milestones a 1-year-old would attain. Therefore, he has normal development.

The child can stand without support, walks but falls, he has attained a mature pincer grasp and can speak a few words with meaning. All these gross motor, fine motor skills, and language milestones are attained by the age of 12 months.

The mother just needs to be reassured.

Related Pearl: Gross motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
3 months Neck holding
5 months Rolls over
6 months Sits with support
8 months Sits without support
9 months Stands with support
12 months

Stands without support

Creeps well

Walks but falls
15 months

Walks without support

Creeps upstairs
18 months Runs
2 years Walks upstairs and downstairs (2 feet/step)
3 years

Walks upstairs with alternate foot

Rides tricycle
4 years

Walks downstairs with alternate foot

Hopping on 1 foot
5 years Can skip without falling to either side

 

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental milestones 

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought to the child health clinic, along with his twin brother. The clinical history reveals that the child is being artificially fed and the birth order was found to be 5. Records indicate, birth weight was noted as 2.8 kgs. Which of the following would not be a criterion for identifying this baby as an 'at-risk' infant?
questions.solution:
Birth weight less than 2.5kg (not 2.8kg) is a criterion for identifying at-risk infants.

At a child health clinic, the criteria to identify at-risk infants include:

  • Birth weight less than 2.5kgs
  • Twins
  • Birth order of 5 or more
  • Artificial feeding
  • Weight below 70% of the expected weight
  • Failure to gain weight during 3 successive months
  • Children with PEM

questions.text: A college-going student was brought to the ER after suffering a head injury in the college sports event. The 2nd year PG tells you to calculate GCS as you were the only intern available. On examination, you find out that the student was confused, he opens his eyes spontaneously, flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. You calculate the Glasgow Coma Score to be________
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Score in this patient is 13.

To calculate the GCS score, the following clinical points have to be considered:

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused
  • The score for eye-opening: 4, because his eyes are opening spontaneously.
  • The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+4+5) = 13.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: True about the structure given below is ________

choices.text: They are nuclear remnants in RBC

questions.solution:
The image shows Heinz bodies which are seen in G6PD deficiency.

Heinz bodies:

  • Exposure of G6PD deficient red cells to high levels of oxidants causes the cross-linking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains. These become denatured and form membrane-bound precipitates known as Heinz bodies.
  • Visualized by supravital staining.
  • Bite cells - as the splenic macrophages pluck out these inclusions, bite cells are produced.

Howell Jolly bodies:

  • Small nuclear remnants seen as inclusions in red cells due to asplenia.
  • They can also be seen in sickle cell anemia due to auto splenectomy or in Hereditary spherocytosis or thalassemia post splenectomy in some red cells but it is not characteristic. The image shows Howell Jolly bodies in peripheral blood smear.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Heinz bodies G-6-PD deficiency 
Gamna–Gandy bodies Congestive splenomegaly 
Mallory bodies Hyaline inclusions in hepatocytes seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis
Councilman bodies Hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis, seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.
Psammoma bodies Dystrophic calcification in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenoma of ovary & papillary carcinoma of thyroid, papillary type of renal cell carcinoma.
Donovan bodies Granuloma inguinale 
Nissl's bodies Cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons 
Mooser bodies Typhus fever
Creola bodies Asthma 
Verocay bodies Schwannoma 
Schiller–Duval bodies Endodermal sinus tumor 

Hirano bodies

  Alzheimer’s disease

Ferruginous bodies

 Asbestosis

questions.text: A boy is brought with complaints of pain and deformity of the right knee. He is a known case of severe hemophilia A.  On examination, a boggy swelling is noticed over the right knee. Which of the following is least likely to be found on radiography of the right knee?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of hemophilic arthritis. Juxta-articular osteopenia is seen in hemophiliac arthritis, not juxta-articular osteosclerosis.

It is caused due to repeated hemarthrosis into the joint leading to chronic synovitis and articular cartilage erosion.

Other radiological features include:

  • Soft tissue swelling
  • Increase in intercondylar distance
  • Subchondral thinning
  • Subchondral bone cyst
  • Hemophilic pseudotumors

questions.text: A 1.5-year-old baby was brought to you with the concern of dry appearing eyes. You suspect Xeropthalmia. What dose and route would you start the vitamin A immediately?
questions.solution:
The recommended dosage for a 1.5-year-old child with vitamin A deficiency is 2,00,000 IU to be given immediately, followed by the same age specific dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks.

The route of administration is oral.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A patient presents with persistent iron deficiency anemia and GI endoscopy reveals the dilated venules as shown in the below image. what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of endoscopy shows dilated venules appearing as linear red streaks converging on the antrum in longitudinal fashion, giving ‘Watermelon appearance of stomach’ which is characteristic of Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia.

GAVE :

  • Presence of both inflammatory and vascular components in mucosa.
  • Dilated mucosal blood vessels
  • Affects antrum of stomach
  • On endoscopy – Prominent longitudinal folds with parallel striking red stripes

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with persistent productive cough and clubbing. On auscultation, wheeze and crackles are present.  The signet ring sign is seen on HRCT. Which of the following statement is false for this condition?

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis involves the upper lung fields
Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis involves central airways
Copious amount of sputum is produced

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis. There is an irreversible airway dilation in this disease.

It is caused by the destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue due to complications from infections, congenital conditions, or autoimmune disorders.

There are 4 morphological types:

  1. Tubular or cylindrical type
  2. Cystic type
  3. Varicose type
  4. Traction bronchiectasis - seen in interstitial lung disease and is associated with fibrosis

Clinically, the patients present with a cough with excessive foul-smelling mucopurulent sputum. On examination, clubbing of the digits, and the presence of crackles on auscultation may be noted.

HRCT is the investigation of choice to confirm the disease. HRCT findings in bronchiectasis include:

  • The signet ring sign is seen when the dilated bronchus and accompanying pulmonary artery branch are seen in cross-section. The bronchus and artery should be the same size, whereas, in bronchiectasis, the bronchus is 1.5 times the size of the adjacent vessel.
  • Thickened secretions are seen as tree-in-bud pattern.
  • Tram track sign is seen due to lack of peripheral tapering of the bronchus. 
  • String of beads appearance is seen as alternate dilatation and constriction in varicose bronchiectasis. 
  • Cluster of grapes appearance is seen as cysts emanating from the bronchial wall in cystic bronchiectasis.

 

Treatment of bronchiectasis includes:

  • Antibiotic treatment targeting the causative pathogen (most common: H. influenzae and P. aeruginosa) should be administered for a minimum of 10–14 days.
  • Mucolytic administration: The mucolytic dornase (DNase) is recommended routinely in CF-related bronchiectasis, but not in non-CF bronchiectasis, given concerns about potential harm in the non-CF population.
  • Bronchial hygiene
  • Hydration
  • Aerosolization of bronchodilators.
  • Hyperosmolar agents (e.g., hypertonic saline).
  • Chest physiotherapy
  • Pulmonary rehabilitation
  • Refractory cases: Resection of a focal area of suppuration, lung transplantation.

questions.text: A patient comes to the orthopedic OPD with chronic neck pain, he has a short neck and limited range of neck movements, especially of lateral bending. His neck X-ray is given below. Which of the following is true about the concerned diagnosis?

choices.text: 75% of the fusion segments occur in lower cervical spine
One of the signs in clinical triad is high posterior hairline
Failure of segmentation of cervical somites during 12th week of embryogenesis
There is an important association with fetal alcohol syndrome

questions.solution:
The given case suggests of Klippel-Feil syndrome. There is an important association with Fetal alcohol syndrome. The given X-ray shows the fusion of C6, C7, and T1 vertebrae.

Klippel-Feil syndrome is a developmental disorder caused by a failure of normal segmentation of the cervical somites during the 3rd to 8th week of embryogenesis, not the 12th week. This results in a congenital fusion of at least 2 cervical vertebrae, sometimes a block of cervical vertebrae, and rarely the entire cervical spine.

In Klippel-Feil syndrome, classic clinical triad includes the short neck, low posterior hairline, and limited range of neck motion. Congenital fusion of cervical segments can occur at any level, but approximately 75% occur in the upper cervical spine, not lower.

questions.text: Two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection, A 4-year-old child presents with ecchymosis and petechiae all over the body. An abdominal examination revealed no hepatosplenomegaly. Blood reports show Platelet count as 15,000/microL and the coagulation profile was normal. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of the above disease?
questions.solution:
Mucocutaneous bleeding and reduced platelet count two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection are suggestive of acute idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Romiplostim a TPO agent administered subcutaneously is not yet FDA approved.

In children:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder in which there is immune-mediated destruction of platelets. 

Acute ITP: Acute presentation with a self-limited course in children

  • Presenting features:
    • Preceded by a viral infection
    • Mucocutaneous bleeding
    • Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever, and jaundice are absent
    • Resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases in 4-6 weeks.
  • Laboratory features:
    • Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000 / μL)
    • Normal/Increased megakaryocytes in bone marrow
    • Prolonged bleeding time
    • Normal tests for coagulation (PT/PTT/INR)
    • Peripheral smear is normal
  • Treatment: 
    • Mild-moderate bleeding symptoms: watchful expectancy
    • Platelet count < 30,000 + risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or concomitant bleeding disorders): Oral glucocorticoids/ IVIG or 
    • Severe bleeding symptoms: IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG 
    • Life-threatening bleeding (eg. intracranial hemorrhage): platelet transfusion + IV methylprednisolone + IVIG 

Deep tissue bleeding (joints and muscles) such as muscle hematomas and hemarthrosis is seen in coagulation disorders or clotting factor deficiencies. 

Superficial mucocutaneous bleeding such as epistaxis, petechiae, ecchymosis is seen in bleeding disorders or platelet disorders.

Related Pearl: Differences between Bleeding Disorders and Coagulation disorders

Finding Bleeding disorders Coagulation disorders
Cause

Quantitative/ Qualitative platelet abnormality

 Deficiency of clotting factors
Sex More common in females (commonly autoimmune) More common in males (commonly X-linked)
Family history Rare (except in VWD) Common
Petechiae Characteristic  Rare
Superficial ecchymosis Small and Multiple Large and Solitary
Bleeding from superficial cuts  Profuse Minimal persistent
Hemarthrosis Rare Characteristic (most common-knee)
Deep dissecting hematomas Rare Characteristic (most common-iliopsoas)
Laboratory tests Bleeding time is prolonged PT and/or PTT are prolonged
Most common Inherited: VWD

Inherited: Hemophilia A

Acquired: Hemorrhagic diathesis of liver disease

VWD: von Willebrand disease

PT: Prothrombin time

PTT: Partial thromboplastin time

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of recurrent bilious vomiting for the past few hours. He was born at 37 weeks gestation and weighed 2.7 kg. The mother was diagnosed with polyhydramnios during pregnancy. His abdominal X-ray shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette and the radiograph showing the presence of a double bubble sign are strongly suggestive of duodenal atresia. 

Duodenal atresia occurs due to failure of recanalization of the duodenal lumen during the gestational period. 

It is associated with various conditions including prematurity, Down’s syndrome, and maternal polyhydramnios. It is also associated with malformations of the hepatobiliary system such as the annular pancreas and biliary atresia.

In most cases, this duodenal obstruction is seen distal to the ampulla of Vater. Hence, infants present with bilious vomiting and features of intestinal obstruction soon after birth. On examination, the upper abdomen is distended with a scaphoid lower abdomen. 

It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. Other investigations include abdominal radiographs that show the double-bubble sign. If distal air is present, an upper GI contrast study should be done to exclude midgut volvulus, which is a surgical emergency.

Definitive management is by surgical bypass of the obstruction as a side-to-side or transverse to longitudinal (diamond-shaped) duodenoduodenostomy. 

Other options:

Option A: In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis the abdominal radiograph will show a single enlarged gastric gas bubble. 

Option C: In jejunal atresia the abdominal radiograph will show a triple bubble sign.

Option D: In colonic atresia the abdominal radiograph will show multiple dilated bowel loops and differentiation between small and large bowel is not possible in neonates. A contrast enema study can confirm the diagnosis. The contrast does not pass proximally to the sigmoid colon.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 32-year-old working IT professional came for a mobile cervical cancer screening camp planned at her workplace. What is the following instrument used to perform this screening test?
questions.solution:
The given instrument used in the patient's pap smear preparation is Ayre's spatula. 

Sharpness on the end can differentiate between Ayre's and Aylesbury spatula. Aylesbury spatula has a more sharp and longer tip than Ayer's spatula. So, Aylesbury spatula is superior to Ayre's in collecting endocervical samples.

The image given below shows a slide holding bottle i.e. Kopliks jar with Ayre's spatula.

questions.text: A person working in the smelting industry presents with the finding as shown below. She also complains of painful paresthesia over the hands and feet. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing hyperkeratosis of palms are suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning.

Acute poisoning: Resembles cholera; garlicky odor.

Chronic poisoning:

  • Raindrop pigmentation is seen on temples, eyelids, and neck
  • Aldrich-Mee’s lines (transverse white striae on the fingernails)
  • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles
  • Painful paresthesia of hands and feet
  • The red velvety appearance of the stomach
  • Blackfoot disease - a gangrenous condition affecting the extremities

Tests to detect Arsenic poisoning:

  • Marsh test and Reinsch test

Treatment:

  • Freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide
  • BAL (British anti-Lewisite)
  • Penicillamine (If BAL is not available)

 Mee’s lines - Transverse white striae of the fingernails are shown below.

Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles is shown below.

Raindrop pigmentation is shown below.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-
