questions.text: A 35-year-old G2P1 at 38 weeks of gestation came to the labor room with complaints of decreased fetal movements.  A non-stress test was done and variable decelerations are noted.  It indicates ______
questions.solution:
Variable deceleration indicates Umbilical cord compression.

Deceleration: Decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15s.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with tingling and numbness over the left shoulder and arm. The physician evaluates his sensory system by neurologic examination. Which of the following stimulus correctly corresponds to the cutaneous mechanoreceptor that would be sensing it?

choices.text: Stretch and fluttering vibration - Meissner's corpuscles
Sustained pressure and touch - Merkel cells
Fast vibration and deep pressure - Ruffini corpuscles

questions.solution:
The Merkel cells are expanded dendritic endings in the epidermis of glabrous skin and respond to sustained pressure and touch. They are located in the epidermis of the skin.

Correct pairs of other options:

  • Fast vibration and deep pressure- Pacinian corpuscles
  • Slow vibration- Meissner's corpuscles
  • Sustained pressure and touch- Merkel cells
  • Stretch and fluttering vibration- Ruffini corpuscles

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient has been prescribed a drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin for the treatment of his chronic gout. What is this drug?
questions.solution:
The drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin for the treatment of chronic gout is pegloticase.

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase) that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite. It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated. The efficacy of this drug gets lowered if antibodies are produced against the drug, which occurs in many patients. This also increases the risk of infusion reactions. 

Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase. It is indicated for the initial management of elevated plasma uric acid levels in patients with malignancies who are on chemotherapy. The efficacy is limited by the production of antibodies to the drug.

Gout occurs due to the precipitation of urate crystals in the tissues with a subsequent inflammatory response. In an acute episode of gout, there is painful distal monoarthritis which can lead to joint destruction, subcutaneous tophi, and renal calculi. Management of gout includes:

  • Reduction of pain and inflammation: NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids
  • Inhibition of the formation of urate: Allopurinol, febuxostat
  • Promotion of urate excretion: Probenecid, lesinurad

Other options: 

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin, this reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils. Overall reducing the inflammatory response.

Option B: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin
Thiazide
Lasix (furosemide)
Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: During a measles epidemic in the community, a 6-month-old child is brought to the vaccination camp. What would you do?

choices.text: Proceed with the immunization of the child for measles
Give half of the dose of usual vaccination
No vaccination is given as the child is less than 9 months
Give the vaccine only if the child develops symptoms

questions.solution:
In the setting of a measles epidemic, we proceed with immunization of measles for this child.

The scheduled age for receiving the first dose of measles vaccine is at 9 months. The second dose is given between 15 - 18 months of age such that the minimum interval between the 2 doses is 4 weeks.  A supplementary dose can be given at the age of  6 months for the following cases:

  • As a part of intensified service delivery during a measles outbreak 
  • In places where the risk of measles among infants < 9 months of age remains high (endemic countries experiencing regular outbreaks)
  • Individual infants at high risk of contracting measles (history of contact with known cases)
  • Infants traveling to countries experiencing measles outbreaks
  • Infants who are known to be HIV-infected or exposed 

Infants immunized between 6 months should further receive doses 1 and 2 according to the national schedule. Thus in the given case, this infant will be immunized at 6 months due to the epidemic and then receive the regular doses at 9 and 15-18 months of age.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of a constant leakage of urine and dysuria even after undergoing fistula repair surgery for vesicovaginal fistula. You decide to attempt a second fistula repair surgery. In order to perform the second surgery, you would counsel the patient to wait for at least
questions.solution:
In order to perform the second surgery, you should counsel the patient to wait for at least 3 months.

The given scenario is suggestive of failed surgery. If the fistula repair fails, one should wait for at least 3 months before attempting a second repair.

Patients usually present with constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence). The constant leakage of urine may lead to excoriation of genital regions. The fistula located at the vaginal vault post-hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat.

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presents with prominent facial erythema, telangiectasia, as shown in the image. It usually gets triggered by eating spicy food or being out in the sunlight. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given image shows erythema and papules on the central face, which along with a history of triggering factors points towards Acne Rosacea.

Rosacea is a chronic disorder with fluctuating severity. It is triggered by exposure to sunlight, spicy food, alcohol, or emotional disturbances. Patients also develop telangiectasia later. They also tend to develop rapid flushing due to temperature change. Rosacea is more common in women aged 30 to 50 years.

A common feature in the majority of patients with rosacea is the presence of facial erythema variably associated with the following:

  • Facial vascular changes: subtype 1 (erythematotelangiectatic rosacea).
  • Inflammatory lesions: subtype 2 (papulopustular rosacea).
  • Hypertrophic changes: subtype 3 (phymatous rosacea).
  • Ocular involvement: subtype 4 (ocular rosacea).

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions will you see a histologically normal bone?
questions.solution:
Histologically normal bone with decreased density is the hallmark feature of osteoporosis.

In advanced osteoporosis, both the trabecular bone of the medulla and the cortical bone are markedly thinned leading to progressive microfractures.

Option A: Inadequate mineralization in osteomalacia leads to a thickened osteoid matrix. 

Option C: Paget's disease presents with a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone.

Option D: Dissecting osteitis cystica is seen in severe hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: The given egg is of:
questions.solution:
Given egg is elongated with lateral spine. Hence it is an egg of Schistosoma mansoni.

Species differentiation of Schistosoma can be done based on the location of spine as follows.

  • Terminal spine: Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni
  • Round with small lateral knob or Rudimentary spine: Schistosoma japonicum.

Related Pearl: Eggs of Schistosoma

questions.text: What is the triangular space bound by the clitoris, labia minora and fourchette known as?
questions.solution:
The triangular space bounded by clitoris, labia minora and fourchette is the vestibule.

The vestibule is the space lying between the anterior and the inner aspects of the labia minora and is bounded posteriorly by the vaginal introitus.

It has 4 openings, namely:

  • Urethral opening
  • Vaginal orifice opening
  • Bartholin’s duct on either side
  • Ducts of paraurethral glands

The posterior part of the vestibule between the fourchette and the vaginal opening is called the fossa navicularis.

questions.text: The image below shows a clinical finding on the skin of a patient with a particular condition. What is its first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
The given image shows burrows that are found in scabies. The first-line treatment for scabies is topical permethrin.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei. Allergic sensitivity to the mite or its products appears to play an important role in determining the development of lesions other than burrows, and in producing pruritus.

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who presented with a painless lump in the breast following an injury was diagnosed with traumatic fat necrosis. All of the following features are present in this condition except:

choices.text: Lump is freely mobile in breast

questions.solution:
Lump in traumatic fat necrosis is fixed or tethered to the skin.

Traumatic fat necrosis mimics breast carcinoma. As it may present with:

  • Skin tethering
  • Nipple retraction
  • Lump in the breast(often painless).
  • Mammographic densities or calcifications

Note: A history of trauma is not diagnostic as this may merely have drawn the patient’s attention to a pre-existing lump and biopsy is required for diagnosis.

It has no malignant potential.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the calcium homeostasis?

choices.text: Parathyroid hormone increases formation of vitamin D
CaSR is a G protein coupled receptor
Calcitonin increases calcium excretion in urine
Calcitonin causes the activation of osteoclasts

questions.solution:
Option D is false. Calcitonin causes inhibition of the osteoclasts.

The parathyroid hormone increases the formation of the 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol and this increases the absorption of calcium from the intestine.

The calcium-sensing receptor, CaSR is a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), which is located in the parathyroid gland. When the serum calcium levels are higher, it is sensed by this receptor and inhibits the secretion of the parathormone.

Calcitonin, in an attempt to lower the serum levels of calcium, increases the urinary excretion of the calcium.

Effects of parathormone (PTH): In response to low levels of Ca+2 in the extracellular fluid(ECF), PTH tends to increase Ca+2 concentration by:

  • Increasing bone resorption leading to Ca+2 release into the ECF
  • Increased reabsorption ofCa+2 by renal tubules, decreasing the urinaryCa+2 excretion
  • Decreased phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules, increasing the urinary excretion of phosphate
  • Conversion of 25-­hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25­-dihydroxycholecalciferol- increases intestinal Ca absorption 

Effects of Calcitonin: Calcitonin tends to decrease plasma calcium concentration in response to high levels ofCa+2 in the ECF, with effects opposite to that of PTH:

  • Decreased osteoclastic and osteoblastic activ­ity
  • Slowing of intestinal absorption of Ca+2

However, the effects of calcitonin on Ca+2 regulation are minor in adult humans.

questions.text: The following figure shows the transverse section of the uterus with an implanted zygote. Identify structure A.
questions.solution:
In the given image, the decidua basalis is marked as A. This part of the decidua forms the placenta.

Implantation occurs 6 to 7 days after fertilization. After implantation, the endometrium is called the decidua. It is of the following types:

  • Decidua basalis - present over chorion frondosum. Decidua basalis and chorion frondosum form the placenta. 
  • Decidua capsularis - present over abembryonic pole. 
  • Decidua parietalis - present on the opposite side of the uterus.

The villi cover the entire surface of the chorion during the early weeks. As the fetus grows, the villi on the embryonic pole continue to grow, giving rise to the chorion frondosum. At the abembryonic pole, the villi degenerate. By the third month, this side of the chorion becomes smooth, and is called the chorion laeve.

As the fetus grows, the chorion laeve comes into contact with the decidua parietalis on the opposite side of the uterus, and fusion occurs. Thus, the uterine lumen is obliterated. The amnion and chorion fuse, to form the amniochorionic membrane. Rupture of the amniochorionic membrane during labor is called 'breaking of waters'.

Note: Superfetation can theoretically occur till the time the uterine lumen is not obliterated.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient is being evaluated for infertility. His semen analysis shows a sperm concentration of 10 million/ml, pH of 7.5, and volume of 2 mL. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The semen analysis showing a sperm concentration of 10 million/mL (<15 million/mL), and normal pH and volume are suggestive of oligozoospermia. 

According to the WHO 2010 criteria for semen analysis, the lower reference limit for normal sperm concentration is 15 million/mL. Oligozoospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.

Other options: 

Option A: Normozoospermia refers to normal values of all ejaculate parameters. 

Option C: Azoospermia refers to no spermatozoa in the ejaculate. 

Option D: Aspermia refers to no semen. 

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

Related Pearl: Causes of Male Infertility

Pre-testicular causes:

Endocrine cause

  • Gonadotropin deficiency
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperprolactinemia

Psychosexual

  • Impotence
  • Erectile dysfunction

Drugs

  • Antihypertensives
  • Antipsychotics

Genetics

  • 47XXY
  • Y chromosome deletions

Testicular causes:

  • Immotile cilia syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Orchitis (mumps, Tb, gonorrhoea, traumatic)
  • Toxins(Drugs,radiation)
  • Primary testicular failure
  • Sertoli cell-only syndrome
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

Post-testicular causes:

Obstruction of efferent duct 

Congenital

  • Absence of Vas deferens
  • Youngs syndrome

Acquired (Inflammatory block)

  • Tuberculosis
  • Gonorrhea

Surgical

  • Vasectomy

Others

  • Ejaculatory failure
  • Bladder neck surgery
  • Retrograde ejaculation 

Related Pearl: Management of male infertility

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was posted for a modified radical mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection. During this procedure, the boundary of axillary lymph node dissection was seen as shown in the image. The superior boundary marked as "A" is formed by _________
questions.solution:
The superior boundary of the axillary lymph node dissection area is bounded by the axillary vein.

Boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection are as follows:

  • Superior: Axillary vein
  • Lateral: Thoracodorsal pedicle
  • Medial: Costoclavicular ligament (Halstead ligament)
  • Inferior: Angular vein    

A minimum of 10 lymph nodes is removed during axillary clearance.

questions.text: A junior resident was conducting a study on factors affecting dead space. In which of the following posture and airway position would he notice the maximum increase in dead space?
questions.solution:
A junior resident would notice a maximum increase in dead space in Upright posture with Neck extension.

Dead space is the volume of a breath that does not participate in gas exchange. It is ventilation without perfusion.

  • Total dead space (Physiological dead space) = Anatomical dead space+alveolar dead space.
  • Anatomical dead space is the area in the tracheobronchial tree where the gaseous exchange between the lung and capillaries doesn’t take place. It includes nasal cavity, larynx, trachea, bronchi, end of the terminal bronchiole.
  • Alveolar dead space is the volume of gas within unperfused alveoli (and thus not participating in gas exchange either)

Factors affecting dead space:

questions.text: If a drug is known to be distributed into the total body water, what dose of the drug is needed to obtain an initial plasma level of 5 mg/L in a male patient weighing 70 kg?
questions.solution:
The drug dose needed to achieve initial plasma concentration is the loading dose, which is 210 mg in this case.

The equation for loading dose or the volume of the distribution equation can be used for calculation.
Loading Dose = Vd × Cp

Since the patient weighs 70 kg and 60% of his body weight is water, he has 42 L (70 L x 60%) of total body water.
Loading Dose = 42 L × 5 mg/L = 210 mg.

questions.text: You are posted as an occupational health officer in an industry. You would perform a daily medical examination on the workers that are handling ________.
questions.solution:
Workers who handle irritant chemicals like dichromate require a daily medical examination.

A periodic medical examination is necessary when workers handle toxic or poisonous substances. This is done to recognize any early stages of diseases related to occupational origin. The frequency of the examination will depend on the type of occupational exposure. These periodical examinations may be supplemented with radiological and biological tests whenever necessary.

Industry Frequency of examination
Dichromate Daily
Lead, radium, toxic dyes Monthly
Most other exposure  Annually

questions.text: A chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presented with a history of a mild burning sensation in his mouth that is aggravated while eating spicy foods. The oral examination showed creamy white patches on the oral mucosa. The wet mount microscopy of the scraping obtained from the patches is given below. This organism is a  ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of creamy white patches on the oral mucosa and the wet mount microscopy showing budding and pseudohyphae are suggestive of oral candidiasis caused by candida, which is a yeast-like fungi.

Fungi are eukaryotic organisms with a rigid cell wall made of chitin and mannan and true nuclei with the nuclear membrane and paired chromosomes. They divide sexually, asexually, or by both processes and can be unicellular or multicellular. They are classified into 4 types based on their morphology :

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Candida species are yeast-like fungi, which normally inhabit the skin and mucosa. Candida albicans is an ovoid or spherical budding cell, which produces pseudohyphae both in tissues and in culture. Candidiasis is an opportunistic endogenous infection. Risk factors include treatment with corticosteroids or antibiotics, high levels of glucose, and AIDS.

Diagnosis includes :

  • Gram staining - Gram-positive budding cells with pseudohyphae.
  • Sabouraud agar culture - Creamy white smooth colonies with yeasty odor.
  • Corn meal agar culture - Candida albicans form chlamydospores.
  • Reynolds Braude phenomenon - Candida albicans form germ tubes when incubated in human serum.
  • CHROMagar - Candida albicans colonies appear green.

Treatment: Topical clotrimazole, nystatin, and fluconazole.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A person working in a farm developed multiple nodules along the lymphatics following rose thorn prick. The culture showed the following appearance. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
History of rose thorn prick, noduloulcerative lesions, and culture showing flower-like clusters of small conidia points towards the diagnosis of Sporotrichosis or rose gardener’s disease.

  • It is caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.
  • Most commonly follows minor trauma like thorn prick etc in rose gardeners, forest workers, etc.
  • More common in Himalayan hilly areas (Himachal Pradesh).

Clinical features:

  • Nodules along the lymphatics which later undergo necrosis and ulceration.
  • Spreads along lymphatics to lymph nodes which become enlarged, suppurative and indurated.
  • Other rare types – osteoarticular, pulmonary, disseminated type.

Diagnosis:

  • Cigar-shaped asteroid bodies in H & E stained tissue sections
  • Culture – flower-like clusters of small conidia
  • Latex agglutination test
  • Skin test – delayed hypersensitivity to sporotrichin.

Treatment:

  • Cutaneous form – Potassium iodide (oral or topical)
  • Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole
  • Disseminated infection – Amphotericin B

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, who presented with a thyroid nodule was advised to undergo FNAC. The cytology report classifies the nodule as Bethesda category 4. What would be the usual management in this case?
questions.solution:
The usual management of a patient classified as Bethesda category 4 is Lobectomy. 

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of the thyroid is the initial screening test for thyroid nodules. The Bethesda system classifies thyroid FNAC into six categories. Each category is linked to a malignancy risk and has a recommended clinical management. 

Bethesda criteria for reporting thyroid cytopathology:

questions.text: A mother is concerned that her 1-year-old daughter has been having repeated episodes of UTI since birth. The pediatrician ordered a voiding cystourethrogram, which revealed reflux of urine into the upper collecting systems without any dilation. Under which grade of vesicoureteral reflux will this presentation be classified?
questions.solution:
Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) severity is graded according to the appearance of the urinary tract on a contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

It is classified into 5 grades (Grade I to V):

Grading of vesicoureteral reﬂux:

  • Grade I- VUR into a non-dilated ureter
  • Grade II- VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation
  • Grade III- VUR into the dilated ureter and/or blunting of calyceal fornices.
  • Grade IV- VUR into a grossly dilated ureter
  • Grade V- Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with clinical features of severe photosensitivity, red fluorescent urine and erythrodontia is suspected of Gunther's disease. All of the following are true about the suspected diagnosis except _______

choices.text: Have Severe disfigurement with werewolves prototype
Also called as congenital erythropoietic porphyria
Inherited in an autosomal dominant manner

questions.solution:
Congenital erythropoietic porphyria also is known as Gunther's disease is autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. 

It presents with non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth. Severe cutaneous photosensitivity is present. Uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocyte, plasma urine, and faeces.

Portwine urine or pink stain in diapers is seen. When illuminated with UV light, the teeth show a reddish fluorescence phenomenon known as erythrodontia.

Severe photosensitivity, red fluorescent urine, and erythrodontia are usually diagnostic of erythropoietic porphyria. Some patients with severe disfigurement and photosensitivity have been suggested as prototypes of werewolves.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: The echocardiography report of a 35-year-old woman hailing from China indicates dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following conditions can explain her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy is characteristic, and may also result in cardiomegaly, congestive cardiac failure and fulminant cardiogenic shock.

Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of the 21st amino acid selenocysteine. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as:

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

questions.text: The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes all of the following symptoms except:
questions.solution:
The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes the following symptoms:

  • Headache
  • Profuse sweating
  • Palpitation (due to tachycardia)

Hypertension is the most predominant sign of pheochromocytoma. Though intermittent hypertension is a classical feature, sustained hypertension is also common.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Classical triad of symptoms:
    • Headaches – most common symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction
  • Polyuria and polydipsia 
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient is posted for an inguinal hernia operation. The anesthetist intends to use a regional anesthesia technique that blocks the nerves in the anterior abdominal wall. Between which of the following structures would the anesthetist be injecting the drug mixture?

choices.text: Between internal oblique and external oblique
Between internal oblique and rectus abdominis
Between internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
The local anesthetic is injected between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles in the anterior abdominal wall. This is because the neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between these two muscles.

The transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block is a regional anesthetic technique for abdominal surgery. 

The neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis in the anterior abdominal wall.

The plane contains:

  • Lower 6 thoracic nerves (T7-12)
  • Iliohypogastric nerves
  • Posterior intercostal and subcostal vessels
  • Anastomosis between superior and inferior epigastric arteries

questions.text: You are monitoring a patient being treated with atropine for alleged consumption of an organophosphate compound. Suddenly he develops marked excitement and claims to see his late wife sitting next to him. All of the following can be used in the management of this patient except?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of marked excitement and hallucinations are seen in atropine toxicity. Chlorpromazine should be avoided in patients with atropine toxicity.

Chlorpromazine is a low potency typical antipsychotic having high anticholinergic activity. Administering phenothiazines like chlorpromazine will worsen atropine toxicity.

 

Option A: Physostigmine is indicated as first-line therapy for atropine intoxication 

Option B and D: Benzodiazepines can be used when marked excitement is present to calm down the patient

questions.text: A 22-year-old primi in her 26th week of gestation is advised glucose challenge test (GCT) for screening for gestational diabetes mellitus. As her GCT values were on the high side, she was subjected to a 3-hour oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) to confirm the diagnosis of GDM. What is the amount of glucose (in grams) you would administer for performing the GCT and OGTT respectively?
questions.solution:
The amount of glucose recommended for performing the glucose challenge test (GCT), and 3-hour oral glucose tolerance test is 50 grams and 100 grams respectively.

Two-step approach: The first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). In the second step, the patients who meet the threshold value in OGCT are subjected to 100gm three hours OGTT, which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus.

Glucose challenge test:

  • Procedure: Patient is asked to take 50gm of oral glucose and Venous plasma glucose is measured one hour later.
  • Cut off values: OGCT values of ≥140mg/dl is taken as cut-off value for doing OGTT.

Glucose tolerance test:

  • Patients who meet the threshold value in GCT are subjected to 100gm three hour OGTT for the diagnosis of GDM.

Note :

The one-step approach omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

questions.text: A 25-year old man presents with the condition given in the image. Which of the following is not associated with the condition in the image?
questions.solution:
The image above depicts gynecomastia in a young male patient. Gynecomastia may be associated with functioning testicular tumors, but not in seminoma.

Gynecomastia occurs as a result of an imbalance between estrogens, which stimulate breast tissue, and androgens, which counteract these effects.

The most common causes are as follows:

  • Cirrhosis of the liver
  • Alcohol
  • Marijuana, heroin
  • Antiretroviral therapy
  • Anabolic steroids
  • Klinefelter syndrome (XXY karyotype)
  • Functioning testicular neoplasms, such as the Leydig cell or Sertoli cell tumors.

Microscopically, there is an increase in dense collagenous connective tissue associated with epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micro-papillae. Lobule formation is almost never observed.

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh-negative sensitized mother?
questions.solution:
MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for the monitoring of fetuses in Rh-negative sensitized mothers.

The middle cerebral artery is used as other fetal vessels require a larger insonating angle and confers significant measurement error.

MCA PSV is enhanced due to increased cardiac output and decreased viscosity of fetal blood, which permits the reliable, noninvasive detection of fetal anemia in cases of blood-group alloimmunization. 

If the MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) and the gestational age is less than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered. MCA Doppler PSV has replaced amniocentesis as the preferred test for the detection of anemia.

questions.text: A patient with mild hip and back pain is asked to perform some movements at the hip joints to look for any pathology. The following movement done by him at the right hip joint is facilitated by all the given muscles, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image shows extension movement being done at the right hip joint. The iliacus is not involved in the extension of the hip. It causes flexion of the hip joint.

Muscles involved in extension of the hip joint are:

  • Gluteus maximus
  • Biceps femoris
  • Adductor magnus
  • Semitendinosus
  • Semimembranosus

Muscles involved in flexion of the hip joint are:

  • Psoas major
  • Iliacus
  • Rectus femoris

questions.text: The method of shoulder reduction shown below is called ________
questions.solution:
The given method of shoulder reduction is Stimson's method.

Stimson’s gravity method: The patient is made to lie prone with the arm hanging over the side of the bed. A weight may be attached to the elbow or wrist. The shoulder may reduce after 15-20 minutes. 

Other methods of reduction for anterior shoulder reduction are:

  • Hippocratic method (traction counter-traction): Gently increasing traction is applied to the arm with the shoulder in slight abduction.  Counter-traction is applied with the heel in the axilla.
  • Kocher's maneuver: traction, external rotation, adduction, medial rotation (TEAM).

Bigelow method: This a method of reduction of hip dislocation.

(Note: There is also a method of reduction of hip dislocation called Stimson's gravity method, where the same concept of using gravity is performed to reduce the dislocation, but that procedure is not very practical).

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: The following are seen in "dystocia dystrophia syndrome" except ______

choices.text: The patient is stockily built with short thighs

questions.solution:
In the dystocia dystrophia syndrome, the patient is subfertile. 

Other features include:

  • Stockily built with bull neck, has broad shoulders and short thighs. She is obese with a male distribution of hairs.
  • They are subfertile, having dysmenorrhea, oligomenorrhea or irregular periods.
  • There is increased incidence of pre-eclampsia and a tendency for postmaturity.
  • The pelvis is of the android type. Occipito-posterior position is common.
  • During labor, there is a tendency for deep transverse arrest or outlet dystocia leading to difficult instrumental delivery or cesarean section.
  • There is a chance of lactation failure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was found to have an ovarian mass incidentally during an abdominal ultrasound. Which of the following tumor markers is suggestive of an ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
CA-125, LDH, and Inhibin may all indicate the presence of an ovarian tumor.

CA-125 is suggestive of an ovarian epithelial tumor.

Elevated LDH is found in dysgerminoma.

Elevated inhibin levels are suggestive of Granulosa cell tumors.

questions.text: A patient presents to your clinic with the following deformity. In which of the following conditions is this deformity seen?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a swan-neck deformity seen in a patient with established rheumatoid arthritis(RA). Swan-neck deformity is hyperextension at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.


Some of the other small joint deformities of the hand in a patient with RA include:


Boutonnière deformity with flexion at the PIP joint and hyperextension at the DIP joint. 


Z-line deformity with hyperextension at the DIP joint and subluxation of the 1st metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A patient has soft tissue sarcoma in the sole of the left foot. MRI shows that the tumor has infiltrated only up to the first layer of the sole. Which of the following muscles is most likely to be spared by the tumor infiltration?
questions.solution:
The flexor digiti minimi brevis is a component of the third layer of the sole. Hence, it is most likely to be spared by the tumor.

The muscles of the sole of the foot are arranged in 4 layers. From superficial to deep, the layers are numbered from one to four.

Muscles of the sole of the foot:

1st layer: This is the superficial layer which includes abductor hallucis, abductor digiti minimi, and flexor digitorum brevis.

2nd layer: It consists of flexor accessorius and the four lumbrical muscles,the tendons of flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus run in the same plane as the muscles of the second layer.

3rd layer: It contains the shorter intrinsic muscles of the toes, which are flexor hallucis brevis, adductor hallucis and flexor digiti minimi brevis.

4th layer: It consists of plantar and dorsal interossei and the tendons of tibialis posterior and fibularis longus.

questions.text: A pregnant woman, who was in her first trimester was referred to the radiologist for gestational age estimation. Which one of the following parameters would she usually consider for the sonographic estimation of gestation age in this patient?
questions.solution:
Crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate parameter used for the sonographic estimation of gestational age in the first trimester. It has an accuracy range of ± 5 days.

Parameters for estimation of fetal age

Trimester

Parameter

First

Crown-rump length (CRL)

Second
  • Biparietal diameter (BPD)
  • Abdominal Circumference (AC)
  • Head Circumference (HC)
  • Femur Length. (FL) 

Third

Femur length

questions.text: A newborn is found to have hearing loss and bilateral congenital cataracts. The echocardiography reveals a ventricular septal defect. What is false regarding the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Most commonly associated cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
Infection in early pregnancy causes milder disease
Foetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness

questions.solution:
The child presents with the classical triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome.

The earlier the infection occurs in pregnancy the greater the damage is to the fetus.

The major determinant of the extent of fetal infection in Congenital Rubella Syndrome is the gestational age at which fetal transmission occurs.

Infection in 1st trimester:

  • Abortions
  • Stillbirth
  • Skin lesions: Blueberry muffin lesions
  • Triad of congenital rubella syndrome
    • Sensorineural deafness
    • Congenital heart defects – MC is PDA
    • Cataracts

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A  researcher focussing on genodermatology was studying the harmful effect of UV radiation on human skin. He observed that UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA  polymerase. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms corrects this particular defect?
questions.solution:
The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA.

Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair. There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

The following image shows an eight-year-old girl with xeroderma pigmentosum. Frontal image of the face, showing large hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face. Marked corneal scarring and injection are evident.

 

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair, leading to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

In XP the skin is normal at birth. Initially, there will be diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle lesions. As time passes these lesions become permanent. As the age progresses a characterized lesion called poikiloderma occurs. It consists of skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and mottled hyper and hypopigmented areas. By the age of 4 -5 years, they present with multiple malignancies including squamous cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin. Since deeper structures like eyelids, cornea, and lens are shielded, are lesser affected.

XP is ultimately fatal. Early detection of skin lesions and their management (prevention of exposure to UV rays) prolongs life. 

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Breast cancer suspectibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Trichothiodystrophy (TTD)

questions.text: A newborn presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was diagnosed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: It is a severe form of mitochondrial disorder
Very-long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) levels are increased
Most patients die in the first year of life

questions.solution:
A cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is a rare inherited absence of peroxisomes (not a mitochondrial disorder). It occurs due to mutations in genes encoding proteins called peroxins, involved in peroxisome biogenesis.

It is a form of leukodystrophy (white matter lesion). Such individuals accumulate C26-C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissues and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. It causes severe neurological symptoms and most patients die in the first year of life. Very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) levels are increased in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome belongs to the Zellweger spectrum. The other two conditions in this spectrum are Adrenoleukodystrophy and Infantile Refsum disease in decreasing order of severity.

Other options:

Most patients die in the first year of life. It is autosomal recessive in inheritance, patients might be asymptomatic carriers.

There is an accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, abnormalities in bile acid synthesis, and a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

questions.text: A research scholar is preparing to do a prospective cohort study in a hospital to evaluate the association of H. pylori with inflammatory bowel disease. Which of the following measures must she take, before starting the study?

choices.text: Enrol all patients taking proton pump inhibitors
Enrol all patients on whom endoscopy was done
Exclude all patients diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease
Exclude all patients with positive urea breath test for H. pylori

questions.solution:
All patients diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) must be excluded from a prospective cohort study, as the study progresses from cause to effect. The study begins before the disease under study has occurred.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of blood in her urine. She informs you that this happens every month for 1 week and stops on its own. She underwent a C-section 1 year ago and has no history of incontinence. During clinical examination, a catheter is inserted into the bladder, and the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the catheter emerging from the cervical os. This, along with the history of cyclical hematuria, is suggestive of Youssef syndrome seen in a case of vesicouterine fistula.

Vesicouterine fistulas can develop after cesarean section, uterine rupture, and placenta accreta. Most cases present weeks to years later.

Vesicouterine fistulas can present with cyclical hematuria, urinary incontinence or complete continence, menstrual abnormalities, and urinary tract infections. Youssef syndrome is seen in cases of vesicouterine fistulas, and it is associated with a classic triad:

  • Amenorrhea
  • Cyclical hematuria - also called menouria: Menstrual blood trickles into the bladder through the fistula, causing hematuria
  • Urinary continence (there is no vaginal leakage of urine)

Hysteroscopy and cystoscopy are gold-standard investigations. 

Vesicouterine fistulas are treated as follows: 

  • Prolonged bladder catheterization - leads to spontaneous closure
  • Surgical repair via abdominal route

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was recently diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma and was started on an anticancer drug. After a few days, the patient started passing blood in the urine for which mesna was used as a treatment. Which of the following is responsible for the side effect?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from hemorrhagic cystitis as an adverse effect, due to the toxic metabolite of cyclophosphamide called acrolein. This can be decreased by vigorous hydration and by the use of mercaptoethanesulfonate (mesna).

Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent that interferes with DNA integrity and function. It induces cell death in rapidly proliferating tissues. It is metabolised by hepatic cytochrome enzyme to form 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide. The tautomer of 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide called aldophosphamide cleaves non-enzymatically in the tumor cell to form phosphoramide mustard and acrolein.

Antitumor effects are due to phosphoramide mustard, while acrolein causes hemorrhagic cystitis. Vigorous intravenous hydration should be done in patients with high-dose treatment. Brisk hematuria in a patient receiving daily oral therapy should lead to immediate drug discontinuation.

Cyclophosphamide is an essential component of many effective drug combinations for non-Hodgkin lymphomas, other lymphoid malignancies, breast and ovarian cancers, and solid tumors in children.

questions.text: The lung compliance of a 40-year-old patient with shortness of breath has been compared to that of a normal person in the pressure-volume curve below. What is the likely diagnosis based on this chart?
questions.solution:
The interpretation of the above pressure-volume curve shows that the patient has increased lung compliance, making the likely diagnosis of pulmonary emphysema. 

Compliance is the tendency for tissue to resume its original position after an applied force has been removed.

After an expiration during quiet breathing, the lungs have a tendency to collapse and the chest wall has a tendency to expand. The interaction between the recoil of the lungs and the recoil of the chest can be measured through a spirometer and a curve of airway pressure plotted against volume is the pressure-volume curve of the total respiratory system (Ptr).

Compliance of the lung and chest wall is measured as the slope of the PTR curve, or, as a change in lung volume per unit change in airway pressure (ΔV/ΔP). 

  • The curve is shifted downwards when compared to normal in case of decreased compliance. Eg. pulmonary edema, and interstitial pulmonary fibrosis due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated. Decreased compliance is also seen in sarcoidosis.
  • The curve is shifted upwards and to the left in case of increased compliance. Eg. emphysema, normal aging lungs due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched).

 

Increased compliance seen in emphysema is due to - 

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: The following appearance on ERCP is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The given appearance of the fish-eye lesion of the ampulla of Vater on ERCP is characteristic of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). 

Mucin can be seen extruding from the ampulla of Vater, a so-called fish-eye lesion that is virtually diagnostic of IPMN.

Cyst fluid analysis of various pancreatic cystic neoplasms:

Characteristics Serous cystic neoplasm (SCN) Mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN)

Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN)
Cytology


 Scant glycogen-rich cells, with positive periodic acid-Schiff stain Sheets and clusters of columnar, mucin-containing cells Tall, columnar, mucin-containing cells

Mucin stain

 Negative Positive Positive
Amylase Low Low High
CEA Low High High

Related Pearl: Cystic Neoplasm of the Pancreas

Characteristics Serous Cystadenoma Mucinous Cystadenoma
Nature Benign Benign, but high risk of malignancy
Epidemiology Common in females (F:M = 2:1) and older age 
Associated with von Hippel Lindau syndrome 		 Most common cystic neoplasm of the pancreas 
Common in perimenopausal females
Usual site

Usually tail of the pancreas, can be uniformly distributed

 Body and tail of the pancreas
Microscopy Microcysts giving a honey-comb appearance Glycogen-rich cells Mucin-producing epithelium
Ovarian-like stroma
Stains positive for estrogen and progesterone
CT Central calcification, with radiating septa giving sunburst appearance.

Solitary cyst with fine septations, surrounded by a rim of calcification.

Eggshell calcification, large tumor size, or a mural nodule are suggestive of malignancy
Cyst fluid analysis

Mucin negative

Low CEA and amylase

Mucin-rich aspirate

High CEA and low amylase
Treatment

Mainly conservative

Good
