questions.text: A 40-year-old patient suffering from AIDS is on zidovudine, lamivudine, and indinavir therapy. He develops pulmonary tuberculosis for which treatment is started. Which of the following drugs need to be used in his antitubercular regimen?
questions.solution:
Rifabutin needs to be added to the antitubercular regimen of AIDS patients if they suffer from pulmonary tuberculosis.

Rifampicin is a potent inducer of CYP enzymes including CYPs 1A2, 3A4, 2C9 and 2C19, which in turn can induce the metabolism of indinavir and can result in therapeutic failure. Therefore, Rifampicin is avoided and Rifabutin is preferred.

Cytochrome Enzymes inducing Potency of Rifamycins is:

  • Rifampicin: Highest
  • Rifapentine: Intermediate
  • Rifabutin: Least

questions.text: Which of the following shows the boiler’s notch of noise-induced hearing loss?

choices.text: Both air and bone conduction curves

questions.solution:
Boiler’s notch is a dip in both BC and AC curve at 4000 Hz seen in noise-induced hearing loss.

This audiometry finding is also known as 4-kHz notch/acoustic dip/Boilermaker’s disease.

Note: Carhart's notch typically dips at 2000 Hz in Bone Conduction curve.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is also known as the supratrochlear artery?
questions.solution:
The inferior ulnar collateral artery is also known as the supratrochlear artery.

The following illustration shows the branches of the brachial artery.

It has 3 Branches: 

  • Profunda Brachii (accompanies radial nerve in the spiral groove) gives nutrient artery to the humerus, gives off an ascending branch, which anastomoses with Posterior circumflex humeral artery, it divides into: 
    • Anterior descending artery (Radial collateral artery)  
    • Posterior descending artery (Middle collateral artery) 
  • Superior ulnar collateral artery (accompanies ulnar nerve)
  • Inferior ulnar collateral (Supratrochlear) artery.

Note: There is another artery named supratrochlear artery in the orbital region. This is a terminal branch of the ophthalmic artery.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient complains of chest pain radiating to the neck and the left arm. He was started on medications that included trimetazidine as one of them. Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism of this drug?

choices.text: Shift from glucose to free fatty acid metabolism
Shift from free fatty acid to glucose metabolism
Agonist at ATP sensitive potassium channels

questions.solution:
Trimetazidine causes the metabolism to shift from free fatty acids to glucose. This requires less oxygen and is beneficial in ischemia. 

Trimetazidine is an antianginal agent which blocks the thiolase enzyme, the final enzyme in the β-oxidation of fatty acids. This causes a partial shift in the metabolism of the myocardium from free fatty acids to glucose. Glucose oxidation provides lesser ATP but also requires less oxygen. This is beneficial in ischemic states. 

The most important adverse effect of trimetazidine is the increased risk of movement disorders like Parkinson disease. This risk is higher in older patients and those with kidney dysfunction. Hence, it is used only as an add-on drug in the treatment of angina.

Ranolazine is another second-line anti-anginal drug that acts by blocking late sodium current (option B). Nicorandil acts as an agonist at ATP-sensitive potassium channels (option D) and causes vasodilation of both arterial and venous vascular beds. This leads to decreased preload and afterload of the heart.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia, with a leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. What is the origin of the malignant cell?

choices.text: Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

questions.solution:
The clinical features and peripheral smear are suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). In CLL, B cells originate from naive B cell or Pre/Post Germinal Centre memory B cell. CLL arises in the lymph node.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL)/ Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL):

The CLL and SLL differ only in the degree of peripheral blood lymphocytes. CLL is the most common leukemia of adults in the western world. The median age of diagnosis is 60 years. The most common genetic anomalies seen are deletions of 13q14.3, 11q, and 17p and trisomy 12q. Loss of tumor suppressor genes in chromosome 13 results in overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein BCL2.

The growth of CLL/SLL cells is confined to the proliferation centers (pathognomonic for CLL/SLL), where the tumor cells receive critical factors from the surrounding environments, such as NF-κB for cell survival, MYC for cell growth, Bruton Tyrosine Kinase (BTK) signaling pathway, etc.,

The tumor cells express CD19, CD20, CD23, and CD5. Smudge cells are also characteristic of CLL. Clinical features include easy fatiguability, weight loss, anorexia, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, hemolytic anemia, etc. CLL/SLL has a tendency to transform to a more aggressive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL)  - this is called Richter syndrome.

The peripheral smear in CLL shows, small round lymphocytes (indicated by arrow) with condensed chromatin, and scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells may get disrupted while preparing the smears, producing so-called smudge cells (indicated by arrowhead).

Factors with a bad prognosis include:

  1. Presence of deletions of 11q and 17p.
  2. Lack of somatic hypermutation.
  3. Expression of ZAP-70 augmenting signals produced by the Ig receptor.
  4. Presence of NOTCH1 mutations.

BTK inhibitors and BCL2 inhibitors are highly active targeted therapy for CLL/SLL.

Other options:

Option A - Centrocytes are the origin of malignancy in follicular lymphoma.
Option B - Diffuse large B cell lymphoma can arise from nodal as well as extranodal mature B cells.
Option D - Bone marrow progenitors are the origin of CML and AML.

questions.text: A 45-year-old teacher comes to you with complaints of dryness, tightness, and soreness in the throat. He says these symptoms appear after long hours of talking in class. He is also unable to hold long conversations. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is his possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Phonasthenia is the condition seen in this patient. The clinical scenario of voice overuse and keyhole appearance of glottis point to this diagnosis. Here, both thyroarytenoid and inter arytenoid muscles are involved.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of laryngeal muscles. This leads to a phonatory gap. The shape of the gap depends on the muscle involved:

  • Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space
  • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space
  • Both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid: keyhole appearance

questions.text: A mother brought her 16-year-old daughter to the hospital with the c/o primary amenorrhea. On evaluation, the height is normal, breast development is appropriate for age but axillary, and pubic hairs are sparse. On USG, the testis is found intraabdominal and there is no sign of uterine tissue. The karyotype is 46, XY. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Androgen insensitivity syndrome

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a genetic problem (X Linked Recessive) in which there is a decrease in the function of the androgen receptor.

In this case, gonad is testis with absent uterus.

Presentation Mullarian agenesis  Androgen insensitivity /Testicular feminization syndrome 
Inheritance pattren Sporaidic  X-linked recessive
Karyotype  46, XX 46, XY
Breast development  Yes  Yes
Axillary and pubic hair Yes No
Uterus Absent Absent
Gonad Ovary Testis (Intraabdominal)
Testosterone  Female levels Male levels
Associated anomoly Yes  No

Turners is associated with short stature, uterus present with raised FSH levels.

Hypothalamic failure has normal anatomy of uterus with decreased FSH LH levels.

questions.text: A neonate with vomiting, irritability and progressive lethargy was investigated and was found to be deficient for ornithine permease enzyme. All the below laboratory findings are associated with this disorder, except _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with a deficiency of ornithine permease points towards a diagnosis of HHH syndrome. Hyperargininemia is not a component of this disorder.

Components of HHH syndrome:

  • Hyperammonemia
  • Hyperornithinemia
  • Homocitrullinemia

The given scenario is HHH syndrome, due to a mutation of the gene coding for ornithine permease (ORNT1). This is an autosomal recessive condition. The import of ornithine from the cytosol to the mitochondrial matrix does not occur, which leads to the accumulation of cytosolic ornithine and, consequently, hyperammonemia and hyperornithinemia. 

Since ornithine is not present, mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate converts lysine to homocitrulline, leading to homocitrullinuria. 

Hyperargininemia is an autosomal recessive defect in the gene for arginase. Unlike the case with urea cycle disorders, the first symptoms of hyperargininemia typically do not appear until the age of 2 to 4 years. Blood and cerebrospinal fluid levels of arginine are elevated.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Thickening of stratum spinosum is seen in?
questions.solution:
Thickening of stratum spinosum is seen in acanthosis.

Acanthosis is a term that describes an increase in the number of cells in the Malpighian or prickle cell layer of the epidermis. Acanthosis is observed in:

  • Viral warts
  • Chronic eczema
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Psoriasis
  • Lichen planus

Other options: 

Option A: Acantholysis refers to the loss of connections between keratinocytes, due to the breakdown of intercellular bridges formed by desmosomes. It is seen in Pemphigus and its variants, Darier disease, etc. The site of the acantholysis in Pemphigus foliaceus and Pemphigus erythematosus, is in the upper part of the epidermis, whereas in Pemphigus vulgaris, it is at a lower level in the epidermis.

Option C: Hyperkeratosis is a thickening of the stratum corneum due to the presence of abnormal quantities of keratin. It can be seen in keratodermas.

Option D: A hypertrophic scar is an excessive connective tissue response to injury. There is epidermal thickening with increased fibroblasts and mast cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female G2P1 presents to the antenatal clinic at 19 weeks for a routine check-up. USG shows a normal for gestational age fetus at 19 weeks of gestation in a frank breech position, with no other abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in ​management?
questions.solution:
Reassurance is to be given in the above case because breech at 19 weeks should not be of worry because most of the time it spontaneously rotates and becomes cephalic at term.

Other Options:

  • Option B: According to the recommended screening strategy based on risk assessment for detecting gestational diabetes mellitus, perform blood glucose testing at 24-28 weeks in case of average risk.
  • Options C: As there is time for spontaneous rotation, External Cephalic Version (ECV), is not indicated at 24 weeks.
  • Option D: The Internal Cephalic Version (ICV) is used to deliver a fetus with a persistent transverse or oblique lie in the second stage of labor.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of lower backache. Her bone mineral density is measured and her T-score is found to be -1.8. What does her T-score signify?
questions.solution:
A T-score of -1.8 signifies osteopenia. (T-score in osteopenia: -1 to -2.5).

Osteopenia refers to low bone mass with a T score of -1 to -2.5.

T-score is the comparison of the bone mineral density of a patient to that of a 30-year-old healthy individual.

Osteoporosis is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T-score less than -2.5. 

A T-score of -1 or higher is considered normal.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A child with a history of egg allergy is advised not to take the live attenuated vaccine for influenza by their family doctor as the vaccine was developed by growing the influenza virus in an embryonated egg. Which of the following sites of an embryonated egg is used for the influenza virus vaccine production?
questions.solution:
Allantoic cavity inoculation is used for the growth of the influenza virus for vaccine production.

Embryonated eggs of a duck or a hen are used for the cultivation of several viruses at different sites. These sites are:

  • Chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) (option A) inoculation results in the formation of lesions called pocks. These vary in morphology from one virus to another and each virus particle forms one pock under suitable conditions. Pock counting is employed in the assay of variola or vaccinia.
  • The allantoic cavity can be used to inoculate influenza and some paramyxoviruses. 
  • Inoculation of the amniotic sac (option B) is used for the isolation of the influenza virus.
  • The yolk sac (option C) is inoculated for the cultivation of viruses, chlamydiae, and rickettsiae.

For the production of the influenza vaccine, each strain of virus is grown in the allantoic cavity of the embryonated eggs. The allantoic or amniotic fluids may be harvested to prepare a single harvest after incubation.

Other chick embryo vaccines include those for yellow fever (17D strain) and the non-neural rabies vaccine. (Flury strain)

Related Pearl: Cultivation of viruses

Animal inoculation:

  • Suckling mice are used for inoculation of coxsackie and arbovirus

Tissue culture: Cell lines

  • Primary cell lines- Rhesus kidney cell line, Human amniotic cell line, Chick embryo fibroblast
  • Secondary cell lines- Human fibroblast cell line, MRC-5, and WI- 38
  • Continuous cell lines- HeLa cell line, HEp-2, KB, Vero

Embryonated egg inoculation:

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the modified Duke criteria for a definitive diagnosis of infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis
The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established
Presence of 1 major + 2 minor is definitive endocarditis in clinical criteria

questions.solution:
If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major (or) 1 major + 3 minor (or) 5 minor criteria.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: An infant presented with a lack of tonicity of the abdominal wall along with a wrinkled appearance of the skin as shown in the figure. Further examination reveals the diagnosis to be Eagle Barrett syndrome. Which of the following is not a component of the characteristic triad seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Eagle Barrett Syndrome is also known as Prune Belly Syndrome (Triad Syndrome) and kyphosis is not a component of the characteristic triad seen in this condition

Prune Belly Triad includes:

  • Cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal Wall Defects
  • Genitourinary Defects

Features of Prune Belly Syndrome:

  • Flabby, hypotonic, and thin abdominal wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles
  • Urethral Obstruction in fetal life.
  • Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

  • Posterior urethral valve
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

questions.text: During your casualty postings, a body of a person who committed suicide by hanging was brought to casualty by the police officer.  You notice the mark of ligature knot on the right lateral side of the neck along with the closure of the left eye. Which of the following is most likely finding you would notice in the right eye?
questions.solution:
The right eye remains open with the dilated pupil as the right ligature knot would compresses the cervical sympathetic ganglia in the neck.

Eyes may show the following findings,

  • Le facies sympathique: In case of hanging, one of the eyes may be opened with dilated pupil, while the other eye may be closed. This occurs due to the pressure of the ligature knot on the cervical sympathetic ganglia in the neck. Thus, the side on which the ligature knot presses the cervical sympathetic ganglia, the eye remains open with dilatation of its pupil.
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhages
  • Prominent eyeballs

Other findings:

  • Post-mortem hypostasis - present in the legs and hands.
  • Petechial hemorrhages - these are usually the exception, rather than the rule.
  • Congestion of the face - less commonly seen than a pale face
  • Ligature mark - above the thyroid cartilage and incomplete
  • Soft tissue hemorrhage may be seen.
  • Laryngeal fractures - fractures of hyoid and thyroid may be seen.
  • Amussat sign - damage to intima and media of the carotid artery
  • Simon's sign - hemorrhages on the anterior aspects of intervertebral discs.
  • Dribbling of saliva - Many textbooks of forensic medicine states that the dribbling of saliva is the surest sign of hanging having taken place during life, as the secretion of saliva is a vital function can't occur after death. But, salivation may not occur when the death is due to vagal inhibition or injury to the spinal cord.

questions.text: A patient presented with a skin lesion, which was diagnosed as melanoma invading up to a depth of 0.8 mm. What is the recommended margin for wide local excision in this patient?
questions.solution:
Resection margin of 1 cm is recommended for melanoma invading to a depth of 0.8mm.

Recommended margins of wide local excision:

Thickness Margin
In situ 0.5 cm
<1 mm 1 cm
1-2 mm 1-2 cm
>2-4 mm 2 cm
>4 mm 2 cm

questions.text: A patient with bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy complains of coughing out food particles while eating. Which of the following muscle paralysis is predominantly responsible for the aspiration of food particles resulting in the symptoms in him?
questions.solution:
The muscle which brings about the closing of the laryngeal inlet is aryepiglotticus. Hence, this muscle's paralysis is responsible for the symptoms in this patient.

Some fibres of oblique arytenoids continue laterally into the aryepiglottic fold and form the aryepiglottic muscle.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: A woman presented with complaints of weakness of the right hand. History is significant for a Monteggia fracture-dislocation a few years back. On examination, she is not able to extend her metacarpophalangeal joints but she can extend the wrist joint. There was no sensory loss. Which of the following nerves is injured?
questions.solution:
The most likely nerve injured in this case is the posterior interosseous nerve. The posterior interosseous nerve is a pure motor nerve and hence there is no sensory loss in its injury.

The patient cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joints but wrist extension is preserved as extensor carpi radialis longus is spared. 

The most common nerve injury associated with Monteggia fracture-dislocation is posterior interosseous nerve injury.

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve
Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
Medial condyle of humerus  Ulnar nerve
Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve
Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve
Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve
Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

questions.text: A pharmacologist is conducting a study on non-microsomal phase 2 reactions involved in drug metabolism. His experiments are not likely to include which of the following conjugation reactions?
questions.solution:
All of the above conjugation reactions are catalyzed by non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronide conjugation.

Glucuronide conjugation is the only phase II metabolic reaction that is carried out by microsomal enzymes. 

Drug metabolizing enzymes are primarily of two types:

  1. Microsomal enzymes are located in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum in the liver, kidney, intestinal mucosa, and lungs. They include the cytochrome P450 system, monooxygenases, etc. These enzymes can be induced by drugs and certain nutrients. These enzymes are involved in oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis, and glucuronide conjugation reactions.
  2. Non-microsomal enzymes are located in the cytoplasm and mitochondria of hepatic cells, plasma and other tissues. They include esterases, amidases and most conjugases. These enzymes catalyze all conjugation reactions except glucuronidation. Phase II reactions carried out by non-microsomal enzymes are:
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Methylation
  • Acetylation

Related Pearl: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Hydrolysis
  • Cyclisation
  • Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

  • Glucuronide conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Acetylation
  • Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: A patient with chronic constipation undergoes anorectal manometry. Considering the normal physiological defecation reflex, what should be the rectal pressure at the first urge to defecate and the rectal pressure required for expulsion of the contents respectively?
questions.solution:
The first urge to defecate occurs when rectal pressure is increased to 18 mm Hg. When this pressure reaches 55 mm Hg, the external and the internal sphinc­ter relax, and there is reflex expulsion of the contents of the rectum.

Defecation reflex: Distension of the rectum and colon stimulates stretch receptors in the rectal wall. Then, the defecation reflexes travel from the colon and rectum to the spinal cord and back again to produce the powerful colonic, rectal, and abdominal contractions required for defecation.

questions.text: The finding seen in the given histological image is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows PAS-positive inclusions called as Russell bodies which are immunoglobulin filled RER in the cytoplasm. It is seen both in lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma and multiple myeloma.

When the same inclusions are present in the nucleus it is called as Dutcher bodies.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and regional lymphadenopathy, following a scratch from his pet kitten. His lymph node biopsy specimen was examined with Warthin-Starry staining; the findings are shown in the given image. What is the causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever and lymphadenopathy after a cat scratch and the above image shows the black short rod-shaped bacilli arranged in chains or clumps, suggestive of cat scratch disease, This condition is caused by Bartonella henselae.

Cat scratch disease presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch. Patients present with a painless papule or pustule at the site of the scratch and lymph node enlargement and can be suppurative. The disease is usually self resolving. However, it can be treated with azithromycin only in patients who have severe complications.

questions.text: A small scale dairy owner follows a pasteurization technique of heating the milk at 63°C for 30 minutes. Which of the following disease can be caused in his customers by the organism that can survive this method of pasteurization?
questions.solution:
The pasteurization technique described in the above question is of the Holder method and Coxiella burnetti survive this method of pasteurization. It is the causative agent of Q fever.

Pasteurization can be done by heating the Milk  at either 

  • 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or
  • 72°C for 15–20 seconds: the flash process

Once heated appropriately, the milk is cooled quickly to 13°C or lower. 

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in the Holder method.

Other options :

  • Trench fever is caused by Bartonella quintana.
  • Enteric fever includes typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi and paratyphoid fever caused by Salmonella paratyphi A, B and C.
  • Oroya fever is caused by Bartonella bacilliformis.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of ascites when the serum ascites-to-albumin gradient (SAAG ) is 1.5g/dl and the ascitic protein level is 3g/dl?
questions.solution:
The cause of ascites when the serum ascites-to-albumin gradient (SAAG) is 1.5g/dl and the ascitic protein level is 3g/dl is Constrictive pericarditis.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG):

  • Calculated by subtracting the ascitic albumin concentration from the serum albumin level.
  • Reflects the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids
  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

Ascitic protein level:

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing passage of protein into the ascites. eg. cardiac ascites
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. cirrhosis

The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is the most reli­able method to differentiate causes of ascites due to portal hyper­tension from those not due to portal hypertension.

questions.text: After a meal, the plasma levels of insulin has peaked in a person. Which of the following glucose transporters would facilitate the uptake of glucose by the skeletal muscles mediated by insulin?
questions.solution:
The glucose transporter that would facilitate the uptake of glucose by the skeletal muscles mediated by insulin is GLUT-4.

Normally, a pool of GLUT-4 molecules is maintained within vesicles in the cytoplasm of the insulin-sensitive cells. When the insulin receptors in them are stimulated, the vesicles move rapidly and fuse themselves to the cell membrane and facilitate the transport of glucose molecules into the cells.

This GLUT-4 receptor is also present in cardiac muscle and adispose tissues.

Related Pearl: Glucose Transporters

Secondary active transport

(Na + -glucose cotransport)

    

SGLT 1

Absorption of glucose

Small intestine, renal tubules

SGLT 2

Absorption of glucose

Renal tubules

Facilitated diffusion

    

GLUT 1

Basal glucose uptake

Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs

GLUT 2

β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells

β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys

GLUT 3

Basal glucose uptake

Brain, placenta, kidneys, many other organs

GLUT 4

Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues

GLUT 5

Jejunum, sperm

GLUT 6

GLUT 7 Glucose-6-phosphate transporter in the endoplasmic reticulum Liver

questions.text: A 60 year-old-woman comes with complaints of sudden onset blindness of the right eye, with throbbing headache in the right temporal region associated with jaw claudication. On examination, a thickened cord-like structure can be felt in the temple. Temporal artery biopsy demonstrates giant cells. Identify the false statement about this disease.

choices.text: A negative biopsy excludes the diagnosis
The classic lesions are medial granulomas
Fragmentation is seen in internal elastic lamina

questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from Giant cell arteritis. A negative biopsy cannot exclude the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis.

Giant cell arteritis is an inflammatory vasculitis of large vessels. It usually involves the temporal artery.

Common clinical features associated with giant cell arteritis are:

  • It is commonly seen in females over 50 years of age.
  • It is characterized by fever, anemia, and headache.
  • Depending on the artery involved, the patient may have tenderness over the affected artery, scalp pain, jaw, and tongue claudication.
  • Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR, normochromic normocytic anemia.
  • Untreated patients may develop ischemic optic neuropathy.
  • Good response to glucocorticoid therapy.

The lesions are focally distributed leaving long segments of the artery normal. Hence, the biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery leading to a false-negative report. For the same reason, adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.

Biopsy findings: Giant cell arteritis is primarily medial granulomatous inflammation.

  • These lesions involve the internal elastic lamina leading to elastic lamina fragmentation.
  • There is intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter.
  • Granulomas with multinucleated giant cells, infiltrate of T cells (CD4+> CD8+), and macrophages.

Image: Giant-cell arteritis with intimal thickening and internal elastic lamina fragmentation.

questions.text: A patient with a history of sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker 3 days back has developed genital discharge resembling 'flow of seed' as shown below. What medium should be used for the culture of the discharge?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of gonococcal urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Thayer-Martin and modified Thayer-Martin media are used for the culture of this organism. Gonorrhoea may manifest as mucopurulent genital discharge which can be described as resembling 'flow of seed' (semen).

Thayer-Martin medium contains vancomycin, colistin and nystatin.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by N. gonorrhea. The major symptoms include urethritis, vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria. In the laboratory diagnosis of N. gonorrhea, the discharge on Gram's stain reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. It acidifies glucose but not maltose in serum sugars. Stuart's medium is used for transport while Thayer-Martin agar is used as a selective medium used to isolate N. gonorrhoeae. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. 

Stuart’s medium is the transport media used for Neisseria gonorrhea and Neisseria meningitides. It is a semisolid, non-nutrient medium. Charcoal present in the medium neutralizes certain bacterial inhibitors while a reducing agent prevents oxidation.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria:

salt milk agar

questions.text: Feedforward inhibition is seen in ________
questions.solution:
Feedforward inhibition is seen in the cerebellum. In the cerebellum, stimulation of basket cells / stellate cells produces IPSPs in the Purkinje cells (i.e, inhibits Purkinje cells)

In feedforward inhibition, a presynaptic cell excites an inhibitory interneuron which then inhibits the next follower cell.

In cerebellum (Refer flow chart):

This arrangement is called feed-forward inhibition which presumably limits the duration of excitation produced by any given afferent volley.

Note: Renshaw cell carries out the negative feedback inhibition of a spinal motor neuron.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida who was admitted to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation was planned for induction of labor using the device shown below. Which of the following medications is present in this device?
questions.solution:
The obstetric device shown in the above image is of cervidil vaginal insert. It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone.

A cervidil vaginal insert is a thin, flat, rectangular polymeric wafer held within a small, white mesh polyester sac. It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone (PGE2) released at a rate of 0.3 mg/hour. The sac has a long attached tail to allow easy removal from the vagina.

Following insertion, the woman should remain recumbent for at least 2 hours. The insert is removed after 12 hours or with labor onset and at least 30 minutes before the administration of oxytocin.

It is used for cervical ripening prior to induction. A possible side effect of dinoprostone is uterine tachysystole.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text:
A postgraduate student, while assisting an emergency trauma surgery on an HIV-infected patient, has suffered a bleeding puncture wound in his right index finger. The post-exposure prophylaxis is given for 4 weeks. Match the drug with their daily dosages?
A. Lamivudine 1. 50mg
B. Tenofovir 2. 100mg
C. Dolutegravir 3. 300mg
questions.solution:
Recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes lamivudine 300mg , tenofovir 300mg and dolutegravir 50mg. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.

Most common cause of HIV in a healthcare worker is due to needle stick injuries. Exposure to needle stick injuries can be prevented by:

  • Using barriers (goggles, gloves,) during performing procedures that cause exposure to blood/ body fluids
  • Hand washing and routine disinfection of surfaces.
  • Careful handling and disposing of sharps and needles after use.

The protocol followed after exposure is: Exposure within the past 72 hours --> Assess exposed individual --> Assess exposure source --> Determine the risk of transmission --> Counselling and support --> 4 weeks prescription with drug information --> routine HIV antibody testing upto 6 months after exposure.

Related Pearl: 2021 NACO Guidelines on Post-exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV

Exposure Code

HIV Source Code

          PEP Recommendation

1

 1

 Not required

1

 2

 Recommended

2

 1

 Recommended

2

 2

 Recommended

3

 1/2

 Recommended

2/3

Not known

Consider PEP if HIV prevalence is high in the given population

Exposure Codes

  • EC1: Mild exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with small volumes/eyes or mucous membrane or subcutaneous injections following small-bore needles
  • EC2: Moderate exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with large volumes or percutaneous superficial exposure with a solid needle
  • EC3: Severe exposure: percutaneous with large volume by hollow needle, deep puncture

HIV Source Codes

  • SC 1- HIV +ve, asymptomatic, CD count high, low viral load
  • SC 2- HIV +ve, symptomatic, CD count low, high viral load
  • SC unknown: HIV status unknown

Recommended PEP regimens

1) Adolescents and Adults (>10 years of age and >30 kg weight): Tenofovir 300 mg + Lamivudine 300 mg + Dolutegravir 50 mg

2) Children (>6 years of age and >20 kg weight): Zidovudine (dosage as per weight band) + Lamivudine (dosage as per weight band) + Dolutegravir 50 mg

  • PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.
  • Duration of PEP: 28 days/4weeks

 

Related Pearl: WHO 2018 guidelines for post exposure prophylaxis regimen in HIV

An HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred.

The recent MOHFW January 2020 guidelines on the management of PEP in HIV recommends the replacement of 2 drug regimen with 3 drug regimen referring to WHO December 2018 guidelines on PEP management protocol in HIV. This shift towards recommending a three-drug regimen for
everyone was based on the availability of less toxic and better-tolerated medications.

ADULTS AND ADOLESCENTS:-

Preferred backbone regimen - TDF + 3TC (or FTC)

New drug -  DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

CHILDREN:-

Preferred backbone regimen - AZT + 3TC

ABC + 3TC or TDF + 3TC (or FTC) can be considered as alternative regimens

New drug - DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Legend

TDF - Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate 

3TC - Lamivudine 

FTC - Emtricitabine 

DTG - Dolutegravir 

ATV/r - Atazanavir + ritonavir 

DRV/r - Darunavir + ritonavir 

LPV/r - Lopinavir + ritonavir 

RAL - Raltegravir 

AZT - Zidovudine 

ABC - Abacavir

questions.text: Patients with which of the following findings would be classified as having stage 2 renal cell carcinoma?

choices.text: A tumour mass limited to kidney ( >7cm) with no nodal metastasis
A tumour mass limited to kidney ( >7cm) with only regional lymph node metastasis
A tumour mass limited to kidney ( <7cm) with no nodal metastasis
A tumour mass limited to kidney ( <7cm) with only regional lymph node metastasis

questions.solution:
A tumour mass limited to the kidney ( >7cm) with no nodal metastasis would be classified as having stage 2 renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

Stage 2 of renal cell carcinoma is characterized by T2 N0 M0.

Stage groupings of RCC:

  • Stage I: T1 N0 M0
  • Stage II: T2 N0 M0
  • Stage III: T1 or T2 N1 M0, T3 N0 or N1 M0
  • Stage IV: T4 Any N M0

TNM staging for renal cell carcinoma:

T: Primary tumour

T1: Limited to the kidney, <7 cm

  • T1a: Tumor confined to the kidney,<4 cm
  • T1b: Tumor confined to the kidney, >4 cm, but <7 cm

T2: Limited to the kidney, >7 cm

  • T2a: Tumor confined to the kidney, >7 cm but < 10 cm
  • T2b: Tumor confined to the kidney, >10 cm

T3: Tumor extension into major veins or perinephric tissues, but not into the ipsilateral adrenal gland or beyond Gerota's fascia

  • T3a: Tumor grossly extends into the renal vein or its segmental (muscle-containing) branches, or tumor invades perirenal and/or renal sinus fat but not beyond Gerota's fascia
  • T3b: Spread to infra-diaphragmatic IVC
  • T3c: Spread to supra-diaphragmatic IVC or invades the wall of the IVC
T4: Involves ipsilateral adrenal gland or invades beyond Gerota's fascia
N: Regional Lymph Nodes
  • N0: No nodal involvement
  • N1: Metastatic involvement of regional lymph node(s)
M: Metastasis
  • M0: No distant metastases
  • M1: Distant metastases

questions.text: A pathology student comes to you for advice regarding the disposal of a contaminated broken glass slide. Which of the following containers would you advise her to use?
questions.solution:
Broken or discarded and contaminated glass should be disposed of in blue containers.

All broken or contaminated glass, including medicine vials and ampoules, should be disposed of in blue containers, except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with cystic neck swelling as shown in the image. On examination, the swelling moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. Which of the following malignancies may develop from this, if the swelling remains untreated?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is a thyroglossal cyst. The most common cancer arising from a thyroglossal cyst is papillary carcinoma.

Though the most common complication of thyroglossal cyst is an infection, 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant, with the most common type of cancer being papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts.

Management:

  • Sistrunk operation (en bloc cystectomy with excision of the central hyoid bone) is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal duct cysts. 
  • To minimize the recurrence of the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid is excised in addition to complete cyst excision including the entire tract.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who is a chronic smoker was admitted to the hospital for  COPD and was prescribed with a very long-acting beta 2 receptor agonist.  Which of the following drug was prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Olodaterol is classified as a very long-acting beta 2 receptor agonist and can be used once daily in COPD maintenance.

Salmeterol and formoterol are long-acting beta 2 agonist and is usually administered twice daily (options a and b).

Salbutamol is a short-acting beta-agonist (option c).

Very long-acting beta-agonists (VLABAs).

  • Indacaterol
  • Olodaterol
  • Vilanterol

questions.text: Which of the following subunits of troponin has a strong affinity for actin?
questions.solution:
The troponin I subunit has a strong affinity for the actin filament.

The troponin molecules are attached intermittently along the sides of the tropomyosin molecule. They have three loosely bound protein subunits, each of which has a specific role in controlling the muscle contraction

  • Troponin I - It binds to the actin
  • Troponin T - It binds to the tropomyosin
  • Troponin C - It binds the calcium ions

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has perfectly normal cycles every month since her puberty. Which of the following pattern of hormones is expected in the proliferative phase, around the time of ovulation, and in the luteal phase respectively?

choices.text: High progesterone, high FSH, high estradiol
Increasing estradiol, high FSH, low inhibin A
Increasing FSH, LH surge, low estradiol
Increasing estradiol, high FSH, high inhibin A

questions.solution:
The pattern of hormones that are expected in a normal menstrual cycle is increasing estradiol in the proliferative phase, FSH surge around the time of ovulation, and high inhibin A levels in the luteal phase.

Hormone Proliferative/follicular phase

Around the time of ovulation

 Luteal/secretory phase
Estradiol

The estrogen levels tend to increase progressively in the proliferative phase

 

 36 to 48 hours before the ovulation, it reaches a maximal concentration to cause LH surge

Due to the production from the corpus luteum, the estradiol levels are higher in the initial to mid-luteal phase.

Once the corpus luteum starts involuting, their levels fall.
Progesterone very low low Due to the production from corpus luteum, their levels reach a maximal concentration
FSH Due to the secretion from the anterior pituitary, the FSH levels increase moderately. This causes the growth and development of the follicles The FSH levels also increase at the time of ovulation about twofold to threefold from the baseline Under the strong inhibitory effects of the estrogen secreted from corpus luteum, their levels tend to be lower
LH The levels of LH increase only minimally by secretion from the anterior pituitary Due to the positive feedback by estrogen, the levels of LH surge to the highest possible levels. This is very essential for the ovulation to happen Similar to LH, once its function of luteinizing is complete, their levels start decreasing
Inhibin A Low Increased Inhibin A is also secreted from the corpus luteum and hence increased
Inhibin B

During the earlier days of the follicular phase inhibit B levels are low.

After this, when the follicles mature, the granulosa cells secrete inhibit B, increasing their levels. 

 There is a postovulatory peak  Decreased

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents with a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition and does not move with protrusion of the tongue. The biopsy of the frozen section is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the given histopathological image showing uniform sheets of cells with capsular invasion by tumor cells is suggestive of follicular carcinoma thyroid.

The following images show follicular carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option A: In follicular adenoma, there is no capsular invasion.

Option C: Anaplastic carcinoma is associated with rapidly progressive swelling with obstructive features and undifferentiated cells on histopathology.

Option D: In medullary carcinoma, amyloid stroma is seen on histopathology.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: The ophthalmological examination findings of a 40-year-old male patient who is on antiglaucoma treatment is as shown below. Which of the following drugs is likely to be associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
The ophthalmological examination shows a pearly white opacity of the lens indicative of cataract. Anticholinesterase agents like echothiophate and cholinergic agonists like pilocarpine are known to be associated with cataract formation.

Other options:

Options A: Specific side effects of apraclonidine are an allergy (conjunctival hyperemia), dry mouth, and sleepiness.

Options C: Specific side effects of brimonidine are an allergy (conjunctival hyperemia), dry mouth, sleepiness, and also causes respiratory depression in young children.

Option D: Specific side effects of timolol are exacerbation of respiratory problems like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bradycardia, depression, impotence.

Related Pearl: Important adverse effects of anti-glaucoma drugs

Corneal hypoesthesia

Lid retraction

CNS depression and apnea in infants and children (<2 years)

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle belongs to Trypanosoma cruzi.

T. cruzi is the causative organism of Chagas disease or South American trypanosomiasis. They are intracellular parasites. It passes its life cycle in two hosts- the definitive host is the man, and the intermediate host (vector) is a reduviid bug or triatomine bugs.

Metacyclic trypomastigotes are the infective forms to the man that are found in feces of reduviid bugs. Transmission occurs when mucus membranes, conjunctiva, or wounds on the surface of the skin are contaminated by feces of the bug.

Inside the definitive host, the trypomastigotes differentiate into intracellular amastigotes. The amastigotes multiply by binary fission and differentiate into trypomastigotes, which are then released into the bloodstream. These are the infective stages for the triatomine bug. No multiplication occurs in this stage. Inside the triatomine bug, the trypomastigotes are transformed into epimastigotes and then into metacyclic trypomastigotes in the hindgu,t which are excreted in feces.

Note: Amastigote forms resemble the Leishmania species; hence, they are frequently known as Leishmanial forms. They are found in muscular tissue, nervous tissue, andthe  reticuloendothelial system.

questions.text: All of the following are effective in the management of patients with ventricular tachycardia except:
questions.solution:
Carotid sinus massage will be effective only in supraventricular tachycardias but not in ventricular tachycardias. This is because it acts by increasing the AV node block which does not play any role in the pathogenesis of ventricular tachycardia.

Hence, AV node blocking maneuvers (carotid sinus massage, valsalva) and drugs (adenosine) are not used in the management of VT.

questions.text: Starling's law implies:

choices.text: Increased heart rate leads to increased cardiac output
Increased discharge leads to increased cardiac output
Increased venous return leads to increased cardiac output
Increased blood pressure leads to increased cardiac output

questions.solution:
Starling's law implies increased venous return leads to increased cardiac output.

Frank-Starling law: The energy of contraction is proportional to the initial length of the cardiac muscle fiber.
The length of the muscle fibers is proportional to the end-diastolic volume, which is determined by venous return.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the management of endometriosis?

choices.text: Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy
Asymptomatic patients are observed over 6–8 months without any need of the infertility workup
Estrogen is the drug of choice for endometriosis
Not all symptomatic women need treatment

questions.solution:
Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy. This is the only true statement.

Endometriosis is estrogen-dependent. Hence estrogen is not used in treatment.

Minimal asymptomatic cases are to be observed over 6–8 months and infertility in such cases should be investigated and treated if necessary.

All symptomatic women do need treatment.

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease
DOC = NSAIDS DOC=GnRH agonist
OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analog
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterone

Surgical management

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oopherectomy.

 Note:

  • Endometrioma is treated by laparoscopic management.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the pediatric OPD by his parents with complaints of excessive sleepiness, and poor scholastic performance. On examination, the child has pallor involving the tongue, conjunctiva, and nail beds. A flow murmur is heard upon auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the underlying disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical signs and symptoms are suggestive of anemia. Acquired hypoproliferative anemia, is the most common cause of anemia in children among the given options.

Iron-deficiency anemia (which is classified as an acquired hypoproliferative anemia) is the most common cause of anemia in children and adults worldwide. Iron deficiency is also the most common nutrient deficiency worldwide.

questions.text: Analysis expressing results of health care benefits in terms of results achieved, like the number of lives saved, instead of monetary benefit is called ______________
questions.solution:
Cost-effective analysis: The benefits of the health care system are expressed in terms of results achieved (Eg: the number of lives saved or the number of days free from disease). This is a more promising tool in the health field than cost-benefit analysis. But in many cases, it is not possible to use cost-effective analysis.

Other options:

Cost-benefit analysis: Here the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to identify whether it is economically sound and to select the best one from several alternate programs. The main drawback of this technique is that the benefits of a particular program in the health field cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. Usually, the benefits are expressed in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.

Input-output analysis: How much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, the term "input" refers to all health-related activities which consume resources, and "output" refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated or lives saved.

Network analysis: A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities that should be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Management Methods in Health Programmes:

Methods based on behavioral sciences

Quantitative methods

Organizational design

Personnel management

Communication

Information systems

Management by objectives(MBO)

Cost–Benefit analysis

Cost-Effective analysis

Cost–Accounting

Input–Output analysis

Model

Systems analysis

Network analysis- Includes Programme Evaluation and Review Technique(PERT) and Critical Path Method(CPM)

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)

Work sampling

Decision making

questions.text: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought unconscious to the emergency ward. In order to rule out hypothermia, how will you best measure his temperature?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the rectal temperature would be the best site to measure the core body temperature.

At extremes of high or low temperatures, like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures are highly misleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperature.

The infrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum which is representative of the core body temperature. However, it often ends up measuring the temperature of the ear canal. This is because of inadequate insertion into the ear canal due to poor manufacturing design or the presence of cerumen. Hence, it is not a reliable method of measuring the core body temperature.

questions.text: A biochemist performed electrophoresis on lipoproteins during a study and the result obtained is shown below. The marked lipoprotein which has moved nearest to the anode is likely to be ______.
questions.solution:
On electrophoresis, HDL moves farthest on the electrophoretic plate towards the anode.

HDL has the highest electrophoretic mobility and the least percentage of lipid content. HDL particles are the densest with a high protein-to-lipid ratio. 

Chylomicron is the largest lipoprotein and has the most amount of triglycerides. Chylomicron particles have the lowest density and the largest size. They contain the highest percentage of lipids and the lowest percentage of protein.

The density of various lipoproteins and their electrophoretic mobility are shown in the images below:

Source

Action

Carry exogenous/dietary triacylglycerol from the intestine to peripheral organs

Very low density lipoproteins (VLDL)

Derived from the liver

Carry endogenous triacylglycerol from the liver to peripheral organs

Low-density lipoproteins (LDL)

Derived from VLDL

Involved in cholesterol transport

Highdensity lipoproteins (HDL)

Derived from Liver, intestine, VLDL, chylomicrons

Involved in reverse cholesterol & Phospholipids transport and also in VLDL and chylomicron metabolism

Intermediate density lipoproteins(IDL)

questions.text: A female patient presents with fever, odynophagia, and trismus. Her oral cavity examination appears as shown in the image given below. She was diagnosed with a peritonsillar abscess. Where does the pus usually get collected in this condition?

choices.text: Between the alar fascia and the prevertebral fascia
Between the capsule of tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle
Between the alar fascia and the superior constrictor muscle
Between the capsule of tonsil and the inferior constrictor muscle

questions.solution:
The site of collection of pus in quinsy/ peritonsillar abscess is between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle.

Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle. It usually follows an episode of acute tonsillitis when the crypta magna gets infected and gets sealed off. An intratonsillar abscess then forms which then bursts through the capsule to reach the peritonsillar space.

The illustration given below shows structures forming a tonsillar bed.

It presents with marked odynophagia such that the patient cannot even swallow his saliva which dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated. Other features include a muffled and thick speech, often called a hot potato voice, sore throat, ipsilateral otalgia, torticollis, and fever.

On examination, the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate are congested and enlarged. The uvula is congested and edematous and pushed to the opposite side. Mucopus covering the tonsil is seen. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

CECT, submandibular ultrasonography, and MRI are better suited for visualizing the abscess and its extent. Submandibular ultrasonography is also helpful for incision and drainage.

Management of peritonsillar abscess:

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to address dehydration
  • High-dose intravenous antibiotics to cover aerobes and anaerobes
  • Analgesics for pain relief
  • Drainage by needle aspiration or incision and drainage
  • Tonsillectomy when there is airway obstruction or recurrence.

Incision and drainage of the abscess at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

The image given below shows the site of the incision in the peritonsillar abscess.

questions.text: A patient is a known case of cervical cancer.  Which of the following factors is not an indication for a hysterectomy to be the treatment of choice in this patient?

choices.text: The uterus is associated with fibroid, DUB, prolapsed

questions.solution:
Conization is the treatment of choice when microinvasion is suspected and Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice when microinvasion is confirmed

 

  • Indications of conization:
    • Endocervical dysplasia
    • The transformation zone is not completely visualized
    • When there is discrepancy of findings between cytology, colposcopy and biopsy
    • Microinvasion is suspected
  • Indications of hysterectomy:
    • Older and parous women
    • Uterus is suspected with fibroid, DUB, prolapsed
    • Microinvasion exists
    • Recurrence or persistent lesion
    • In – situ adenocarcinoma cervix

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presents with shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips. Chest X-ray shows a boot-shaped heart due to an upturned cardiac apex. The finding seen on the chest X-ray is due to:
questions.solution:
The clinical description of shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips, along with boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, suggests tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The findings of a boot-shaped heart due to the upturned cardiac apex is due to right ventricular hypertrophy.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart condition. The four cardinal features of the tetralogy of Fallot are as follows:

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract (subpulmonary stenosis)
  • An aorta that overrides the ventricular septum
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

The image given below shows cardinal features seen in TOF:

 

Children with TOF usually present with dyspnea on exertion, they characteristically assume a squatting position for relief of dyspnea. During anoxic spells, children start crying, become dyspneic and cyanotic, and may eventually lose consciousness. 

A chest x-ray of a child with TOF typically shows a boot-shaped heart due to the upturned cardiac apex. This is mainly because of right ventricular hypertrophy. Other chest x-ray features in tetralogy of Fallot are:

  • Pulmonary oligaemia (due to pulmonary stenosis)
  • Normal size heart (heart failure is not a feature in TOF)
  • Right-sided aortic arch (25%)

Medical management with oral propranolol prevents cyanotic spells, surgical correction is the definitive treatment of choice. The intravenous administration of prostaglandin E1 can be tried to keep ductus arteriosus open while awaiting surgery.

Given below is a chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped heart (cœur en sabot in French).

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties. The following finding was noted on examination. Genetic testing revealed a dystrophin gene mutation. On which chromosome is the affected gene located?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image showing pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles are highly suggestive of Duchenne's muscular dystrophy. It is an X-linked recessive condition. 

Duchenne's and Becker's muscular dystrophy are caused by loss-of-function mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome. It is one of the largest human genes. Dystrophin provides mechanical stability to the myofiber during muscle contraction. Defects in the complex may lead to small membrane tears that permit the influx of calcium, triggering events that result in myofiber degeneration.

Duchenne's muscular dystrophy is associated with deletions or frame-shift mutations that result in the total absence of dystrophin. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show the absence of the normal sarcolemmal staining pattern.

In contrast, the mutations in Becker's muscular dystrophy typically permit the synthesis of a truncated version of dystrophin, which retains some function. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show reduced staining.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came to the hospital with a history of palpitations and chest pain.ECG of the patient was suggestive of atrial fibrillation. The direct oral factor Xa inhibitor drug was used to prevent stroke in this patient. Identify this drug?
questions.solution:
Rivaroxaban is a direct oral factor Xa inhibitor that is used for stroke prevention in patients with atrial fibrillation. 

Direct factor Xa inhibitors inhibit both the free and clot-associated factor Xa and thus prevent thrombin formation. This in turn suppresses platelet aggregation and fibrin formation. It includes drugs like rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban. These drugs are administered via the oral route. 

Just like other anticoagulants, the major adverse effect is bleeding. Andexanet alfa is recombinant factor Xa used in cases of severe bleeding associated with these drugs as a reversal agent. These drugs are also substrates of the P-glycoprotein pump (Pgp). Inducers or inhibitors of Pgp can thus alter the drug levels of these agents.

Apart from stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, direct Xa inhibitors are also used in the treatment of acute deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. Rivaroxaban and apixaban are indicated for post-operative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing orthopedic surgery. Low-dose rivaroxaban combined with aspirin is required in cases of coronary or peripheral vascular disease to prevent major cardiac or limb adverse effects.

The need to initiate oral anticoagulation for stroke prevention is based on the CHA2DS2VASc score. It includes risk factors like congenital heart disease, age >75, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, prior stroke, vascular disease, age > 65, and sex category (females). Each of these parameters carries a score of 1 except for prior stroke and age>75 which carries a score of 2. Anticoagulation can be started if the score > 1 unless the female gender is the only risk factor.

Other options:

Options A & C: Bivalirudin, argatroban, and desirudin are parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors.

Option D: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor and can also be used for stroke prevention. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: An orthopedic surgeon was a bit apprehensive in giving a medicolegal opinion to a male patient who had met with a road traffic accident. The following image shows the x-ray of his left ankle. He finally concluded the finding in x-ray to be a normal variant, as the patient and felt reassured by the fact that he had a similar finding on the other ankle as well. Which of the following terminology suits well to describe this normal variant?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bony projection behind the talus suggestive of os trigonum, and this is called a supernumerary bone.

Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken for fractures. However, these bones maybe bilateral and have smooth surfaces without any callus

Examples of accessory bones:

  • Os trigonum:  Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as the lateral tubercle of the talus.
  • Os vesalianum: Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found within the peroneus brevis tendon. Also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal.

questions.text: A medical student is asked to examine a patient, and his X-rays and interpret the spinal curvatures. Which of the following has he wrongly interpreted given that patient has no abnormality?
questions.solution:
The cervical part of the vertebral column normally demonstrates lordosis(convex forwards).

  • During embryonic life, the body appears flexed and has 2 primary spinal curvatures. These are the thoracic and the pelvic curves, which are convex dorsally.
  • After birth, functional muscle development leads to the early appearance of secondary spinal curvatures. These are the cervical and the lumbar curves, both of which are convex forwards (lordosis).

Normal adult curvatures of the vertebral column are as follows: 

  • The cervical curve is lordosis (convex forwards)
  • The thoracic curve is kyphosis (convex dorsally)
  • The lumbar curve is lordosis (convex forwards)
  • The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 1.9 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a circumvallate placenta. The membranes at the periphery are thickened and consist of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

Normally, the chorionic plate and basal plates are of the same size. In conditions of extrachorial placentation, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:

  • Circummarginate placenta -  In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage. 
  • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are:
    • Preterm delivery
    • Abortions
    • IUGR
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Retained placenta and membranes

Option A: Placenta succenturiata has one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins.

Options B & D: Placenta marginata or circummarginate placenta - a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female with complete facial palsy following a head injury needs workup. If you were to advise Electroneuronography for this patient, it will be most useful when it is performed ____________

choices.text: Immediately following the onset of complete paralysis
Within 2 days of the onset of complete paralysis
Between 4-21 days since the onset of complete paralysis

questions.solution:
Electroneuronography performed between 4-21 days following injury gives the most useful information.

Electroneuronography: In this test, stimulation of the facial nerve is done at the stylomastoid foramen and the surface electrodes pick up the compound muscle action potentials. The responses of action potentials in the paralyzed side and the normal side on similar stimulation are compared using which the percentage of degenerating fibers is calculated. Studies reveal that degeneration of 90% occurring in the first 2 weeks indicates a poor prognosis for recovery of function.

This test is most useful between 4 and 21 days of the onset of complete paralysis.

questions.text: A researcher is studying DNA replication in human pluripotent stem cells. Which of the following DNA polymerases is involved in leading strand synthesis?
questions.solution:
DNA Polymerase epsilon is involved in leading strand synthesis.
