questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found to have colonic cancer on routine colonoscopy and biopsy. His father had developed a similar colonic cancer and died at the age of 40. His family history is remarkable for endometrial and urothelial cancer. There is no history of familial adenomatous polyposis. Abnormality in which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is responsible for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Regulated genomic instability in lymphoid cells

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome/Hereditary non-polyposis colonic cancer (HNPCC). HNPCC results from a defect in the DNA mismatch repair system.

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant disorder that leads to the development of carcinoma in the cecum and proximal colon. One defective copy of the gene is inherited while the other gene undergoes a loss of function mutation.  

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function is lost leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome and microsatellite instability. A microsatellite is a sequence of 1-6 nucleotides found repeated throughout the genome. They are found in normal individuals at a constant length. In patients with DNA mismatch repair, these lengths are variable leading to mutated alleles. 

Other options: 

Option A: Patients with regulated genomic instability in lymphoid cells develop T and B cell neoplasia. 

Option C: Patients with a defect in the nucleotide excision repair pathway develop xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option D: Patients with defects in the homologous recombination DNA repair system may develop Bloom syndrome, ataxia-telangiectasia, and Fanconi anemia.

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: All of the following features are against the  diagnosis of Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) except _____

choices.text: Appearance for first time in old age
Onset of symptoms with stress or emotional upset

questions.solution:
The onset of symptoms in response to stress is a feature of IBS.

Features which argue against the diagnosis of IBS

  • First time in old age
  • Progressive course
  • Persistent diarrhoea after a 48 hour fast
  • Presence of nocturnal diarrhoea
  • Steatorrheal stools

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with growth retardation and a history of recurrent attacks of hypoglycemia. On examination, you notice doll-like facies with relatively thin extremities and massive hepatomegaly. Blood examination reveals increased lactic acid, triglyceride, and uric acid levels. All of the following complications can be expected in this child except:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this clinical scenario is von Gierke’s disease. Cardiomyopathy is not a complication of von Gierke’s disease. On the contrary, cardiomyopathy is associated with Pompe's disease.

Enzyme deficient in von Gierke’s disease is glucose-6-phosphatase (common to both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis). Inheritance is autosomal recessive. 

Glycogen accumulation occurs in the liver and renal tubular cells. Clinical features include:

  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Ketosis
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperuricemia

A definitive diagnosis is made using a liver biopsy. Fructose and galactose restriction in the diet is advised.

Complications of von Gierke's disease includes polycystic ovaries, osteopenia, hepatic adenoma, pulmonary hypertension, pancreatitis and renal failure.

questions.text: A diabetic man presented with vomiting, abdominal pain, and polyuria. He gives a history of missing 2 doses of insulin since morning. He is hypotensive and tachycardic and his breath has a fruity odour. Blood glucose was 350 mg/dL. Which test, done here will give a positive result?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis in which rothera’s test will give positive results due to the presence of ketone bodies in urine. 

Rothera’s test by nitroprusside reagent is a specific test used to detect whether acetone or acetoacetate is present in the given sample of urine. A purple ring at the junction of two liquids indicates a positive test.

Note: Rothera's test does not detect β-hydroxybutyrate. 

Other options:

Option A: Hay's test is used to test for bile salts.

Option B: Fouchet's test is used to test for bilirubin.

Option C: Ninhydrin test is used to test for alpha-amino acids.

questions.text: A senior resident uses Diene’s stain to stain the micro-organisms which appear as shown below. This characteristic appearance is shown by which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
Diene's method of staining is used for diagnosis of mycoplasma. It is also known as Eaton agent since Eaton was the first person to isolate Mycoplasma pneumoniae. 

The colony is typically biphasic, with a fried egg appearance, consisting of a central opaque granular area of growth extending into the depth of the medium, surrounded by a flat, translucent peripheral zone. 

Mycoplasma colonies can be studies either with a hand or after staining with Diene's method. For Diene's method, a block of agar containing the colony is cut and placed on a slide. It is covered with a cover slip on which an alcoholic solution of methylene blue and azure has been dried. 

Mycoplasma are the smallest free-living microorganisms and they can be grown in a cell-free medium. They lack a cell wall and are higly pleomorphic. They occur as granules and filaments of various sizes. They were previously called pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) since they were thought to cause pleuropneumonia in many animals and humans.

The species of mycoplasma causing human infections are:

  • M.pneumoniae causing pneumonia
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum causing non-gonococcal urethritis
  • M.hominis and M.gentalium causing genital tract infections.

 

Related Pearl: Common names of various bacteria

List of common names and scientific names of medically important bacteria:

Common name Scientific name
Klebs-Loffler bacillus Corynebacterium diphtheria
Koch week bacillus Haemophilus aegypticus
Tubercle or Koch bacillus Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Hansen’s bacillus Mycobacterium leprae
Eaton agent Mycoplasma pneumonia
Pfeiffer’s bacillus Haemophilus influenza
Friedlander’s bacillus Klebsiella pneumoniae
Glander’s Bacillus Burkholderia mallei
Whitmore Bacillus Burkholderia pseudomallei

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with amnesia. Which of the following will not be impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Name of pet bird growing up

questions.solution:
The ability to drive a bicycle is not impaired in this patient.

The ability to drive a bicycle is a non-declarative memory and this type of memory is preserved in amnesia.

Non-declarative memory includes:

  • Skill learning
  • Habit learning
  • Simple forms of conditioning

Declarative memory supports the conscious recollection of facts and events. For example:

  • Memory for routes, lists, faces, melodies, objects
  • Memory for other verbal and nonverbal material

The memory of the melody of his favorite song, the name of pet bird growing up and route navigation are all types of declarative memory. This is impaired in amnesia.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following rapid ascent to over 3000 metres above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of headache and breathlessness following rapid ascent indicate acute mountain/altitude sickness and IV digoxin is not used to treat this condition. 

On ascent to high altitudes, the low partial pressure of oxygen leads to hypoxia and systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and the following symptoms are seen:

  • Headache
  • Irritation
  • Insomnia
  • Breathlessness
  • Nausea and vomiting

Treatment involves administration of oxygen, descent to a lower altitude and administration of acetazolamide. Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high altitude areas

questions.text: Which of the following is a low potency local anesthetic?
questions.solution:
The potency of procaine is low.

Potency depends on hydrophobicity. Hydrophobicity can be increased by the addition of alkyl groups to the molecule.

Tetracaine, bupivacaine, etidocaine are highly potent LA.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Local Anesthetics based on the Potency

  1. Low Potency - Procaine
  2. Intermediate Potency
    • Mepivacaine
    • Prilocaine
    • Chloroprocaine
    • Lidocaine
  3. High Potency
    • Tetracaine
    • Bupivacaine
    • Etidocaine

questions.solution:
A person disobeying quarantine rules would be tried under IPC section 271.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with mitral stenosis requires anticoagulation. Which of the following statements is false regarding her management?

choices.text: LMWH or UFH is used until 13 weeks of pregnancy
From 13 weeks till close to delivery substitute UFH with warfarin
Following vaginal delivery, anticoagulation with LMWH or UFH is restarted after 6 hours

questions.solution:
Warfarin is not contraindicated during lactation.

Warfarin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), unfractionated heparin (UFH) do not accumulate in breast milk. They do not induce an anticoagulant effect in the infant.

The choice of anticoagulants is the main problem in pregnancy due to the following reasons:

  • Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
  • Heparin: It is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but less effective than warfarin.
  • LMWH: Inadequate and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.

Period of gestation

Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

LMWH or UFH

13 to 36 weeks

Warfarin

36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery

LMWH or UFH

6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section

LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

If the patient delivers when the anticoagulant is still effective and bleeds excessively, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously.

questions.text: Which of the following are false regarding the pseudogestational sac?

choices.text: No fetal and yolk sac poles

questions.solution:
There is no increase in the size of the pseudogestational sac.

A pseudosac is a small fluid collection that is centrally located within the endometrial cavity and is surrounded by a thick decidual reaction. 

Pseudogestational sac features:

  • Ovoid shape
  • Central location
  • No increase in size
  • No fetal and yolk sac poles

A pseudosac can be seen in up to 20 percent of women with an ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: Sexual gratification obtained by merely feeling female body parts or articles belonging to a woman is known as ______
questions.solution:
Sexual gratification obtained by merely seeing or feeling female body parts /articles belonging to women is known as fetishism.

Fetishism is a type of paraphilia where the sexual focus is on a particular object which is associated with the human body (a shoe for example). This is found mostly in men. The object of desire usually plays a part during masturbation or sexual intercourse.

Types of Sexual perversions:

  • Eonism/Transvestism: Sexual gratification is achieved by wearing the dress of the opposite sex.
  • Fetishism: Gets sexual gratification by merely seeing or feeling female body parts, certain articles belonging to a woman, such as a sari, footwear, stockings, undergarments, hankies, hairpins, etc.
  • Masochism: Sexual gratification is obtained by being tortured by the sex partner. (opposite of Sadism)
  • Sadism: Sexual gratification is achieved by inducing pain in the sex partner.
  • Voyeurism/Peeping Tom or Scotophilia: Sexual gratification by secretly watching others getting undressed, taking a bath, or performing sexual intercourse, etc.
  • Troilism: Gets sexual gratification by watching his own wife performing, sexual intercourse with another man.
  • Nymphomaniac: A type of perversion of excessive sexual desire in a woman
  • Satyriasis: Excessive sexual desire, arousal, and drive in men.
  • Frotteurism: Gets sexual gratification by pressing/rubbing his genital part through the dresses worn, against the body parts of a female in front of him.
  • Undinism: Gets sexual gratification by watching the act of passing urine or defecating by a woman.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: On examination of the chest wall, the presence of thrills indicate:
questions.solution:
On examination of the chest wall, the presence of thrills indicates a palpable murmur. Thrills are the palpable vibrations produced by turbulent blood flow causing murmurs.

Palpable S3 and S4 cause a double thrust in the apical impulse.

Palpable right ventricular systole is known as heave which is felt in the left parasternal area.

questions.text: Which of the following tests would be positive in a patient suspected to have tibial collateral ligament injury?
questions.solution:
In a patient with an injury to the tibial (medial) collateral ligament, the abduction or valgus stress test would be positive.

The abduction or valgus stress test is done as follows:

  • The patient is made to lie in the supine position.
  • One hand of the examiner is placed on the lateral aspect of the knee for support.
  • The other hand is placed over the ankle.
  • Gentle abduction or valgus stress is applied to the knee while the hand at the ankle externally rotates the leg slightly, and the knee is flexed to 30°.

The test is said to be positive when pain is reproduced, or there is excessive gapping at the medial joint. The below image shows the abduction or valgus stress test.

Adduction or varus stress test is positive in patients with a lateral collateral ligament injury.

Dial test is used to assess the posterolateral instability. This occurs when there is damage to the lateral collateral ligament, popliteofibular ligament, and popliteus tendon.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve nuclei are present in both the general somatic efferent and general visceral efferent column?
questions.solution:
Oculomotor nerve nuclei are present in both general somatic efferent (GSE) and general visceral efferent (GVE) columns in the brainstem.

questions.text: A young patient having a dibucaine number of 80 was prescribed topical anesthetic dibucaine. Which of the following statements is true regarding dibucaine number?

choices.text: A homozygote patient with abnormal allele will have a dibucaine number of 80
Dibucaine number measures  the amount of pseudocholinesterase enzyme
Percentage of activation of pseudocholinesterase is termed as dibucaine number
Adequacy of pseudocholinesterase can be determined qualitatively by dibucaine number

questions.solution:
Among the given options, Option D i.e Adequacy of pseudocholinesterase can be determined qualitatively by dibucaine number is the true statement

  • Dibucaine is a local anesthetic. It inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by 80% but inhibits atypical enzyme activity by only 20%.
  • Dibucaine number refers to the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity.
  • A patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80; a homozygote will have a dibucaine number of 20.
  • The dibucaine number measures pseudocholinesterase function, not the amount of enzyme. Therefore, the adequacy of pseudocholinesterase can be determined
    • Quantitatively in units per liter - in the laboratory
    • Qualitatively by dibucaine number 

Related Pearl: Dibucaine number

  • High dibucaine number (80) means the high quantity of normal and low quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: normal response to succinylcholine and mivacurium.
  • Low dibucaine number (<30) means the low quantity of normal and high quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: prolonged succinylcholine and mivacurium block.

questions.text: A 6-year-old mentally retarded girl presents with a protuberant abdomen, short stature, coarse facial features, and cloudy corneas. Skeletal malformations include dysostosis multiplex and bullet-shaped middle phalanx. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point to the diagnosis of Hurler's disease (MPS 1). Deficiency of the enzyme α-L-iduronidase that degrades glycosaminoglycans results in Hurler’s disease.

Hurler’s disease was also known previously as gargoylism (coarse facial features).

Clinical features of the disease include coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, and inguinal hernias. They also present with hepatosplenomegaly, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, and can present with hydrocephalus or valvular heart disease. These patients also have Reilly body inclusions in their leukocytes. 

The gene encoding α-L-iduronidase is present on chromosome 4. Heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate are accumulated. Enzyme replacement therapy is available in the form of aldurazyme.

Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans.

  • Most common MPS: Sanfilippo >  Hunter’s and Hurler’s 
  • MPS with no mental retardation: Scheie’s disease, Morquio syndrome, and Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome.
  • MPS with no corneal clouding: Hunter’s disease and Sanfilippo syndrome
  • MPS with XLR inheritance: Hunter’s disease
  • MPS with no visceromegaly: Morquio’s disease
  • Skeletal deformity associated with all MPS: Dysostosis multiplex
  • MPS with no leucocyte inclusions: Morquio’s disease

questions.text: A  farmer was presented with a suppurative wound on his arm and respiratory symptoms. Later he was diagnosed with melioidosis. The causative organism of this disease belongs to which category of bioterrorism agents as classified by CDC?
questions.solution:
Melioidosis is caused by burkholderia pseudomallei and it belongs to category B agent of bioterrorism as classified by CDC.

Melioidosis is also known as Whitmore's disease. The incubation period can be as short as 2–3 days,  months, or years. A suppurative wound infection can occur at the inoculation site which may lead to sepsis and multi-organ involvement. It is presented as fever with leukocytosis. Chest x-ray shows upper lobe consolidation. Gram staining with Wright's or methylene blue shows a gram-negative organism.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of bleeding from the nose after a fistfight. On evaluation, it was found to be a vertical fracture of the nasal septum. What is the name of the fracture suffered by this patient?
questions.solution:
Since it is a vertical fracture of the nasal septum, it is called a Chevallet fracture.

Injuries to the nasal septum can result from trauma to the nose from the front, side, or below. The septum may get buckled on itself, fracture vertically, horizontally, or get crushed.

A Chevallet fracture usually results from a blow to the nose from below. This fracture line runs vertically. It extends from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

A Jarjaway fracture results from a blow to the nose from the front. The fracture line runs horizontally backward. It begins just above the anterior nasal spine and extends just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer. 

Patients with septal injuries with mucosal tears present with profuse epistaxis. Those with an intact mucosa may have a septal hematoma, which should be drained. 

Dislocated or fractured fragments of the septum should be repositioned and supported. This is done with mucoperichondrial flaps, mattress sutures, and nasal packing.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents to the ER with palpitations, headache, and sweating. There have been multiple such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to be high. Investigations reveal a suprarenal mass and elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine. The given clinical condition is associated with the germline mutation of all the following genes except ______
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of pheochromocytoma and it has been associated with the germline mutation of all the above genes except NF-2 gene.

Patients commonly present with a classical triad of palpitation, headache, and profuse sweating. The presence of this triad in association with hypertension elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine, and suprarenal mass makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis.

Pheochromocytoma is associated with:

  • MEN-2: caused by germline mutations of the RET proto-oncogene
  • Familial paraganglioma syndrome: caused by germline mutations within the succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB), SDHD, and SDHC genes.
  • Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome: caused by a germline mutation in the VHL gene.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1: caused by a germline mutation in the NF1 gene.

questions.text: A patient has been bitten by the snake shown in the picture. The venom in this bite would be predominantly.
questions.solution:
The snake in the given image has white bands on the body which is a feature of common krait and it belongs to the elapidae family. The venom of the common krait is Neurotoxic.

Krait venom produces only paralysis, not convulsions.

Related Pearl: Identification of Poisonous Snakes

Snake Identification
 Common Cobra  Hooded with spectacle mark
King cobra Hooded without spectacle mark
Common krait Single/double white bands on body
Russell viper
Three rows of diamond shape black/brown spots.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought due to complaints of hallucinations, abnormal behavior, hydrophobia, and insomnia. He was bitten by a stray dog 4 weeks ago. The patient dies a couple of days later. An autopsy revealed the presence of the following findings in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. What are these pathognomic microscopic findings called?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of abnormal behavior, hydrophobia, and hallucinations a few weeks after a dog bite is suggestive of rabies. Negri bodies are the pathognomonic microscopic finding in rabies.

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites that are usually devoid of inflammation.

The rabies virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods.

Image: Characteristic Negri bodies found in the Purkinje cell of the cerebellum.

Clinical stages of rabies:

PHASE TYPICAL DURATION SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS
Incubation period 20-90 Days None
Prodrome 2-10 days Fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, paresthesia
Acute neurologic disease    
Encephalitic/Furious rabies (80%) 2-7 days Anxiety, Agitation, Hyperactivity, hallucinations, hydrophobia, autonomic dysfunction
Paralytic /dumb rabies (20%) 2-7 days Flaccid paralysis in limbs progressing to quadriparesis with facial paralysis.
Coma 0-10 days Respiratory depression, arrest, death

questions.solution:

It is due to exposure to allergens and occurs in childhood.

questions.text: A G2P1 obese woman was diagnosed with arrest of descent during labour. Identify the following manoeuvre performed for this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. 

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen).
  • The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby. 
  • Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position.

Rubin's manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position. 
  • Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder.

Wood corkscrew manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position.
  • Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.

questions.text: You are working at an NGO eye hospital which provides affordable eye-care to people in need. Under the program whose logo is given below, NGO eye hospitals are considered ____________
questions.solution:
Under the National Programme for the Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI), whose logo is shown above, NGO eye hospitals are considered secondary level.

The levels of eye care, according to NPCBVI are:

  • Primary level: Sub-district level hospitals, community health centers, mobile ophthalmic units, upgraded PHCs, link workers, Panchayats.
  • Secondary level: District hospitals, NGO eye hospitals
  • Tertiary levels: Regional institutes of Ophthalmology, medical colleges.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a diabetic foot. The plan is to amputate the foot at the level of A-B as shown below. What is the amputation at this level called?
questions.solution:
This level of amputation is called Syme's amputation.

Amputation at the level distal tibia and fibula 0.6 cm proximal to the periphery of the ankle joint passing through the dome of the ankle. It is the most satisfactory functional level in the lower extremity when the outcome is good. The most common causes of an unsatisfactory Syme stump are posterior migration of the heel pad and skin slough resulting from overly vigorous trimming of “dog ears” or a compromised posterior tibial artery. The chief objection to this amputation is cosmetic.

Sarmiento modification of Syme technique is transection of the tibia and fibula approximately 1.3 cm proximal to the ankle joint and excision of the medial and lateral malleoli.

Related Pearl: List of Names of Amputations and Their Levels

TYPE 

LEVEL OF AMPUTATION 

Lisfranc

Tarsometatarsal joint 

Chopart 

Transverse tarsal joints (articulation of calcaneus with cuboid and talus with navicular)

Pirogoff

Calcaneum is rotated forward to be fused with tibia after vertical section through its middle 

Syme 

Distal tibia & fibula 0.6 cm proximal to the periphery of ankle joint passing through the dome of the ankle. Involves removal of both medial and lateral malleoli.

Boyd 

Talectomy, forward shift of the calcaneus and calcaneo-tibial arthrodesis 

Sarmiento 

Distal tibia and fibula: 1.3 cm proximal to the ankle joint and excision of medial and lateral malleoli

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: A low sodium diet decreases the risk of pre-eclampsia
Calcium supplementation in calcium-deficient mothers decreases the risk of preeclampsia
Treatment of preeclampsia with magnesium increases endothelin-1 concentrates
There is decreased vascular sensitivity to angiotensin 2

questions.solution:
Calcium supplementation in calcium-deficient mothers decreases the risk of preeclampsia.

Women who have a low daily intake, other calcium-deficient states, or live in an area of endemic calcium deficiency may benefit from calcium supplementation to reduce the risk of preeclampsia

Calcium supplementation above the RDA does not reduce the incidence of pre-eclampsia. Unless women are calcium deficient, supplementation has no salutary effects.

A sodium-restricted diet is ineffective in preventing preeclampsia.

Treatment of preeclampsia with magnesium lowers endothelin-1 concentrates. 

There is increased vascular sensitivity to angiotensin 2.

questions.text: A middle-aged man who presented with an abdominal mass has the following subcutaneous venous circulation with the direction of the flow as depicted by the arrows in the image. This can be seen in:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the upward flow of subcutaneous venous circulation can be seen in inferior vena cava obstruction.

The level of the umbilicus is a watershed area for venous and lymphatic circulation. The systemic veins anastomose with tributaries of portal veins at the umbilicus. Normally, venous blood and lymphatics flow upwards above the plane of the umbilicus and downwards below this plane. 

  • In inferior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal wall is completely upward.
  • In superior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal veins is completely downward.
  • In portal hypertension with dilated abdominal veins, the blood flow is away from the umbilicus, radiating like a star from the umbilicus (caput-medusae).

Causes of superior and inferior vena caval obstruction:

Causes of SVC obstruction Causes of IVC obstruction 

 

1. Mediastinal malignancy

2. Mediastinal fibrosis

3. Retrosternal thyroid

4. Aortic aneurysm

5. Radiation fibrosis

6. Iatrogenic
  1.  Thrombosis extension
  2.  Tumor invasion
  3.  Extrinsic compression (Eg: Pregnancy, abdominal mass)
  4. Coagulopathy
  5. Sepsis, dehydration, immobility
  6. Iatrogenic

Splenic vein thrombosis is one of the prehepatic causes of portal hypertension, in which the portal venous system is affected before it enters the liver.

questions.text: Abhiyan Indradhanush comes under?

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

questions.solution:
Abhiyan Indradhanush in relation to Employees State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) pertains to change of bedsheets on a daily basis from Sunday to Saturday (VIBGYOR pattern for the color of bedsheet to be used) at ESIC hospitals.

Not to be confused with Mission Indradhanush, which is related to vaccination and comes under the purview of MOHFW (Ministry of Health and Family Welfare).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was found dead at home, who had a chronic history of swelling of both limbs and breathlessness. The gross pathological image of his liver is given below. What is the most likely cause of the appearance of the liver?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the nutmeg appearance of the liver, seen in heart failure.

Congestive hepatopathy, also known as chronic passive congestion of the liver, is liver dysfunction due to venous congestion; it usually occurs due to congestive heart failure. It can also occur due to isolated venous obstruction.

Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, known as a nutmeg liver. Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver.

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver, resembling the cut section of nutmeg. This appearance occurs due to hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins, usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

questions.text: A surgery resident during the rounds advised the intern to monitor the burns patient for adequate fluid resuscitation and also instructed him to give a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight if the patient showed signs of hypoperfusion. All of the following are indications to give bolus fluid, except:
questions.solution:
A low hematocrit does not indicate a need for fluid resuscitation.

Instead, a high hematocrit is an indicator of hypoperfusion. 

Urine output is the best measure to monitor for the adequacy of fluid resuscitation. Urine output should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour. If the urine output is below this, the infusion rate should be increased by 50%. If the urine output is inadequate and the patient is showing signs of hypoperfusion, then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given.

Signs of hypoperfusion include:

  • Restlessness with tachycardia,
  • Cool peripheries 
  • High hematocrit

questions.text: A microbiologist uses a differential and selective media to distinguish lactose fermentators (seen as pink colonies) from non-lactose fermentators (seen as colourless or pale). Which of the following is not a constituent of this medium?
questions.solution:
MacConkey agar is used to distinguish lactose fermentators (seen as pink colonies) from non-lactose fermentators (seen as colourless or pale). Cysteine is not a constituent of MacConkey agar.

It is selective because bile salts and dyes inhibit Gram-positive organisms and Gram-negative cocci. It is Differential because the pH indicator turns pink-red when the lactose is fermented.

Contents of MacConkey agar: Mnemonic: PLANT

P – Peptone 

L – Lactose                 

A – Agar

N – Neutral red

T– Sodium Taurocholate

MacConkey agar showing LF and NLF.

questions.text: A 30-year-old electrician was brought to the casualty after getting electrocuted. You examine him and find no signs of life but still try to resuscitate him with cardiac massage and artificial respiration, as you suspect suspended animation. Which of the following conditions would you least expect suspended animation to be associated with?
questions.solution:
Suspended animation is least likely to be associated with garroting. Suspended animation is a condition where signs of life are absent as functions are interrupted for some time or are reduced to a minimum. In such cases, however, life continues and resuscitation is successful. Because the metabolic rate is so low, individual cell oxygen requirements are met by using oxygen dissolved in body fluids.

It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Severe syncopal attack
  • After anesthesia
  • Cholera
  • Concussion
  • Drowning
  • Electrocution
  • Hypothermia
  • Insanity
  • Newborn infants
  • Narcotic Poisoning
  • Shock
  • Sunstroke

The patient can be resuscitated with a cardiac massage or electric stimulator and artificial respiration.

questions.text: A patient who was started on penicillamine subsequently presented with facial swelling. Urinalysis shows proteinuria. The histological image of the kidney biopsy is shown below. Immunofluorescence shows granular deposits of IgG along the basement membrane. This disease can occur secondary to all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicts nephrotic syndrome most probably due to membranous nephropathy, as the symptoms started after starting penicillamine (trigger). Membranous nephropathy is not commonly associated with CMV infection.

Also, the histological image shows diffuse basement membrane thickening, which is suggestive of membranous nephropathy. Immunofluorescence, in this case, will show granular deposits of IgG along the basement membrane which is also present.

Almost 75% of membranous nephropathy are primary and the rest are due to:

  • Drugs such as penicillamine, captopril, gold and NSAIDs
  • Malignant tumors of lung and colon
  • SLE
  • Infections such as Chronic Hep B, Hep C, syphilis, HIV, and malaria.
  • Autoimmune disorders such as thyroiditis

questions.text: Which among the following is the investigation of choice in renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice in renal cell carcinoma is CECT.

MRI is the investigation of choice in renal vein involvement as the renal vein is sub-optimally visualized in CECT.

MRI is superior to CT in differentiating benign from malignant thrombus but offers no advantage in staging the nodal disease.

questions.text: In which of the following drug toxicities is alkalinization of urine done?
questions.solution:
Alkalinization of the urine is done in poisoning with acidic drugs such as barbiturates. When the urine is alkaline, weakly acidic drugs like barbiturates are present in highly ionized form and are excreted more rapidly.

When the tubular urine is made more alkaline, weak acids like barbiturates become highly ionized and are excreted to a greater extent. Similarly, acidification of urine increases the excretion of weak bases. This property is used in the management of drug overdose.

Drug Treatment of overdose
Weak acids
(e.g., phenobarbital, aspirin)		 Alkalinization of urine with sodium bicarbonate
Weak bases
(e.g., amphetamine)		 Acidification of urine with ammonium chloride

questions.text: During rounds in the ward, the senior resident advised you to add a fourth-generation cephalosporin to a patient with a pseudomonal infection. Which of the following drugs would you add?
questions.solution:
Cefpirome is a fourth-generation cephalosporin which is a parenteral antipseudomonal cephalosporin.

Fourth-generation cephalosporin

  • Cefepime
  • Cefpirome

Other options:

Options A and D: Ceftriaxone and ceftazidime are third-generation parenteral cephalosporin.

Option B: Cefaclor is a second-generation oral cephalosporin.

questions.text:
A 15-year old boy presents with persistent vomiting for one day. Laboratory investigations reveal the following. What is the best sequence of management?

Random blood glucose: 400 mg/dl

Serum sodium: 133 mEq/L

Serum potassium: 3 mEq/L

Urine ketone bodies: 4+

choices.text: Start IV fluids, administer IV regular insulin, and then correct hypokalemia
Start IV fluids, administer subcutaneous bolus of insulin and correct hypokalemia concurrently
Start IV fluids and correct hypokalemia first, then administer IV regular insulin
Administer IV regular insulin with KCl first , then start IV fluids once the K+ level is corrected

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). On confirming the diagnosis, IV fluids must be started. If the initial serum potassium < 3.3 meq/L, insulin should be administered only after the correction of hypokalemia.

This is because treatment with insulin and fluids can worsen hypokalemia by the following mechanisms:

  • Insulin causes the shift of K+ ions into cells
  • Resolution of the acidosis also promotes K+ entry into cells
  • Urinary loss of K+ salts of organic acids

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of Saint's triad?
questions.solution:
Saint's triad includes cholelithiasis.

Saint's triad includes the following:

  • Hiatus Hernia
  • Cholelithiasis (gall stones)
  • Diverticulosis of the colon

Other options :

  • Choledocholithiasis indicates the presence of a gallstone in the common bile duct.
  • Cholangitis indicates inflammation of the bile duct system.
  • Cholecystitis indicates inflammation of the gallbladder.

Related Pearl: Triads in Surgery

Triad

Seen in

Epigastric pain + Inability to vomit + Inability to pass a nasogastric tube

Hypertension + Bradycardia + Irregular respiration

Hypersensitiveness of skin + Reflex muscular contraction + Tenderness at Mc Burney’s point

Hutchison’s teeth (notched upper incisors) + Interstitial keratitis + Nerve deafness

questions.text: A newly joined trainee at the gymnasium was able to lift about 8 Kilograms of weight using both his upper limbs. When two more kilograms were added, he could not resist and had dropped the weight down. Which receptor and nerve fiber are responsible for his inability to bear the weight?

choices.text: Golgi tendon organ and Ib fiber
Golgi tendon organ and Ia fiber

questions.solution:
The Golgi tendon organ and Ib fiber are responsible for his inability to bear the weight.

Here, in the scenario given, two types of physiological reflexes have happened.

  • Stretch reflex/myotatic reflex - This has been responsible for the ability to bear the initial 8 kgs of weight by the trainee.
  • Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex - When two more kgs have been added, this has brought the inhibition of motor neuron discharge to his muscles which are responsible for his inability to bear the weight.

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite of the stretch reflex.

When the tension on the muscle becomes extreme, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ, carried by Ib afferents, leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction.

It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

Note: Muscle spindles senses changes in muscle length (stretch).

questions.text: 'How the differences in one variable can be explained by the differences in another variable' is analyzed by ______________
questions.solution:
The coefficient of determination expresses the proportion of variance in one variable that is explained by the variance in the other variable. The coefficient of determination is calculated by r2.

It gives the percentage variation in y explained by x-variables.

The range is 0 to 1 (i.e. 0% to 100% of the variation in y can be explained by the x-variables).

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Calculating one variable using another variable is done by the coefficient of regression.

The variation in one data set is compared with that of another data set by the coefficient of variation (CV). It measures the relative variability by using the mean and standard deviation.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

Related Pearl: Regression

When two variables are correlated, the value of one of the variables can be predicted from the value of the other using regression techniques.

  • Independent variable: The variable from which the other variable is calculated.
  • Dependent variable: The variable for which the value is calculated.

Types of regression:

1. Simple linear regression

  • In this, the value of one variable (y) is used to predict the value of another variable (x).
  • The regression equation is used for this purpose. It gives a straight-line relationship between the two variables.
  • It is given by the equation y = a + bx, where, a is a constant called the intercept constant and b is the regression coefficient.
  • The intercept constant is the point where the Y-axis is intercepted by the regression line. 

 2. Multiple linear regression

  • In this, more than one variable is used to predict the expected value of another variable (y).
  • Here, the expected value of y = a + b1x1 + b2x2…..bnxn where b1 and b2…..bn represent different regression coefficients and x1, x2…….xn represents the known variables.

 3. Logistic regression

  •  In some situations, we are not interested in a numerical outcome (like risk, etc) but we want a nominal or categorical one (like death/survival, developing a disease/not developing a disease)
  • Here, the relationship between the variables will not be a linear one as the outcome from survival to death in relationship with the risk factor can change suddenly. Thus these outcomes are represented by 0 and 1.
  • Using a mathematical logistic function we can transform linear regression data, such that the values of a variable y are limited to the range of 0 to 1, which would give us the probability of y occurring for the given values of variable x.

questions.text: Which of the following group of muscles are unlikely to be involved in a patient diagnosed with an inflammatory myopathy?
questions.solution:
Ocular muscles are unlikely to be involved as they are spared in inflammatory myopathy. They are not involved even in advanced, untreated cases. 

The pattern of muscle involvement in various inflammatory myopathies is: 

  • Proximal muscles are most commonly involved in dermatomyositis and polymyositis, causing difficulty in getting up from a chair, brushing hair, etc.
  • Proximal and distal muscles are involved in inclusion body myositis, such as wrist, finger flexors, and quadriceps.
  • Pharyngeal and neck-flexor muscles are often involved in all forms of inflammatory myopathy, causing dysphagia or difficulty in holding up the head. Respiratory muscles may also be affected in advanced cases.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman complains of excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden bouts of sleep. The symptoms began at the age of 11 and have been worsening. She couldn’t stay awake during her classes or exams and often dozed off standing up, while working. Eventually, she developed episodes of sudden loss of muscle tone, precipitated by strong emotions. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of narcolepsy.

It is characterized by the tetrad of: 

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness
  2. Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  3. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations
  4. Sleep paralysis

The hallmark of narcolepsy is decreased REM latency, i.e. decreased latent period before the first REM period occurs. Normal REM latency is 90-100 minutes. In narcolepsy, REM-sleep usually occurs within 10 minutes of the onset of sleep (sleep onset REM).

Treatment: 

  • Sleep hygiene
  • Scheduled naps
  • Avoidance of alcohol and drugs that cause drowsiness
  • Drugs: 
    • Modafinil (wakefulness-promoting drug) is the drug of choice.
    • Amphetamines
    • Methylphenidate

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: A school going child was admitted to the ophthalmology ward for trachomatous infection of the eye. While doing the ophthalmic examination, you noticed mature follicles with characteristic papillary hyperplasia and corneal pannus. According to McCallan’s staging of trachoma, you would classify this child as?
questions.solution:
The above child belongs to stage 2 of McCallan’s classification as ophthalmic examination reveals mature follicles with characteristic papillary hyperplasia and corneal pannus. 

McCallan’s classification: The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

  • Stage 1 (Incipient trachoma or stage of infiltration): It is characterized by hyperaemia of palpebral conjunctiva and immature follicles
  • Stage 2(Established trachoma or stage of florid infiltration): It is characterized by the appearance of mature follicles, papillae and progressive corneal pannus.
  • Stage 3(Cicatrising trachoma or stage of scarring): It includes obvious scarring of the palpebral conjunctiva.
  • Stage 4(Healed trachoma or stage of sequelae): The disease is quiet and cured but sequelae due to cicatrization, give rise to symptoms.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: A nasogastric tube could not be passed in a newborn having cyclical hypoxia. There is an absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge and there was no misting on a metal spatula under the nose. Which of the following is an effective substitute for tracheostomy in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of choanal atresia, and McGovern’s technique is an effective substitute for tracheostomy in this condition.

Choanal atresia is characterised by a persistent bucco-nasal membrane, leaving a sheet of tissue at the back of the nose and separating it from the pharynx.

Features of choanal atresia include: 

  • Cyclical hypoxia: This is observed in the newborn, where the baby cries, taking in air through the mouth. This relieves the hypoxia, but upon settling down for a while and closing its mouth, the baby struggles to breathe and becomes hypoxic again.
  • Presence of mucoid nasal discharge
  • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
  • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx
  • Absence of misting on a cold metal spatula held under the nose

Choanal atresia can be confirmed by putting methylene blue dye into the nose and observing its passage to the pharynx or putting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph. The most useful investigation though is an axial CT scan.

Definitive treatment is correcting the atresia either by transpalatal or transnasal approach, which is usually done at 1.5 years of age.

McGovern's technique involves the use of a feeding nipple with a large hole, which provides a good oral airway in the infant, as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A: Trotter’s method is used to control epistaxis. The patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood, and breathe quietly from the mouth, as shown in the image below.

 

Option C: Epley’s manoeuvre is used in the treatment of Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo, as shown in the image below.

 

Option D: Pringle maneuver is used to minimize blood loss during hepatic surgery by clamping the vascular pedicle (free margin of lesser omentum), as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx. It has the following features:

  • Bony obstruction is more common than membranous
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.

CT scan is the investigation of choice

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

Immediate management involves placing a feeding nipple with a large hole at the mouth to force the baby to mouth-breathe - McGoverns technique.

Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of abnormal skin pigmentation over his forearms and face. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. Which stain has been used to identify his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features suggest a diagnosis of hemochromatosis. Prussian blue stain is used to identify this condition. On this stain, the hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes appear blue in color. 

Hemochromatosis occurs due to excessive iron absorption that leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs. The involvement of organs occurs in the following order:

  • Liver
  • Pancreas 
  • Myocardium
  • Endocrine organs (pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid, and parathyroid glands)
  • Joints
  • Skin

It can be primary hemochromatosis (inherited disorder) or secondary hemochromatosis (accumulation of iron due to other causes). The adult form of primary hemochromatosis usually occurs due to mutations of the HFE gene.

Clinical features include:

  • Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly
  • Diabetes mellitus due to destruction of pancreatic islets
  • Slate-gray color skin pigmentation due to increased melanin production
  • Cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy)
  • Acute synovitis due to excessive deposition of calcium pyrophosphate that produces disabling polyarthritis known as pseudogout
  • Atrophic testes secondary to pituitary involvement

The image below shows a slide of liver microscopy that has been stained with Perls Prussian blue stain. The hepatocellular iron appears blue due to the stain.

Other options:

Option A: Masson trichrome stain can be used to demonstrate collagen. 

Option B: Congo red stain can be used for demonstrating the accumulation of amyloid.

Option C: Sudan black stain is a fat-soluble dye that is used to demonstrate lipid inclusions. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Related Pearl: Classification of Iron Overload

 Primary / Hereditary Hemochromatosis

HFE gene-related

  • Type 1: C282Y mutations of genes encoding HFE 

Non-HFE gene-related

  • Type 2: Juvenile hemochromatosis
    • 2a - HJV mutation (hemojuvelin)
    • 2b - HAMP mutation (Hepcidin)
  • Type 3: Transferrin receptor 2 (TfR2) related 
  • Type 4: Ferroportin-related HH 

Secondary / Acquired Hemochromatosis

Transfusion iron overload

  • Thalassemia major
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Chronic hemolytic anemias

Chronic liver disease

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

Miscellaneous

  • Congenital atransferrinemia
  • African iron overload (Bantu siderosis)

questions.text: A woman comes to the ophthalmology OPD because of having vision difficulties for the last 3 months. On fundoscopic examination, the following findings are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a fundus typical of pathological myopia due to the stretching of the retina.

The tigroid appearance or tessellated appearance of the fundus can be appreciated. As the eye enlarges, the retinal pigment epithelium becomes thinner, resulting in:

  • A tessellated (checkered) appearance of the fundus
  • Increased visibility of the choroidal vasculature

Other features of the myopic fundus are as follows:

  • Lacquer cracks are spontaneous ruptures of the elastic lamina of Bruch’s membrane. It appears yellowish-white. it is usually located in the posterior pole.
  • Annular gray shadow around the optic disc
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Foster Fuchs spots
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Total retinal atrophy

questions.text: Which of the following is a mesenchymal tumor of the stomach?
questions.solution:
A gastrointestinal stromal tumor is a mesenchymal tumour of the stomach.

Other options:

Option A: Carcinoid: Neuroendocrine tumor

Option B: Lymphoma: Lymphoid tumor

Option C: Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach.

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: A young man presented with seizures refractory to medication. The finding on the skull X-Ray is shown below. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows bracket calcification which is seen in the lipoma of the corpus callosum.

Majority of the lipomas arise near the corpus callosum. These tumors have marginal calcification where they merge with the adjacent cortical tissues. This gives rise to the characteristic bracket appearance. Intracranial lipomas are asymptomatic. Epileptic seizures are common and are occasionally refractory to anticonvulsant treatment.

Other options:

Option A- Sturge–Weber syndrome shows the following features:

  • Facial port-wine stain along the course of the trigeminal nerve
  • Ipsilateral venous angiomas in the cortical leptomeninges
  • Mental retardation
  • Seizures, hemiplegia
  • Skull radio-opacities i.e tram track calcification.

 Below image shows Tram track calcification

Option B- Tuberous sclerosis shows cortical tubers and calcification of ependymal nodules in the wall of ventricles. 

Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder caused by mutations in the TSC1 (chromosome 9) or TSC2 (chromosome 16) genes, which code for hamartin and tuberin respectively. 

Tuberous sclerosis presents usually at a young age. Patients may have retinal hamartomas, cardiac rhabdomyoma, renal angiomyolipomas, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas. The patients present with characteristic cutaneous signs. The first cutaneous sign that develops is the ash leaf macule, which is a macular hypomelanotic patch, commonly seen on the lower back. Another cutaneous manifestation is the shagreen patch, which is a hypermelanotic nevus. It is located in the lumbosacral region. The characteristic bumps that develop on the face are called adenoma sebaceum or facial angiofibromas.

The image below shows the characteristic ash leaf macule.

The below image shows adenoma sebaceum.

 

The below image shows Shagreen patch 

Option C- Meningioma on X-Ray shows calcification, hyperostosis of adjacent bone, and increased vascular markings, it is usually seen falx. Imaging shows the presence of a dural tail sign.

questions.text: During the pre-anaesthetic evaluation of a patient, the oral cavity examined is depicted in the image given below. The image shows which class of the Mallampati score?
questions.solution:
The image of the oral cavity shows the soft palate and the base of the uvula, and is thus graded as Mallampati class III.

Mallampati classification is an important component of airway examination. It is used to assess the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate in an upright position with the patient's head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phonation. 

Higher scores indicate poor visibility of these structures due to the presence of a large tongue. Thus, Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati classes III and IV are considered features of difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old businessman with type A personality comes to you with the blood reports confirming him to be diabetic with elevated blood cholesterol levels. He also mentions that he has been under immense stress in his work. Which of his risk-factor for developing coronary heart disease is considered non-modifiable?
questions.solution:
The non-modifiable risk factor for developing coronary heart disease, in this case, is his personality type. All other factors mentioned are modifiable factors.

questions.text: An intern uses the following instrument to catheterize the patient during his surgery postings. What is the size of the catheter used by the intern?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Foley's catheter. The presence of a red coloured ring in the balloon port indicates its size as 18 F.

Catheter size is measured in the Charrière or French scale. The French scale refers to the external diameter of the catheter, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter. As a general rule, catheter size should be the smallest size that can accomplish the desired drainage (i.e., 12 to 14 Fr for clear urine and 20 to 24 for thick pus or blood-filled urine).

Other options:

Option A: 14 F foley's catheter has a green ring in the balloon port.

Option B: 12 F foley's catheter has an white ring in the balloon port. 

Option D: 20 F foley's catheter has a yellow ring in the balloon port.

The image below shows Foley catheters with different coloured rings in the balloon ports.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: An immunologist while conducting an experiment on anaphylaxis notices varied reactions with different routes of administration of the shocking dose. Identify the correct order of effectiveness of a shocking dose in causing anaphylaxis based on its route of administration?
questions.solution:
The shocking dose is most effective in Intravenous > Subcutaneous >intradermal routes (least) in causing anaphylaxis.

Anaphylaxis is a Type I hypersensitivity syndrome. There are 2 clinical syndromes which are:

  • Anaphylaxis is an acute, potentially fatal systemic form
  • Atopy is the chronic, recurrent, non-fatal, localized form

Priming dose - For induction of hypersensitivity reactions, the host should have contact with the antigen, leading to the priming of the appropriate B or T lymphocytes. 

Shocking dose - Subsequent contact with allergen causing manifestations of hypersensitivity. The shocking dose is most effective in Intravenous > intraperitoneally or Subcutaneously >intradermally (Least).

questions.text: All of the following are true about socialized medicine except:

choices.text: Ensures social equity and universal coverage
Use state funds for free medicine

questions.solution:
Increasing the utilization of health services is not a component of socialized medicine.

It refers to the provision of medical service through the state funds; however, it is operated and regulated by professional groups. Russia was the first to completely socialize medicine.

It eliminates competition among physicians as well as ensures social equity and universal health coverage.

questions.text: A known patient of parkinsonism, taking levodopa for the past 2 years, presents to you with disorientation, confusion, and altered sensorium. You try to reduce the dose of levodopa but it worsens the motor symptoms and the presenting symptoms persist despite reducing the dose. Which of the following drugs is best suited for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Clozapine is recommended in the above given clinical scenario.

The patient presents with disorientation, confusion and altered sensorium. This is suggestive of delirium. Antiparkinsonian agents are frequently implicated in causing delirium because of dopamine increase.

Decreasing the dosage of the antiparkinsonian agent has to be weighed against a worsening of motor symptoms.

Clozapine is recommended when:

  • The antiparkinsonian agents cannot be further reduced
  • Delirium persists even after reducing the dose of antiparkinsonian agents.

If a patient is not able to tolerate clozapine, alternative antipsychotic agents should be considered.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient, a known case of colon carcinoma came to the hospital with complaints of loss of appetite for 3 months.  Which of the following drugs is best suited to be prescribed in this patient to increase appetite?
questions.solution:
Cyproheptadine has an appetite-stimulating effect and has been used to promote weight gain in poor eaters.

It mainly blocks 5 hydroxytryptamine receptors and also has H1 antihistaminic and sedative properties. Side effects include drowsiness, dry mouth, ataxia and weight gain.

Loratidine, Cetirizine and Azelastine are second generation antihitamines.

Loratidine (option A) is a long acting H1 antihistamine and is useful in urticaria and atopic dermatitis

Cetirizine (option B) inhibits release of histamine and cytotoxic mediators from platelets and has superior efficacy ion urticaria and atopic dermatitis. 

Azelastine (option C) inhibits the intracellular adhesion molecule (ICAM-1) on nasal mucosa and is useful in allergic rhinitis.

questions.text: Which of the following structures do not pass through both greater and lesser sciatic foramens?
questions.solution:
The tendon of the obturator internus muscle passes only through the lesser sciatic foramen.

Structures passing through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramen:

  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus.

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: The child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant with large corneas, lacrimation and photophobia supported with the image is suggestive of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) also known as developmental glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure(IOP) which results from the developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber.

It can be classified as:

  • True congenital or newborn glaucoma in which IOP is elevated during intrauterine life and the baby is born with ocular enlargement.
  • Infantile glaucoma: which manifests prior to age 3 years.
  • Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Clinical findings include:

  • Blepharospasm
  • Buphthalmos: Large eyeball due to stretching of the globe from elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Corneal enlargement:
  • Corneal haze is due to corneal edema.
  • Blue sclera - due to the shining of the underlying uveal tissue through the thinned-out sclera
  • Haab striae are healed breaks in Descemet's membrane

Treatment:

  • Goniotomy - when the angle of the anterior chamber is visible through the clear cornea.
  • Trabeculectomy when the corneal clouding prevents visualization of the angle.
  • Filtration procedures such as Trabeculectomy or combined trabeculectomy with trabeculectomy if the above procedures fail.
  • Glaucoma drainage devices in unresponsive cases.

Other options:

Option A: Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood that is seen between 1-2 years.

Findings of Retinoblastoma include:

  • Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex)- the most common manifestation
  • Strabismus 
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma
  • An endophytic tumor grows into the vitreous as a white mass that may ‘seed’ into the gel. If calcification is present it gives a "cottage cheese appearance". An exophytic tumor grows outwards and causes overlying exudative retinal detachment.

The image below shows the leucocoria of the left eye.

Option C: Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy (CHED) is an inherited corneal dystrophy that manifests since birth with endothelial degeneration. It appears as diffuse bilateral corneal edema in the absence of elevated IOP. The clinical features of the disease include corneal clouding, visual impairment, and nystagmus.

Option D: Megalocornea is a bilateral non-progressive X-linked condition that most commonly affects males. In this condition, the horizontal corneal diameter is ≥12mm(<2 years) and is ≥13 mm(>2 years). It is characterized by a clear cornea, normal corneal thickness, and no breaks in the descemet's membrane. Systemic associations of Megalocornea include Marfan's syndrome, Apert syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos, and Down syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cardinal feature of the disease pathogenesis primarily involving the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, aka paralysis agitans. Postural instability along with bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are cardinal features of Parkinson's disease.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Note: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is per se not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

questions.text: A young patient presents with fever and acute pain over the right thigh.  X-ray of the thigh reveals a lamellar onion skin periosteal reaction on the femur. Which of the following is false regarding the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: The most common location includes the metaphysis of long bones
It occurs mostly in patients of 5 to 25 years old
Immunohistochemical staining for MIC-2 gene is specific for this
Patients with metastasis have only a 20% chance for long-term survival

questions.solution:
The diagnosis, in this case, is Ewing's sarcoma. The most common location includes the diaphysis of long bones.

A diaphyseal tumor presenting with fever, pain, and swelling suggests Ewing's sarcoma. Classically, Ewing's sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion with the lamellar "onion skin" periosteal reaction. Immunohistochemical staining for MIC-2 is specific for Ewing’s sarcoma. It occurs more commonly in the age group of 5 to 25 years. 

Patients with metastasis have only a 20% chance of long-term survival.
