questions.text: A 40-year-old male, suspected to have ischemic heart disease was subjected to a treadmill stress test. During the procedure, he had a maximum blood pressure of 180/100 mm Hg, and his heart rate went up to 120 beats per minute. As he developed dizziness and chest pain, the test was terminated, and the patient made to lie supine on the couch for a while. A repeat BP after 20 minutes was 120/90 mm Hg, and the heart rate came down to 70 as well. Which of the following is the correct sequence of physiologic responses that have lowered his BP and heart rate?

choices.text: Aortic arch - Hering's nerve - Nucleus tractus solitarius - RVLM - CVLM
Carotid sinus - Vagus nerve - RVLM - Nucleus tractus solitarius - CVLM
Aortic arch - Vagus nerve - CVLM - Nucleus tractus solitarius - RVLM
Carotid sinus - Hering's nerve - Nucleus tractus solitarius - CVLM - RVLM

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of physiologic responses to increased blood pressure is 'Carotid sinus - Hering's nerve - Nucleus tractus solitarius - CVLM - RVLM'

  • An increase in blood pressure causes stimulation of the baroreceptors.
  • The afferents from the baroreceptors are carried to the 'nucleus tractus solitarius' located in the medulla via the Hering's nerve. Hering's nerve is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) that innervates the baroreceptors of the carotid sinus and the chemoreceptors.
  • The neurons from the nucleus tractus solitarius release glutamate and activate the CVLM (caudal ventrolateral medulla)
  • Following this, the neurons of the CVLM release GABA and inhibit the neurons in the RVLM (rostral ventrolateral medulla)
    • The RVLM serves as the predominant site for sympathetic discharge from the brain and hence, its inhibition reduces the sympathetic discharge which brings down the blood pressure and heart rate
  • The neurons from the nucleus tractus solitarius also excited the vagal motor neurons in the nucleus ambiguus
    • As the vagal neurons are stimulated in the nucleus ambiguus, it lowers the blood pressure and heart rate as well.
  • Baroreceptors
  1. Stretch receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels
  2. Types based on location
    • Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions)
    • Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions)
  3. Afferents
    • Carotid sinus – a branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) – the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)
    • Aortic arch receptor – a branch of Vagus nerve (X CN) – aortic depressor nerve
  4. Center for Reflex
    • Medulla (Nucleus Tractus solitarius)
  5. Efferents
    • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature
    • Most sensitive to MAP
    • The threshold for excitation: 50 mmHg
    • Maximal activity: 180 mmHg
  6. Responses when one carotid sinus is isolated and perfused and the other baroreceptors are denervated
    • Perfusion pressure <30mm Hg:no response
    • 70–110mm Hg: the linear relationship between perfusion pressure and the fall in systemic BP and HR
    • >150mm Hg: no further increase in response to the degree of inhibition of sympathetic nerve is maximal.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with unilateral scrotal swelling. On examination, the swelling shows transillumination and the testis is palpable separate from the swelling. The fluid aspirated from the swelling resembles barley water in appearance. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with a unilateral scrotal swelling, which shows transillumination, and fluid aspirated from the swelling showing a barley water appearance is suggestive of a spermatocele.

A spermatocele is an unilocular retention cyst derived from the epididymis. It is a cystic lesion that transilluminates. When aspirated, the fluid has a characteristic barley water appearance due to the presence of spermatozoa.

Transillumination can be present in swelling caused by spermatoceles or an epididymal cyst. Differences between a spermatocele and an epididymal cyst are demonstrated in the table below:

Spermatocele Epididymal cyst
Unilocular retention cyst Multiple, multilocular (bunch of grapes on palpation)

Present at the epididymal head, above and behind the upper pole of testes

 Posterior to testis
Barley water fluid appearance on aspiration Aspiration is usually ineffective as the cyst is multilocular
Treatment: Excision Treatment: Excision


Hydrocele is a scrotal swelling caused by the accumulation of serous fluid in the processus vaginalis. Clinically, a hydrocele encloses the testis and the epididymis. Hence, the testis will not be palpable separately from the swelling.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy was found to have a mental age of 11 years. Based on the calculated Intelligence quotient (IQ),  you would classify his mental status as _______ according to Levine and Marks' IQ classification
questions.solution:
Intelligence quotient (IQ) = Mental age x 100/ Chronological age.

Based on the above formula, his IQ is calculated to be around 84, which is between 80-89. This case will be classified as low normal according to Levine and Marks IQ classification.

Related Pearl: Intelligence Quotient

  • The intelligence quotient is a score that can be obtained from several standardized tests to assess human intelligence.
  • Historically, IQ = Mental age x 100/ Chronological age
  • Here, the mental age is obtained from intelligence tests.
  • Higher the IQ, the more brilliant is the person.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to have jaundice. His stools are yellow and his urine is pale straw yellow-colored. He is otherwise well. Blood tests show unconjugated bilirubinemia. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given child is exclusively breastfed, whose stools and urine appear normal, along with unconjugated bilirubinemia suggests breast milk jaundice.

Breast milk jaundice is uncommon and is seen in exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 3-4 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain pregnanediol and β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.

Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Other options: 

Options A and D- Biliary atresia and neonatal cholestasis have conjugated bilirubinemia.

Option B- Erythroblastosis fetalis have unconjugated bilirubinemia and it is seen in the first 24 hours of life.

Related Pearl: Hyperbilirubinemia- Causes

questions.text: A worker at a textile mill complains of exhaustion and fatigue and says he works around 72 hours per week. According to the Factories act of 1948, what are the maximum hours of work per day for an industrial worker?
questions.solution:
According to The Factories act, 1948, the maximum hours of work per day for an industrial worker is 9 hours. It should not be more than 48 hours per week, if working overtime, it should not exceed 60 hours per week. 

Adolescents between 15 and 18 years of age can only be employed in certain industries, and their work hours should not exceed four and a half hours per day.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male came with the ocular finding as shown in the given image. Which of the following is responsible for the disease process in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Band-shaped keratopathy and is due to the calcium deposition on the cornea.

The deposition is seen on the Bowman's layer, epithelial basement membrane, and the anterior stroma.

Causes:

  • Ocular
    • Chronic anterior uveitis (particularly in children)
    • Phthisis bulbi
    • Silicone oil in the anterior chamber
    • Chronic corneal oedema 
    • Severe chronic keratitis
  • Metabolic (metastatic calcification). This is rare and includes increased serum calcium and phosphorus, hyperuricemia, and chronic renal failure.
  • Hereditary causes include familial cases and ichthyosis.

Treatment

  • Chelation using topical ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) 1.5–3.0% until all calcium has been removed.
  • Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) using excimer laser.

questions.text: A baby, about 30 days old, is brought with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. He has large and hazy corneas. His lacrimal system is normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario fits the description of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG):

It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Diagnosis

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring
  • Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in a patient who presents with a painful ear swelling as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of painful, erythematous ear swelling is suggestive of perichondritis.

The most common cause is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non-iatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. The most common organism responsible is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

The image given below shows a patient with a cauliflower ear deformity. It is also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear. It is usually caused by repeated episodes of trauma.

 

Chondrodermatitis chronica helicis is a small, nodular, tender, chronic inflammatory lesion occurring on the helix of the ear. It is shown in the image below. 

 

Otitis externa, also called swimmer's ear, is the inflammation of the ear canal. It has the following appearance:

Related Pearl: Eponyms of the ear

Eponym

Description

Boxer’s/ Cauliflower ear

Organized hematoma of pinna

Surfer’s ear

Exostosis

Swimmer’s ear

Diffuse otitis externa

questions.text: Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a Six’s thermometer.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: The SI unit for the biological risk of radiation exposure is ________
questions.solution:
The SI unit for the biological risk of radiation exposure is sievert and the conventional unit is Rem.

It indicates the potential danger to health. To determine a person's biological risk, a number is assigned to each radiation type (X rays, Gamma rays, alpha particles, beta particles, etc) depending on the ability to transfer energy to cells. This number is called the quality factor (Q). When a person is exposed to radiation, the biological risk can be estimated by multiplying the dose in rad and the quality factor (Q) for that type of radiation.

Risk in Rem= Rad × Q

1 sievert = 100 rem

Rad is a unit of absorbed radiation by tissue or material. It has been replaced by gray (Gy).

Related Pearl: Important SI units for radiation

Quantity measured Old unit New Unit Conversion Description
Radioactivity Curie Becquerel 1 curie = 3.7 x 1010 becquerel  
Radiation exposure Roentgen Coulumb/kg 1 roentgen = 2.58 × 10-4 C/Kg Amount of radiation absorbed in air.  
Absorbed dose Rad Gray (Gy) 100 rad = 1 gray (or, 1 rad = 0.01 gray)  Amount of radioactive energy absorbed per unit gram of tissue or material.
Dose equivalent Rem Sievert (Sv) 100 rem = 1 sievert  Indicates potential danger to health.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of the following pathological change seen in the spleen?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a pale, wedge-shaped area of infarction in the spleen.

An infarct is a region of ischaemic necrosis resulting from the obstruction of blood flow, typically due to occlusion of the arterial supply or venous drainage. The most common cause of solid organ infarts is thromboembolism.

The pattern of ischemic necrosis seen in solid organ infarction is coagulative necrosis. However, CNS infarctions are an exception. They cause liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: Where can we find the Thornwaldt's cyst?
questions.solution:
Thornwaldt cyst can be found in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx in the adenoid mass.

  • It is an epithelial-lined median recess found within the adenoid mass and extends from pharyngeal mucosa to the periosteum of the basiocciput.
  • It represents the attachment of notochord to the pharyngeal endoderm during embryonic life.
  • When infected, it may be the cause of persistent postnasal discharge or crusting. Sometimes an abscess can form in the bursa (Thornwaldt’s disease).
  • It is managed surgically by marsupialization of the swelling and complete removal of the lining of the cyst.    

The following is the MRI showing a Thornwald cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following points towards Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome?

choices.text: Sensory neural deafness and retinitis pigmentosa

questions.solution:
Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) along with abetalipoprotenemia points towards Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome.

Syndromes associated with RP (Atypical RP)
Usher syndrome (Most common) Sensory neural deafness + RP 

Bardet–Biedl syndrome 

(Previously called Lawrence–Moon–Biedl–Bartum Syndrome)

 Polydactyly, obesity, mental handicap, and kidney disease + RP
Kearn–Sayre syndrome Ocular myopathy and heart disease + RP
Refsum Syndrome   

Varied skin as well as neurological and visceral features + RP
 

Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome

 Abetalipoprotenemia and acanthocytosis + RP
Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) Neuropathy and Ataxia + RP

questions.text: A 6-year-old unimmunized boy from the rural area complains of difficulty swallowing. On examination, the below finding is seen. What is false regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: All cases should be reported to local and state health departments
Specific antitoxin is the mainstay of treatment
All case contacts are closely monitored for illness through 7-day incubation period
Immunized case contacts need not receive antimicrobial prophylaxis

questions.solution:
The image shows a Pseudomembrane in an unimmunized boy, suggesting a diagnosis of Diphtheria. In which, all case contacts should be treated with prophylactic antimicrobial therapy irrespective of immunization status. All the other options are true.

Diphtheria:

  • Causative agent: Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Carriers are the most common causes of infection. Immunization does not prevent the carrier state.
  • The regulation of toxin production in the bacterium is partially controlled by iron, thus making it an important prerequisite for toxin production.
  • Mode of infection: Droplets through the respiratory tract (most important), cutaneous lesions, and fomites.

Clinical features:

  • Respiratory tract diphtheria: 
    • The commonest type of diphtheria
    • Thick, adherent pseudomembrane (grey or white) on one/both tonsils and adjacent pharynx. Dislodging of the membrane may cause bleeding.
    • Underlying soft tissue edema and enlarged lymph nodes can cause a bull-neck appearance.
    • Patients with laryngeal diphtheria are at risk for suffocation because of local soft-tissue edema and airway obstruction by the diphtheritic membrane.
  • Cutaneous diphtheria:
    • An indolent, non-progressive infection characterized by a superficial, ecthyma-like, non-healing ulcer with a gray-brown membrane.
  • Infection at other sites:
    • Occasionally, it causes mucocutaneous infections at other sites, such as otitis externa, purulent conjunctivitis, and vulvo-vaginitis.

Diagnosis: The culture of the organism from the nose and throat specimens is the gold standard. Demonstration of the toxin by Elek's gel precipitation test. A gram stain or fluorescent antibody test is unreliable.

Complications:

  • Obstruction due to pseudomembrane
  • Myocarditis
  • Polyneuropathy

Recent update:

Diphtheria toxin has been used in the treatment of cancer. Denileukin diftitox (recombinant human interleukin-2 and diphtheria toxin) is the first immunotoxin approved by FDA, for the treatment of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for congenital dehiscence of the fallopian canal?
questions.solution:
The congenital dehiscence (absence of bony cover) of the fallopian canal of the facial nerve occurs most commonly in the tympanic or horizontal segment over the oval window.

It is the most common anomaly of the facial canal. A dehiscent nerve is prone to injury at the time of surgery. It gets easily compressed or inflamed in mastoid and middle ear infections.

questions.text: Post-disaster, the WHO recommends which of the following vaccines to be given to the healthcare workers?
questions.solution:
The WHO recommends typhoid, cholera, and tetanus vaccines for the healthcare workers after a disaster.

  • WHO does not recommend these vaccinations for the general population post-disaster.
  • Supply of safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta are the most practical and effective strategies of preventing diseases, post-disaster.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented at term with a USG report suggesting fetus in breech position and on per vaginal examination, toes of the foot can be felt. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the fetus is in a footling breech position at term, which is an indication for the cesarean section.

In footling breech, one or both legs are extended at the hip, so that the foot is the presenting part.

A major complication of breech presentation is cord prolapse. In the cord prolapse, the umbilical cord drops down below the presenting part of the baby and becomes compressed.

Factors favoring cesarean delivery of the breech fetus:

  • Large fetus: > 3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech
  • Primi with breech
  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech

questions.text: A child presents with a dislocated fracture of the first metacarpal. What is the preferred regional anaesthesia technique for the surgery?
questions.solution:
The axillary block is the most preferred approach to the brachial plexus in pediatric patients for surgeries of the elbow, forearm, and hand.

It is a relatively easy and safe procedure. Complications include systemic toxicity due to accidental intraarterial injection and permanent nerve injury from the intraneural injection.

questions.text: The image illustrated below represents the shape of congenital renal anomaly seen in a 10-year-old child. Radiological investigations indicate that both the renal units are low lying. Which of the following arteries most likely prevents the ascent of the kidney in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image shows horseshoe kidney. Inferior mesenteric artery prevents the ascent of the horseshoe kidney.

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys.

Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of lower poles of the kidney. Horseshoe kidneys are prone to reflux,obstruction and stone formation.

The common associations of horseshoe kidney are:

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux
  • Wilms Tumor (4 times more common in children with horseshoe kidneys than in the general population)
  • Multicystic Dysplastic Kidney
  • Turner’s Syndrome

questions.text: An elderly male who is a known case of chronic bronchitis comes with complaints of dry cough, fever, and shortness of breath for 2 weeks. Laboratory reports reveal that he is positive for COVID-19. The causative virus in this patient shows all the following features, except that ______.

choices.text: It is an enveloped RNA virus.

questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned options are true about the COVID-19 virus, except that it has negative sense RNA. Positive sense RNA is seen in the COVID-19 virus.

Properties of coronaviridae family:

  • They have enveloped RNA viruses
  • They contain a genome of unsegmented single-stranded and positive-sense RNA
  • They have helical nucleocapsid

The image given below shows the structure of the coronavirus.

Related Pearl: Types of symmetry of viruses

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with depression, being treated with phenelzine came to the emergency department with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis following dinner at the restaurant. On examination, his BP is 190/120.  The patient is diagnosed with a cheese reaction. Consumption of any of the following foods could have caused cheese reaction except:
questions.solution:
Cheese reaction is seen on the consumption of tyramine-rich foods such as cheese, red wine, aged meat, fish, etc. Apples do not cause a cheese reaction.

Cheese reaction occurs in patients being treated with MAO inhibitors who consume tyramine-rich foods. Inhibition of the MAO-A isoform prevents the metabolism of dietary tyramine in the gut, thus allowing intact tyramine to enter circulation. A hypertensive crisis occurs as a result of a powerful pressor effect of tyramine. 

The hypertensive crisis in cheese rection is treated with phentolamine.

questions.text: You are a medical practitioner in a remote rural area, you remove a worm from a patient as shown below by rolling it over a stick. The worm that you are removing by this procedure is ____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the way Guinea worm(Dracunculiasis) is removed by rolling them out over a small stick.

Dracunculiasis/Guinea worm disease is a vector-borne parasitic disease caused by Dracunculus medinenesis. Transmission occurs by consumption of water containing cyclops harbouring infective stages of the parasite. This disease is totally a water-based disease and has no alternate way of transmission.

The life cycle of Guinea worm:

Guinea-worm disease is amenable to eradication. 

  • Worms are removed by sequentially rolling them out over a small stick.
  • Wet compresses may relieve discomfort. Occlusive dressings improve hygiene and limit shedding of infectious larvae.
  • No drug cures the infection but metronidazole and mebendazole are sometimes used to limit inflammation and facilitate worm removal.
    • Provision of safe drinking water (e.g., piped water, installation of hand pumps).
    • Control of cyclops
  • Health education of the public in matters relating to boiling or sieving drinking water through a double thickness cotton cloth for personal protection, and prevention of water contamination by infected persons.
  • Surveillance: Active search for new cases.

questions.text: When you were working as a junior resident in the cardiology department, you admit a patient after making a diagnosis of congestive heart failure. Your senior advises you to put him on with ACE inhibitor and endopeptidase inhibitor. You decide to prescribe your patient with a single drug that has combined action. Which one of the following drugs you would prescribe to achieve this?
questions.solution:
Omapatrilat is a dual neutral endopeptidase inhibitor and ACE inhibitor. 

Other options:

Option A - Ivabradine is an inhibitor of If  current in the sinoatrial node. It reduces the heart rate without decreasing the force of contraction.

Option C - Nesiritide is a recombinant human brain natriuretic peptide (BNP). It causes vasodilatation and natriuresis. It is administered intravenously and used in acute decompensated heart failure.

Option D - Levosimendan is a calcium sensitizer. It causes vasodilatation and increases myocardial contractility without increasing oxygen demand.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Drugs used in acute decompensated heart failure:
 
Intravenous vasodilators

Nitroglycerine

Sodium nitroprusside

 Decrease preload and afterload
Nesiritide Recombinant human BNP
 
Intravenous positive inotropes

Dobutamine

Dopamine

Epinephrine

Norepinephrine

 β1 receptor-mediated stimulation of cardiac output

Enoximone

Milrinone

 PDE 3/4 inhibitors

Levosimendan

Pimobendan

 Combined Ca2+ sensitizers and PDE3 inhibitors
 
Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

Bumetanide

Furosemide

Torasemide

 Loop diuretics- used for symptomatic treatment of severe heart failure and acute decompensation.
Morphine Opioid - to calm the patient and decreases cardiac O2 consumption
 
Drugs used in chronic heart failure:
Drugs Uses
ACE inhibitors Used as first-line therapy
ARBs Used in case of intolerance to ACE inhibitors
Beta-blockers Used as first-line therapy  

Spironolactone

Eplerenone

SGLT-2 inhibitors Used as 1st line therapy- reduces mortality and morbidity
Sacubitril/Valsartan Neprilysin inhibitor/ARB(ARNI)
Ivabradine Inhibitor of If current in the sinoatrial node

questions.text: A pregnant Rh-negative woman presents for her regular antenatal visit. Her Indirect Coombs test is negative. When would you give her prophylactic  Anti-D?
questions.solution:
In a non-immunized Rh-negative primigravida, Anti D is given at 28 weeks of gestation. It is also given within 72 hours of delivery. 

Routine postpartum administration of anti-D immune globulin to at-risk pregnancies within 72 hours of delivery decreases the alloimmunization rate by 90 percent.

Additionally, the provision of Anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks of gestation reduces the third-trimester alloimmunization rate from approximately 2 percent to 0.1 percent.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man undergoes renal transplantation. Within minutes of completing the anastomosis, the transplanted kidney appears cyanotic & mottled, and it is found to be completely anuric. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Hyperacute rejection. Hyperacute rejection occurs when preformed anti-donor antibodies are present in the circulation of the recipient.

Hyperacute rejection:

  • Occurs within minutes or hours after transplantation.
  • Immunoglobulin and complement are deposited in the vessel wall, causing endothelial injury and fibrin-platelet thrombi.
  • Neutrophils rapidly accumulate within arterioles, glomeruli, and peritubular capillaries.
  • The kidney cortex then undergoes outright necrosis (infarction). Hence the transplant appears cyanotic & mottled.

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: A police officer while investigating a case of infantile homicide asks a forensic expert to estimate the age of the dead infant. The forensic expert estimates the age as 3 months by counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth. Which of the following methods has been used by the forensic expert for age estimation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests that Boyde’s method is being used by the forensic expert for estimating the age of the dead infant.

Boyde’s method method is based on counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth (incremental lines) from the neonatal line onwards. The neonatal line is formed soon after birth and can be seen in about 3 weeks or by electron microscopy 1–2 days after birth. This method is applicable mainly to estimate the age of dead infants.

Other options:

Option B- Stack’s method: Determination of age is done from the weight of the erupting teeth of the fetus/ infant. It can be used on both deciduous and permanent teeth in their erupting phase.

Option C- Miles' method: Age estimation is made on the basis of a comparison of the amount of wear on all three permanent molars with the baseline. It is used to determine the age beyond 25 years. 

Option D- Gustafson’s Method: It is based on physiological changes in teeth. It is used to determine the age between 25-60 years. Gustafson’s criteria include:

  • Attrition: Wear and tear changes of the occlusal surface.
  • Periodontosis: Regression of gums surrounding the tooth resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling.
  • Secondary dentin: Deposition of dentin in the pulp cavity.
  • Cementum apposition: Deposition of cementum in the root forming incremental lines.
  • Root resorption: Involves both cementum and dentin.
  • Transparency of the root: This is the most reliable criterion. Canals in dentin get filled with minerals and they become less transparent.

Note: Amino acid racemization is considered the most reliable destructive method of dental age estimation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is apalutamide approved for?
questions.solution: Apalutamide is an androgen receptor inhibitor indicated for the treatment of patients with non-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.

questions.text: Given below is a transverse B mode doppler ultrasound image done at the saphenofemoral junction in a 40-year-old male patient.  All of the following structures are responsible for this USG appearance except _________
questions.solution:
The given transverse B mode doppler ultrasound image of the saphenofemoral junction shows the Mickey Mouse sign and the internal iliac artery is not responsible for Mickey mouse sign.

Mickey mouse sign is formed by:

  • Common Femoral Vein (CFV)
  • Common Femoral Artery (CFA)
  • Greater Saphenous Vein (GSV) at the Saphenofemoral junction (SFJ).

It represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels as seen in a duplex ultrasound.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male patient was found to have a BP of 146/94 mmHg. His laboratory findings are given below. Which of the following will be the most appropriate anti-hypertensive for this patient?

Fasting blood sugar: 200 mg/dL

Post-prandial blood sugar: 320 mg/dL

HbA1C: 9%
questions.solution:
The most appropriate anti-hypertensive drug for this patient would be telmisartan. Telmisartan has PPARγ agonistic activity, leading to improved insulin sensitivity in patients with diabetes mellitus.

By acting as an agonist on PPARγ receptor, telmisartan regulates the downstream glucose and lipid metabolism. It increases basal and insulin-stimulated uptake of glucose into the adipocytes via GLUT-4. It also decreases the amount of reactive oxygen species and increases serum adiponectin. By these mechanisms, it improves oxidative stress and insulin resistance in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. Furthermore, it has been shown to reduce cardiac fibrosis and hypertrophy.

ACE inhibitors such as Lisinopril (option B) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are able to stop the progression of diabetic nephropathy in patients with diabetes mellitus. They are the first-line anti-hypertensive drugs in diabetic patients. However, because of its additional beneficial effects as described above, telmisartan is preferred.

Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic (option A) and amlodipine, a DHP type of calcium channel blocker (option D) offer no added advantage to the treatment of hypertensive patients with diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: The senior resident in the emergency medicine department decided to add the diuretic which acts on site "A"  marked in the image to the patient with pulmonary edema. The mechanism of action of this diuretic is __________
questions.solution:
Site " A" is the thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle. Loop diuretics act on the thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle and inhibit Na+- K+ -2Cl- symport.

Related Pearl: Site and mechanism of action of diuretics

Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter
Thiazides Distal convoluted tubule  Na+- Cl- symporter
Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the dermatology OPD with findings as shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs can result in this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The above presentation is of livedo reticularis, which is an adverse effect of amantadine.

The patient presents with a common skin finding consisting of a mottled vesicular pattern that appears as a lace-like purplish discoloration of the skin which is due to the local release of catecholamines resulting in post-capillary vasoconstriction.

Adverse effects of amantadine are:

  • Insomnia, restlessness, confusion
  • Nightmares
  • Anticholinergic effects
  • Hallucinations 
  • Livedo reticularis
  • Edema of ankles

questions.text: You will counsel patients regarding first-dose phenomenon while prescribing which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
First-dose phenomenon is characteristic of prazosin and patients must be counselled regarding the effects.

Within 30-90 minutes of the initial dose of prazosin or when the dosage is increased, there is marked orthostatic hypotension or syncope. This is known as the first-dose phenomenon. After a few initial doses, tolerance develops to this side effect. Initiating low doses at bedtime is recommended to minimize this phenomenon.

questions.text: Monoclonal antibody to IL-5 receptor used in the treatment of eosinophilic asthma is _________
questions.solution:
The monoclonal antibody to the IL-5 receptor used in the treatment of eosinophilic asthma is Benralizumab.

The monoclonal antibodies to the IL-5 are Mepolizumab and Reslizumab.

Some of the important monoclonal antibodies are listed below:
