questions.text: The oxygen binding affinity of hemoglobin increases with the number of O2 molecules already bound to it. Which of the following is true regarding this property?

choices.text: It maximizes the loading of O2 from pulmonary end
It prevents the unloading of O2 at hypoxic ends of peripheral tissues
It causes the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to become linear
It is called the multiple binding property of hemoglobin

questions.solution:
The property explained here is cooperative binding and It maximizes the loading of O2 at the pulmonary end.

The cooperative binding property of hemoglobin is because of the multimeric structure of hemoglobin and helps in maximal O2 loading at the pulmonary end and maximal O2 unloading at the tissue end.

Hemoglobin behaves differently at high (R – Relaxed state - high affinity) or low Po2 state (T- taut state – low affinity). It causes the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to become sigmoid in shape.

In contrast, Myoglobin exhibits a hyperbolic shape dissociation curve. Making it ineffective as an oxygen transport protein.

questions.text:
Which of the following values are negative in the declining stage of the demographic cycle?
  1. Demographic gap
  2. Population
  3. Death rate
  4. Population growth
  5. Birth rate
questions.solution:
The demographic gap and population growth are negative in stage 5 ( declining stage) of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with cardiac dysrhythmia. On probing, he says he consumed the leaves of the plant shown in the image. What is the active principle of this plant?
questions.solution:
The plant in the image is Digitalis purpurea. Its active principle is digitonin.

Digitalis purpurea contains digitoxin, digitalin, digitonin, and digoxin. It can cause cardiac dysrhythmia in acute toxicity. 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text:
An investigator was studying the effects of various poisons on the enzymes of the TCA cycle. He plotted the graph for the enzyme catalyzing the conversion of succinate to fumarate after adding malonate. Which of the following graphs represents the type of inhibition expected here?

V: Reaction velocity

[S]: Substrate concentration
questions.solution:
The enzyme catalyzing the conversion of succinate to fumarate is succinate dehydrogenase. Its inhibition by malonate is a competitive inhibition which is represented by image 1. (option B)

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme-binding site. This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition. eg: succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate.

The below graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/V is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

 

Inhibition Km Vmax
Competitive Increases Same
Non Competitive Same Decreases
Uncompetitive Decreases Decreases

Although image 4 also corresponds to noncompetitive inhibition, the graph shows a plot of 1/V (Reaction Velocity) vs. concentration of inhibitor across various concentrations of substrate (S). Hence, it is a Dixon Plot.

Related Pearl: Inhibitors of metabolic pathways

Inhibitors of glycolysis

Agent Enzyme
Iodoacetate Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase
Arsenate Phosphoglycerate kinase
Fluoride Enolase

 

Inhibitors of TCA cycle

Agent Enzyme
Fluoroacetate Aconitase

Arsenite

 α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Malonate Succinate dehydrogenase

 

Inhibitors of electron transport

Complex Inhibitors
Complex I Piercidin, Amobarbital, Rotenone
Complex II TTFA, Carboxin, Malonate
Complex III BAL, Antimycin A
Complex IV Hydrogen sulphide, Carbon monoxide, Cyanide

 

Inhibitors of oxidative phosphorylation

Agent Mechanism
Atractyloside Inhibits ADP and ATP Transporter
Oligomycin Blocks flow of protons through Fo complex

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: The following endotracheal tube is preferred for _________
questions.solution:
The image shown is of an armored tube (a.k.a. reinforced, flexo-metallic endotracheal tube). It is useful in head and neck surgeries and when the patient is in a prone position.

An armored tube is a flexible, spiral wound tube which is reinforced with the metal coil so as to minimize kinking. The metal coil is better made out in the second image.

Other specialized endotracheal tubes include:

  • South oral Ring Adair Elwin: Nasal surgery
  • Micro laryngeal tubes: Laryngeal surgery 
  • Double-lumen endotracheal tubes (Carlen, Robertshaw): Thoracic surgery

Note: The tip of the armored endotracheal tube is 2 cm distal to the distal-most metal ring, and this portion may not be visualized in radiography.

questions.text: While in OBG posting, your professor teaches about positive Stallworthy sign in a patient. Which of the following statement is false about the condition in this patient?

choices.text: It is a painful vaginal bleeding condition
The patient has low lying placenta
Per-vaginal examination should not be done
The uterus is relaxed and soft with no tenderness

questions.solution:
The Stallworthy sign is seen in placenta previa, a painless vaginal bleeding condition not a painful condition.

Clinical features of placenta previa:

  • Sudden-onset recurrent painless vaginal bleeding: First bleeding usually appears after the end of the second trimester or later and is usually mild and not fatal. This is called ‘Sentinel bleed’. 
  • The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age. 
  • The uterus is relaxed, soft, no tenderness 
  • Floating head 
  • Fetal heart sound is present unless there is major separation and the patient is exsanguinated.
  • Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis which recovers promptly as pressure is relieved is suggestive of a low-lying placenta especially of posterior type: Stallworthy sign.

Per-Vaginal Examination should not be done in suspected Placenta Previa, whereas it can be only done in the operation theatre with all the arrangements for CS.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, increased frequency of micturition, and pain during sex that extends to the vulva and vagina. The pain increases when the bladder is full. Cystoscopy shows fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa as shown in the image below and marked submucosal edema of the bladder. Biopsy reveals mucosal ulceration and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are characteristic of interstitial cystitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

Interstitial cystitis is a rare idiopathic condition that occurs most frequently in women presenting as intermittent severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria. Hunner ulcers are characteristic ulcers seen in interstitial cystitis. It is characterized by marked submucosal edema of the bladder with mucosal ulceration, seen in the late phase of interstitial cystitis.

Cystoscopic findings show fissures and punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) in the bladder mucosa. Microscopically, mucosal ulceration is covered by fibrin, necrotic material, and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells. The pathologic findings are nonspecific, and the main role of biopsy is to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may mimic interstitial cystitis clinically. Late in the course, transmural fibrosis may appear, leading to a contracted bladder.

Other options:

Option A: Malakoplakia is an inflammatory reaction caused by defects in phagocyte function. It occurs during chronic bacterial infections. On cystoscopy, it appears as soft, yellow, raised mucosal plaques 3-4cm in diameter with large aggregates of foamy macrophages.

Option B: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder or urothelial neoplasms are the most common bladder tumors. Morphological variants include papillary, nodular, or flat lesions. 

Option C: Follicular cystitis is characterized by multiple lymphoid follicles in the bladder mucosa or underlying wall. 

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
Interstitial cystitis Idiopathic Hunner's ulcer
Polypoid cystitis Catheterization of bladder Mimics malignancy
Malakoplakia Defective phagocytosis Michaelis– Gutmann bodies
Eosinophilic cystitis Systemic allergic disorders Submucosal eosinophils
Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

 Prophylactic administration of mesna reduces the incidence

questions.text: Packed red blood cell transfusion is started for a patient in the ward. It must be completed within:
questions.solution: Transfusion of pRBCs (packed red blood cells) or whole blood should be completed within 4 hours after the commencement. Transfusion of platelets, fresh frozen plasma, and cryoprecipitate should be completed within 30 minutes.

questions.text: A woman with a deformed nasal tip is set to undergo an augmentation rhinoplasty. The plastic surgeon is performing the procedure using an autologous auricular graft. Images A and B show the donor and recipient sites, respectively. What type of tissue is the structure that is being harvested during the procedure?
questions.solution:
The structure that is being harvested for the rhinoplasty procedure is a part of the auricular cartilage. It is a type of elastic cartilage.

Elastic cartilage, like hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that, much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibers containing elastin protein.

Microscopic fidings of elastic cartilage:

  • Chondrocytes within lacunae
  • Elastic fibers in the matrix
  • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

Trachea and bronchi

Articular cartilage at ends of bones

Epiphyseal plate

Costal cartilages of ribs

Temporary skeleton in embryo

Apices of arytenoid

Epiglottis

Corniculate cartilages

Cuneiform cartilages

Eustachian tube

Pinna(Auricle)

External auditory meatus 

Articular discs e.g. of Temporomandibular joint and Sternoclavicular joint

Intervertebral discs

Menisci

Glenoid and acetabular labrum   

Pubic symphysis

Manubriosternal joint

Lining of the bony grooves for tendons

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent epigastric pain with burning sensation for the past 2 years. The pain usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food. He also says that he sometimes wakes up at night because of severe pain. The most probable cause for his symptoms is:
questions.solution:
Epigastric pain with a burning sensation that usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food suggestive of duodenal ulcer.

The following patterns of pain are usually seen in peptic ulcer disease:

  • Duodenal Ulcer- Pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Pain may awaken the patient from sleep.
  • Gastric Ulcer- Pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common.
  • Perforated ulcer- The bed of the ulcer tunnels through the entire thickness of the gastric wall and opens into the peritoneum. This presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and leads to peritonitis. Radiography shows gas under the diaphragm.
  • Penetrating ulcer- It is a type of perforation where the ulcer tunnels into an adjacent organ like the pancreas/liver. In this case, the pain is no longer relieved by food or antacids and might radiate to the back.

Many patients with peptic ulcers, especially elderly patients, may not have these symptoms and may directly present with a complication like bleeding or perforation.

questions.text: A patient presents with high colored urine. A urine dipstick test done was positive. On further evaluation by centrifugation at 2000rpm for 5 min, the sample was still high colored but became colorless after about 3 hours.  Which among the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Myoglobinuria is most likely in this patient.

A urine dipstick test is the first step to be done in a patient with high coloured urine to help identify true hematuria. A positive dipstick test identifies heme which is present in red blood cells, haemoglobin or myoglobin. A negative dipstick test implies that the reddish discolouration is due to pigments from certain food items (beetroot), drugs or due to porphyrias.

Myoglobinuria is the presence of an excess amount of myoglobin in the urine. It is mostly caused by muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury. 

Causes of myoglobinuria:

  • Physical causes are trauma, crush injury, heatstroke, hypothermia, malignant hyperthermia, extensive burns, seizures, strenuous exercise, and prolonged immobility.
  • Non-physical causes include hypoxic injury, metabolic disturbances, genetic disorders, infections, drugs, and toxins.

The primary goal of treatment in the case of myoglobinuria is to prevent acute kidney injury (AKI), and for that, the initial therapy is mainly focused on rehydration to facilitate the renal clearance of myoglobin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of the sympathetic nerve supply of the stomach?
questions.solution:
The sympathetic nerve supply is not secretomotor to the gastric mucosa.

Nerve supply of the stomach:

Sympathetic nerves: They arise from T5-T12 spinal segments and are distributed to the stomach via the greater and lesser splanchnic nerves and the celiac plexus. They perform the following functions:

  • Vasoconstriction
  • Inhibition of gastric motility and constriction of the pyloric sphincter
  • Carry visceral pain sensations

Parasympathetic nerves: Derived from the right and left vagus nerves. The anterior vagal trunk is formed from the left vagus nerve, whereas the posterior vagal trunk is formed from the right vagus nerve. They perform the following functions:

  • Secretomotor to the gastric mucosa
  • Motor to the gastric musculature
  • Relaxation of pyloric sphincter and promoting gastric emptying
  • Carry sensations such as fullness, nausea, and probably pain.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student complains of an irresistible urge to move his legs, especially during his sleep. He is feeling comfortable only after doing so. He is also experiencing burning, itching, and cramp-like sensation in his legs. What is the ideal drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is restless leg syndrome. Ropinirole is a dopaminergic agonist approved for its treatment.

Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during periods of rest and especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of legs. In idiopathic cases, dopaminergic hypofunction is postulated.

Another dopamine agonist that can be used in the treatment of restless leg syndrome is pramipexole.

Other options:

Option A- Riluzole is a benzothiazole derivative that is used in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. They inhibit glutaminergic transmission.

Option C- Rilmenidine is an imidazoline receptor agonist that is used for the management of hypertension.

Option D- Rimonabant is an inverse agonist of the CB1 (cannabinoid receptor) that was used as an anti-obesity medication.

questions.text: An anaesthetist notices diffusion hypoxia in a patient who was anesthetized with N2O. Which of the following statement is true regarding this phenomenon?

choices.text: Hypoxia is observed during  induction with nitrous oxide
Due to slow diffusion of nitrous oxide from blood to alveoli
N2O diffusion results in reduced alveolar PCO2
To avoid hypoxia, 100% air should be administered when N2O is discontinued

questions.solution:
In Diffusion hypoxia, nitrous oxide diffusion results in reduced alveolar Pco2.

Diffusion hypoxia occurs during recovery (not during induction) from nitrous oxide anesthesia when N2O is suddenly cut off.

Nitrous oxide diffuses rapidly from the blood to the alveoli and replaces the oxygen which reduces alveolar O2 concentration, resulting in relative hypoxemia. Another effect of rapid outgassing of N2O into alveoli is the dilution of alveolar Pco2, which can also reduce respiratory drive.

To avoid hypoxia, 100% O2 rather than air should be administered when N2O is discontinued.

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: A first-year medical student is doing a meticulous dissection of the thoracic cage in a human cadaver. During dissection, he sees an osseo-aponeurotic opening in the diaphragm transmitting a large vessel. Which among the following other structures can be seen passing through the same opening?

choices.text: Left vagus nerve and thoracic duct
Right vagus nerve and thoracic duct

questions.solution:
The osseo-aponeurotic opening in the diaphragm transmits the aorta. The other structures which pass through the same opening are the azygous vein and the thoracic duct. 

It is the most posteroinferior of the three larger openings in the diaphragm and lies at the level of the T12 vertebra. It is bounded laterally by the two diaphragmatic crura, the vertebral column posteriorly, and anteriorly by the median arcuate ligament.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Major openings through the diaphragm

Level of opening

T8

T10

T12

Located in

In the central tendon

In the muscular part

In crus of the diaphragm

Structures passing through

 

Inferior Vena cava

Right phrenic nerve 

Oesophagus

Vagus nerve- right and left

Aorta

Thoracic duct

Azygous vein

Hemiazygous vein

 

Minor openings through the diaphragm

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Many enzymes are activated in fed or fasting state by covalent modification such as adding or removal of phosphate groups. Which of the enzyme is active in the dephosphorylated state?
questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase is highly active in the well-fed/high insulin/dephosphorylated state.

The rest of the enzymes are active in the phosphorylated state/low insulin/fasting State.

Related Pearl: Enzymes active in phosphorylated and dephosphorylated state

Phosphorylated state

(Low insulin)

Dephosphorylated state

(High insulin)
  • Fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase
  • PEP carboxykinase
  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Glycogen phosphorylase
  • Hormone-sensitive lipase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Glycogen synthase
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • HMG CoA reductase

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and a rash on her face, as seen below. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are positive. Which of the following is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and image is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). C1, C2, and C4 complements are deficient in SLE patients.

The rash seen in the image is a malar rash (classically seen in SLE); it is characterized by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences, with sparing of the nasolabial folds. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are specific for SLE.

Clinical syndromes associated with genetic deficiencies of various complement components:

  • C1 inhibitor deficiency - Hereditary angioedema
  • C1, C2, C4 deficiency - SLE and other collagen vascular disorders
  • C5-C8 deficiency - Toxoplasmosis, bacteremia with gram-negative diplococci 
  • C3 and its regulatory protein or C3b inactivator deficiency - Severe recurrent pyogenic infections

questions.text: A 25-year-old male complained of burning micturition, multiple joints pains, and red eyes. Reiter's syndrome is suspected. Which of the following cutaneous feature is likely to be associated?
questions.solution:
Keratoderma blennorrhagica is seen associated with Reiter’s syndrome in 10% of cases.

Reiter syndrome is a systemic disorder, originally defined as a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. Cutaneous involvement includes psoriasiform lesions, named keratoderma blennorrhagic um (in about 10%), painful and erosive lesions on the tips of the fingers and toes, nail dystrophy (20-30%) and erythroderma as a rare complication.

In addition, there may be other distinct mucocutaneous manifestations like circinate balanitis, these are small, shallow, painless ulcerative lesions on the glans penis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady came to you in the outpatient department in the peripheral setting. She repeatedly self-medicates with antacid tablets. She complains of numbness in her hands. Which of the following is false with regards to the condition she is suffering from?

choices.text: Pernicious anemia is the most common cause
Upper limbs are affected before lower limbs
Methylmalonic acid, homocysteine levels are elevated
Myopathy is a key feature of the disease

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicates vitamin B12 deficiency due to chronic antacid use, leading to neuropathy. Myopathy is not a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency.

A myopathy is a muscle disease that is unrelated to any disorder of innervation or neuromuscular junction. The common symptoms of myopathy include muscle weakness, impaired function in activities of daily life, and very rarely, muscle pain, and tenderness. 

Acid lowering agents like proton pump inhibitors alter the hydrogen ion secretion into the stomach leading to an increase in gastric pH. The change in pH modifies the bioavailability and absorption of vitamins and minerals, like vitamin B12. 

Pernicious anemia is the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency may produce several neurological manifestations.

A preferential large-fiber sensory loss affecting proprioception and vibration with sparing of small-fiber modalities occurs in Vitamin B12 deficiency. Upper limb paresthesias occur before lower limbs are affected. 

An unsteady gait may be seen due to sensory ataxia.

Severe cases may show optic neuropathy and behavioral changes ranging from mild irritation and forgetfulness to severe dementia and frank psychosis.

Serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine are elevated because the enzymes which metabolize them require B12 and in a deficient state these products start building up.

questions.text: You are evaluating a cyanotic newborn with an echocardiogram showing pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. Which developmental structure's defective maturation is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
This newborn is found to have pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. The structure which gives rise to the root of the pulmonary artery is the truncus arteriosus which is marked as '4' in the given image.

Structures marked:

  1. Sinus venosus
  2. Atrium
  3. Bulbus cordis
  4. Truncus arteriosus

The heart tube begins to bend by day 23. This bending creates the cardiac loop which is completed by day 28. The fate of various structures formed as a result of this bending is as follows:

Given below are the heart tube and their derivatives:

 Part of the heart tube Derivative structure in the heart

Bulbus cordis

  • Proximal 1/3 

 

  • Middle 1/3 (conus cordis)

 

  • Distal 1/3 (truncus arteriosus)

 

  • Trabeculated part of right ventricle

 

  • Outflow tract of right and left ventricles

 

  • Root and proximal portions of aorta and pulmonary artery
Primitive ventricle
  • Trabeculated part of the left ventricle
Primitive atrium
  • The common atrium that splits to right and left atrium

questions.text: A surgeon has been performing a difficult neck dissection for the past 3 hours. During the procedure, he has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve. Which of the following triangles of the neck, is he probably dissecting?
questions.solution:
The surgeon has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve, which has its major course in the carotid triangle.

The hypoglossal nerve leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It then descends to the carotid triangle. Here, in the carotid triangle, the nerve makes a loop lateral to the internal and external carotid arteries. The nerve then ascends to the digastric triangle, reaches further up supplying the muscles of the tongue.

Contents of the carotid triangle:

  • Common carotid artery, internal and external carotid artery
  • Branches of external carotid – superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Spinal part of the accessory
  • Sympathetic chain
  • Ansa cervicalis

questions.text: A patient's urine microscopy revealed the structure below. The given disease is classified under ________
questions.solution:
The given image is an egg of Schistosoma haematobium, recognized with its terminal spine and internal miracidia. Schistosomiasis is an example of Metazoonoses.

Zoonoses: Those diseases and infections which are naturally transmitted from other vertebrate animals and man.

Meta-zoonoses are zoonotic diseases transmitted by invertebrate vectors, in which the infective agent develops/multiplies and after a period of extrinsic period of incubation is transmitted to a vertebrate host. Examples include Arboviral infections, Plague, and Schistosomiasis.

Classification based on their reservoir hosts into:

  • Anthropozoonoses
  • Zoo-anthroponoses
  • Amphixenoses

Classification based on the life cycle of the infecting agent:

Category

Mode

Example

Direct zoonoses

Direct contact/ fomite/mechanical vector

No essential developmental/ propagative changes during transmission

Rabies, Trichinosis, Brucellosis

Cyclo-zoonoses

Require more than one vertebrate host is needed to complete the developmental cycle and not an invertebrate host

 Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Meta-zoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors, in which, In the invertebrate, the infective agent develops / multiplies and after a period of extrinsic period of incubation is transmitted to another vertebrate host.

Arboviral infections, Plague and Schistosomiasis

Sapro-zoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil/ plants)developmental site/reservoir

Various forms of larva migrants and mycoses

questions.text: A young boy was noticed to have the following finding on general examination. Which among the following conditions is it most likely associated with?
questions.solution:
The lesion seen in the picture is that of the Shagreen patch. It is seen in Tuberous sclerosis.

Skin lesions in Tuberous sclerosis:

  • Shagreen patches are characteristic of tuberous sclerosis and consist of a roughened, raised lesions. They have an orange-peel consistency and are located primarily in the lumbosacral region
  • The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients (visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp).
  • Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age. They are tiny red nodules present over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. They can enlarge and coalesce to give a fleshy appearance.
  • Periungual fibromas are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients.
  • Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis (confetti=small pieces of paper used to throw at celebrations).

Image (below): Facial angiofibroma (Adenoma sebaceum)

Image (below): Periungual fibroma

Image (below): Confetti skin lesions

Image (below): Ash leaf–type macules

questions.text: A Gravida 2 Para 1 woman with 37 weeks of gestation presents with true labor pain and cervical dilation. L/S ratio (Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio) of the newborn baby was found to be <1.5. A defect in which of the following cells can account for this finding?
questions.solution:
L/S ratio of ≥ 2 is considered normal (not ≥1). L/S ratio of < 1.5 is suggestive of fetal lung immaturity due to reduced/absent surfactant synthesis. Surfactant is produced by type 2 pneumocytes.

Major surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (i.e Lecithin). It reduces the surface tension of water. 

Components of surfactant:

  • Phospholipid - Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) also known as Dipalmitoyl Lecithin. Lecithin is the most abundant lipid in surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol - Minor component
  • Surfactant apoproteins
  • Calcium ions
  • 4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: Surfactant protein (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

Clinical relevance:

  • Tests to assess fetal lung maturity:
    • L/S ratio i.e. Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio: Ratio ≥ 2 is considered normal.
    • Shake test/Bubble test/Clement test: Formation of stable foam in the presence of surfactant.
    • Phosphatidylglycerol levels in Amniotic fluid
  • Autosomal dominant familial interstitial lung disease has absent surfactant protein SP-C.
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis - Autoantibody against GM-CSF which is involved in the clearance of surfactant.

The primary alveoli develop and the production of the surfactant begins by week 20-24. However, it does not reach the lungs until later. The surfactant appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. Mature levels of the pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 weeks of gestation.

Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase production of surfactant.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most common nail change seen in lichen planus?
questions.solution:
The most common nail changes seen in lichen planus are the formation of longitudinal ridges and grooves over the nail due to slight thinning of nails.

Nail involvement occurs in up to 10% of cases. These changes usually occur in the context of severe generalized Lichen planus, although skin lesions may not be seen in the vicinity of the affected nail. Elevated ridges may be seen on the nail. Adhesion between the epidermis of the dorsal nail fold and the nail bed may cause partial destruction of the nail (pterygium unguis).

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

questions.text: A retired army officer was advised to undergo a complete health check-up. During an examination, the radiologist identifies a bullet present in the body surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. What type of bullet is it called?
questions.solution:
The kind of bullet identified by the radiologist as explained in the given scenario is known as souvenir bullet.

Souvenir bullet is the one which has been lodged in the body for a long time with no fresh bleeding around it and surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. They can be visualized on X-rays. They are usually a result of bullet lodging in an inaccessible space which may result in more damage on attempted retrieval. e.g. Bullet in the spine.

Other options:

Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet): This is where two bullets come out with a single shot. Seen with unused or locally made weapons. It may cause confusion with the number of entry and exit wounds.

Incendiary bullets: Type of army bullet used to cause fire in the target.

questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair regarding the mode of inheritance and the conditions.
questions.solution:
Friedreich’s ataxia is an autosomal recessive inherited disease, resulting from a mutation of a gene locus on chromosome 9.

The condition causes nervous system damage and movement problems. It usually begins in childhood and leads to impaired muscle coordination (ataxia) that worsens over time.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child with acute diarrhea is being treated with oral rehydration solution (ORS).  Which of the following is correct regarding zinc supplementation in this child?
questions.solution:
A 7-month-old child being treated for acute diarrhea should be supplemented with oral zinc at 20 mg/day for 10-14 days.

Zinc administration for diarrhea management can significantly reduce mortality and hospital admission. In addition, it improves diarrhea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials.

Zinc supplementation is usually done for 10 to 14 days. The dosage is age-dependent as follows:

Age <6 months: 10 mg/day

Age >6 months:  20 mg/day

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of progressive breathlessness and cough for 3 months. A chest X-ray showed a cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the right lung. Wedge resection of the lesion was done, and the histopathology image is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of a patient with a history of cough and breathlessness. This, combined with cavitary lesions on radiography and the histological slide showing the characteristic hydatid cysts, are suggestive of infection with Echinococcus granulosus.

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

  • Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host's inflammatory response.
  • Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
  • Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction, giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

The clinical features of hydatid disease of the lung are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain. Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole.

The below image shows the histology of a hydatid cyst.

questions.text: An infant with a large head and normal length was brought with failure to thrive. On examination hepatosplenomegaly and frontal bossing were noted. Blood tests show pancytopenia and X-ray imaging is done which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A presentation of failure to thrive in an infant with a large head, normal length, pancytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and the X-ray image showing dense bones is suggestive of osteopetrosis. 

Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease/Albers–Schönberg disease:

It is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to mutation of CLCN7 (in osteoclasts).

Clinical features: Macrocephaly (due to hydrocephalus), developmental delay, pancytopenia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Blood investigation: Low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels.

Radiological features: Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. Diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen. The skull base shows uniform radiodensity

Treatment: Symptomatic treatment and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be done.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old cirrhotic patient has been posted for a laparotomy procedure. He has encephalopathy and severe ascites. His pre-operative workup results are given below. According to the Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system, which class would the patient fall into?

Serum bilirubin: 3.2 mg/dl
Serum albumin: 2.4 g/dl
Prothrombin time: increased by 7 seconds
INR: 2.5
questions.solution:
The Child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the patient described is Class C.

The points for:

  • Serum bilirubin of 3.2mg/dl: 3
  • Serum albumin of 2.4g/dl: 3
  • INR of 2.5: 3
  • Uncontrolled encephalopathy: 3
  • Uncontrolled ascites: 3

Therefore the Child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the total points (3+3+3+3+3)= 15 is Class C.

Related Pearl: Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score

The Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) score was originally developed to evaluate the risk of portocaval shunt procedures performed for portal hypertension. It is also useful in predicting the surgical risks of other intra-abdominal operations performed in cirrhotic patients.

Variable

2 Points

3 Points

Bilirubin level

<2 mg/dL

2–3 mg/dL

>3 mg/dL

Albumin level

>3.5 g/dL

2.8–3.5 g/dL

<2.8 g/dL

Prothrombin time (increased seconds)

International normalized ratio

1–3

<1.7

4–6

1.7–2.3

>6

>2.3

Encephalopathy

None

Controlled

Uncontrolled

Ascites

None

Controlled

Uncontrolled

Child-Turcotte-Pugh class and overall surgical mortality rates:

  • Class A = 5–6 points - Well-compensated - 10% mortality
  • Class B = 7–9 points - Decompensated and significant  functional compromise - 30% mortality
  • Class C = 10–15 points - Severerly decompensated - 75-80% mortality

Prognosis of the various CTP classes:

A 100 85
B 80 60
C 45 35

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of chronic low backache and a few other neurological symptoms. During the evaluation, an MRI is done, which is suggestive of astrocytoma, involving the left side of the T11 - T12 spinal cord parenchyma. If the mass lesion is just compressing the left side of the cord, which of the following sensory/motor deficit can be expected on the right side, below the level of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, with a lesion in the left side of the spinal cord, can be compared to that of Brown-sequard syndrome. Hence, the female would have a loss of temperature sensation on the right side of the body below the level of the lesion

Brown-sequard syndrome:

Caused due to hemisection of the Spinal cord. It can also be caused by fracture-dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor.

Clinical features:

  • Pyramidal tract: Pyramidal weakness (ipsilateral upper motor neuron type of paralysis) below the level of the lesion on the same side as the lesion (pyramidal tract crosses in the medulla).
  • Dorsal columns: Impaired fine touch, 2 point discrimination, proprioception, vibration below the level of the lesion on the same side of the lesion (dorsal column fibers cross in the medulla).
  • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure sensation below the level of the lesion on the contralateral side of the lesion (spinothalamic tract crosses midline after entering the cord).

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A surgeon is performing transurethral resection for a patient with an enlarged prostate gland. The prostatic part of the urethra where he operates contains which of the following types of epithelium?
questions.solution:
The prostatic urethra is lined by both urothelium and pseudostratified/stratified columnar epithelium.

The proximal part of the prostatic urethra (i.e. up to the opening of the ejaculatory duct) is lined by the transitional epithelium (urothelium). Whereas the distal part of the prostatic urethra is lined by the stratified or pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

questions.text: How many primary level vision centers are proposed as per the Vision 2020 Program?
questions.solution:
The number of primary level vision centers proposed as per Vision 2020 Program is 20000.

Centers No. of Service centers
Center of Excellence 20
Training centers 200
Service centers 2000
Primary level vision centers 20,000

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse. What is this called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a man with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse is suggestive of satyriasis. 

Satyriasis refers to uncontrollable or excessive sexual desire (hypersexuality) in males. It is also known as Don Juanism. Don Juan is a legendary, fictional libertine who devoted his life to seducing women.

In patients with this condition, sexual activity is usually a means to mask their deep feelings of inferiority. Some patients may have unconscious homosexual impulses, which they deny through compulsive sexual contact with women. They are usually not interested in women after sex.

Other options: 

Option B: Frotteurism is a form of paraphilic disorder, wherein the affected male achieves sexual gratification by rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman, usually in crowded places.

Option C: Nymphomania refers to excessive sexual desire or hypersexuality in women. It is a form of sexual addiction. 

Option D: Sexual masochism is a form of paraphilia, wherein the individual has sexual fantasies or urges that involve acts of being beaten, bound, or humiliated. It is more commonly seen in men.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the mucocele of the gall bladder?
questions.solution:
The gall bladder is easily palpable in mucocele.

  • Mucocele is due to prolonged obstruction of the cystic duct usually by a large solitary calculus.
  • Obstructed GB lumen is progressively distended by mucus or by a clear transudate produced by mucous epithelial cells.
  • Clinical features:
    • A visible, easily palpable, non-tender gall bladder
    • Frequently remains asymptomatic.
  • Treatment: early cholecystectomy

questions.text: A 42-year-old factory worker was brought to the emergency department due to the splash of the chemical reagent in his right eye. On examination, the cornea looks hazy, and less than one-third of the limbus is found ischaemic. Which of the following grading system would you use to assess its severity?
questions.solution:
Roper-Hall classification is used to assess the severity of chemical injuries. The patient is having grade 2 chemical injury according to this system. 

Chemical injuries to the eye:

  • Alkali burns are twice as common as acid burns.
  • Alkalis tend to penetrate more deeply than acids, as the latter coagulate surface proteins, forming a protective barrier.
  • The most commonly involved alkalis are ammonia, sodium hydroxide, and lime.
  • Grading of severity (Roper–Hall system)
    • On the basis of corneal clarity and severity of limbal ischemia:
      • Grade 1 is characterized by a clear cornea (epithelial damage only) and no limbal ischemia (excellent prognosis).
      • Grade 2 shows a hazy cornea but with visible iris detail and less than one-third of the limbus being ischemic (good prognosis).
      • Grade 3 manifests as a total loss of the corneal epithelium, stromal haze obscuring iris detail, and between one-third and half of the limbus showing ischemia (guarded prognosis).
      • Grade 4 manifests with an opaque cornea and more than 50% of the limbus showing ischemia (poor prognosis).

questions.text: A bacteriologist experiments by streaking S. aureus across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated and after overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae was found to be large and well developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller, farther away from the streak. This demonstrates dependence of  H. influenzae on __________
questions.solution:
The above phenomenon noticed by bacteriologist is Satellitism. This demonstrates dependence of H. influenzae on Factor V.

In Satellitism, Factor V is available in high concentrations near staphylococcal growth and in smaller quantities away from it. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus and factor V is required for the growth of H. influenza and hence the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller, farther away from the streak.

questions.text: A patient who presents to the ER with chest pain and dyspnea is diagnosed with STEMI. Swift revascularization by thrombolysis is planned for her.  What is the dose of streptokinase to be used?
questions.solution:
Streptokinase is given in a dose of 1.5 million units IV given over 1 hour for treatment of MI.

Fibrinolytic therapy should ideally be initiated within 30 min of presentation. The fibrinolytic agents that have been approved for IV use in patients with STEMI are:

  • Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)
  • Streptokinase
  • Tenecteplase (TNK)
  • Reteplase (rPA) 

Adverse effects of streptokinase:

  • Transient hypotension
  • Allergic reactions
  • Hemorrhage

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with blisters on his upper chest and back and mucosal lesions as shown. On examination, the bullae were flaccid and filled with clear fluid. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Flaccid bullae on the skin and oral erosions suggest a diagnosis of mucocutaneous pemphigus vulgaris.

Oral erosions usually precede skin manifestations. The skin lesions are flaccid blisters with clear fluid on an erythematous base, that rupture to produce painful erosions. These are distributed over the face, scalp, upper chest, back, and neck.

Options B and D: Bullous pemphigoid and epidermolysis bullosa acquisita show subepidermal involvement with tense blisters.

Option C: Pemphigus foliaceus causes superficial blisters with no mucosal involvement.

questions.text: A patient presented with profuse watery diarrhoea and muscle cramps for the past few weeks. The diarrhoea was intractable to antibiotics and stool culture was negative for organisms. He also complained of indigestion and frequent bloating. On investigation, he was found to have microcytic hypochromic anaemia. Serum potassium was 2.4 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy was normal. Excess of which of the following hormones leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of WDHA syndrome. It is due to hypersecretion of VIP (vasoactive-intestinal peptide).

WDHA syndrome includes the following features:

  • Watery diarrhea
  • Hypokalemia (Serum K+< 3.5 mmol/L)
  • Achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency)

Neural crest tumors, such as neuroblastomas, ganglioneuroblastoma, ganglioneuromas, and pheochromocytomas can also be associated with VIPoma syndrome.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon, while operating, found a primary carcinoma affecting the aryepiglottic folds. The clinical records of the patient mention complaints of dysphagia, but no hoarseness, and lymph node involvement with palpable upper and mid jugular nodes. What is the most likely cancer he is operating on?
questions.solution:
The surgeon is most likely operating on a supraglottic carcinoma.

Laryngeal carcinoma is one of the most common causes of head and neck cancers and is caused by smoking and alcohol abuse. The primary sites are supraglottis, glottis, and subglottis.

Supraglottic carcinoma occurs in the epiglottis, false cords, and aryepiglottic folds. Lesions are often asymptomatic until they are quite large and the first sign would be a neck swelling due to cervical node metastasis. Lymph node metastasis occurs early and level II (upper jugular) and III (middle jugular) lymph nodes are the most commonly involved. As the tumor increases in size, patients complain of alteration in phonation, hoarseness, otalgia, and dysphagia. In the case of epiglottic cancers, bilateral metastases can be seen. 

Other options: 

Option A: Glottic carcinoma presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom. Lesions of the vocal cords affect its vibratory capacity. Therefore they are diagnosed early and have a better prognosis. Lymphatic spread is rarely seen. 

Option B: Subglottic carcinoma is seen extending from the glottis to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. It involves prelaryngeal, pretracheal, paratracheal, and lower jugular lymph nodes. Stridor or features of laryngeal obstruction is the early features of the disease. Hoarseness is a late feature of subglottic carcinoma. 

Option D: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma causes nasal symptoms like obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, and epistaxis. There are also otologic symptoms due to eustachian tube obstruction causing conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. Cranial nerves may be involved and can cause ophthalmoneurologic features like squint, diplopia, and facial pain. Cervical node metastasis is also commonly seen. 

Related Pearl: Sites and subsites of the larynx (AJCC Classification)

Sites

Subsites

Supraglottis

Suprahyoid epiglottis

Infrahyoid epiglottis

Arytenoids

Aryepiglottic folds with the corniculate and cuneiform cartilages

False/Ventricular cords

Glottis

Subglottis

Image :  A top view of the larynx (seen with a mirror).

questions.text: La-belle indifference is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
La-belle indifference is seen in conversion disorder. It is the absence of concern towards one’s problem despite the apparent severe disability.

A conversion reaction is an acute and temporary loss or alteration in motor or sensory function triggered by psychosocial stress. Most of the patients have a history of traumatic events in childhood. The symptoms or deficits of conversion disorder are not intentionally produced. 

Symptoms of conversion disorder include:

  • Mutism, blindness, and paralysis are the most common symptoms.
  • Sensory system: Anesthesia and paresthesia
  • Motor system: Abnormal movements, gait disturbance (astasia abasia), weakness, paralysis, tics, jerks, etc.
  • Central nervous system: Pseudo-seizures

Other options: 

Option A: Illness anxiety disorder - The person may or may not have a medical illness but whose anxiety is out of proportion to their diagnosis and assumes the worst possible outcome imaginable.

Option B: Factitious disorder - The person simulates, induces, or aggravates illness to receive medical attention, regardless of whether or not they are ill. They may inflict injury to themselves or people close to them to receive medical care. There is no other motivation like avoidance of duty or financial gain.

Option C: Malingering - The person seeks hospitalization, similar to individuals with factitious disorder, however, this is driven by primary motivations like avoidance of duty, legal responsibility, or financial gain.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child has a tumour in the mid pons. Which of the following patterns of breathing can be seen in this child, assuming that the vagal afferents are also abolished?
questions.solution:
Apneusis is the pattern of breathing that can be seen in this child because a tumour in the mid pons inhibits the signal charges from the apneustic centre.

At mid pontine level lesion, the apneustic centre is intact while the pneumotaxic centre is separated. Concurrent removal of vagus inputs causes this kind of abnormal pattern of breathing characterized by deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief insufficient release.

Related Pearl: Effects of Various Lesions and Brainstem Transections

Label

Level of transection

Vagi intact

Vagi cut

A

Complete transection above pons

Regular breathing continues

Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

B

Mid-pontine level section

Regular breathing continues

Apneusis develops

C

Transection midway between pons and medulla

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

D

Complete transection below medulla

Spontaneous respiration ceases

Spontaneous respiration ceases

CP - middle cerebellar peduncle

DRG - Dorsal group of respiratory neurons

IC - inferior colliculus

NPBL - nucleus parabrachialis (pneumotaxic center)

VRG - ventral group of respiratory neurons

4th vent - fourth ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about fibromuscular dysplasia?

choices.text: String of beads appearance on angiography
Most commonly affected peripheral artery is subclavian artery

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and the string of beads appearance on CT angiography is characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common peripheral (limb) arteries affected are the iliac arteries.

Fibromuscular dysplasia is a segmental, non-atheromatous, dysplastic type of angiopathy that predominantly affects females. The most common subtype is medial fibroplasia. It is one of the major causes of renovascular hypertension. The most common sites of involvement in decreasing order of frequency are as follows:

  1. Renal arteries
  2. Carotid arteries
  3. Peripheral (limb) arteries - most commonly iliac arteries

On angiography, a string of beads appearance is seen as shown below.

questions.text: A person is having opioid-induced bradycardia. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be used to counteract opioid-induced bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Pancuronium is vagolytic (resulting from blockade of M2 receptors) leading to increased heart rate and hence can be used to counteract opioid-induced bradycardia.

Pancuronium-induced tachycardia has been attributed to the following:

  • Vagolytic action: Inhibition of M2 receptors
  • Sympathetic stimulation: Direct by blockade of neuronal uptake of norepinephrine and indirectly by release of norepinephrine from adrenergic nerve endings.

Other options: Vecuronium, cisatracurium, and atracurium are nonvagolytic relaxants

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: A physiologist studies a chemoreceptor that detects elevated sodium levels and decreases the glomerular filtration rate. In the given image of the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which of the marked structures represents this chemoreceptor?
questions.solution:
The chemoreceptors that detect elevated sodium and decrease the glomerular filtration rate are the macula densa cells in the distal convoluted tubule. These are marked as '1' in the given illustration.

Macula densa cells are chemoreceptors that detect sodium and chloride concentrations of the tubular fluid. In response to elevated sodium and chloride, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, resulting in decreased flow of blood to the glomerulus and reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This vasoconstriction is mediated via increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity leading to increased adenosine formation resulting in calcium release. 

The given illustration shows:

1- Macula densa: These are specialized cells at the start of the distal convoluted tubule form the macula densa. 

2- Granular cells/JG cells: These are modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole; these are mechanoreceptors that secrete renin in response to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn, increases the blood pressure. 

3- Lacis cells: These are extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. 

4- Proximal tubular cells: These are involved in sustaining glomerulotubular balance, a mechanism by which the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes is maintained at constant levels. This is achieved by increasing the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule in response to increased GFR.

questions.text: Which of the following provides the nutrient artery to the femur?
questions.solution:
The second perforating branch of the profunda femoris artery is the nutrient artery to the femur.

The following table shows bones of the lower limb and their nutrient arteries:

Bones of the Lower limb

Nutrient arteries

Femur

2nd perforating branch of the profunda femoris

Tibia

Branch of posterior tibial artery

Fibula

Peroneal artery, a branch of posterior tibial artery

questions.text: Diffusion is one of the processes involved in transporting substances across the cell membrane in the human body. Which of the following factors increases the rate of diffusion?
questions.solution:
Among the given factors, decreased size of the molecule (to be diffused) increases the rate of the diffusion.

Whereas, a decrease in the temperature, lipid solubility, and the area of the membrane altogether decreases the rate of the diffusion.

Related Pearl: Factors influencing the rate of net diffusion of a substance across a membrane

Fick’s Law of Diffusion → J = -DA (Δc/Δx)

where,

J is the net rate of diffusion,

D is the diffusion coefficient,

A is the area, and

Δc/Δx is the concentration gradient.

Factors Effect on diffusion
↑ Thickness of the membrane ↓
↑ Lipid Solubility ↑
↑ Temperature ↑
↑  Size of the molecule ↓
↑  Area of the Membrane ↑
↑ Distribution of Protein Channels ↑

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, who was diagnosed with ventral hernia underwent an inlay technique of hernia repair to close the defect. Which of the following positions represents the correct placement of mesh in this technique?
questions.solution:
The correct placement of mesh in the Inlay technique of hernia repair is marked as "B".

Depending on the position of the mesh-placement the inlay, sublay, and onlay technique are differentiated.

Inlay repair:

  • Mesh is sutured to the fascial edge without overlap
  • Associated with a high recurrence rate

Onlay or overlay:

  • Placement of mesh over anterior fascia
  • Mesh is placed outside abdominal cavity

Underlay (Sublay):

  • Mesh placed below fascial components
  • Retrorectus
  • Preperitoneal
  • Intraperitoneal

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination, the eye is white and there are no obvious signs on ophthalmoscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis.

There are 3 types of optic neuritis: papillitis, neuroretinitis, and retrobulbar neuritis. The common causes of retrobulbar neuritis include demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease).

Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss.  Ocular movements are painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensations known as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also be impaired. 

On examination, Marcus Gunn pupil or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is usually noted due to asymmetric involvement. The most common visual field defect is a central or centrocecal scotoma. 

Type Retrobulbar neuritis Papillitis Neuroretinitis
Pathology Inflammation of the optic nerve behind the disc Inflammation of the optic nerve head  Inflammation of the optic nerve head and the macula
Fundus appearance Optic disc appears normal

Hyperemia and oedema of the optic disc with or without peri-papillary flame-shaped hemorrhages

 Macular star (due to exudates that form around macula)
Prevalence Most common in adults

Most common in children

 Least common type
Associated conditions Strong association with demyelinating disorders like MS, NMO

Weak association with demyelinating disorders

 Cat-scratch disease, Lyme disease, Syphilis etc.

 

The image below shows papillitis.

 

The image below shows macular star appearance in neuroretinitis.
